questions.text: A 2-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery. He was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 27-year-old woman who had inconsistent prenatal care. The mother’s medical history includes generalized seizures managed with carbamazepine. She took routine prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. The mother has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years, she does not use alcohol, and she used cocaine 1-2 times per month during the pregnancy.  Physical examination of the patient shows a newborn male in no acute distress. The patient moves the upper extremities freely but not the lower extremities. There is a red, fleshy, swelling present on the lower back. Stroking the skin around the anus does not produce a contraction of the anal sphincter. Which of the following interventions could have prevented this neonate’s abnormalities?

choices.text: Increasing the dose of prenatal vitamins

questions.solution:
This neonate is presenting with an abnormal lesion on the lower back, paraplegia, and loss of anal sphincter tone -- a presentation consistent with meningomyelocele. 

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g. spina bifida occulta).   Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Most isolated NTDs appear to be caused by folate deficiency, probably in combination with genetic or environmental risk factors. Folate deficiency may arise from inadequate oral intake, malabsorption, use of folic acid antagonists, or genetic causes of abnormal folate metabolism. Folic acid supplementation is recommended for all women during preconception and the first trimester periods; 0.4 mg daily of folic acid is recommended for all women, beginning before conception and continued through pregnancy. For women taking carbamazepine or valproate, or those with a prior infant with an NTD or with an NTD affecting either parent, a higher folic acid dose of 4 mg daily is recommended.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Cessation of cocaine use:
Incorrect: Cocaine is a potent vasoconstrictor, and therefore, it can cause fetal and placental injury leading to placental abruption, spontaneous abortion, prematurity, and fetal death. Neural tube defects, as seen in this patient, are not associated with cocaine use.  
❌ Smoking cessation:
Incorrect: Tobacco use negatively affects both maternal and fetal health and continues over into the postnatal period. Tobacco use is associated with neonatal death, reduction in birth weight, placental abruption, placenta previa, and preterm birth. It is also associated with specific congenital malformations such as cleft lip with gastroschisis, cardiac defects, digital anomalies, bilateral renal agenesis, and anal atresia but not neural tube defects.   
❌ Changing carbamazepine to valproate:
Incorrect: Both valproate and carbamazepine, as well as other folate antagonists (e.g., methotrexate), are associated with neural tube defects. Therefore, changing to valproate is unlikely to change the prognosis.   
✅ Increasing the dose of prenatal vitamins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male is brought to the emergency department by his parents for jaundice and hypotonia. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient was jaundiced at birth, and the symptoms have persisted. He is exclusively breastfed and produces 6-7 wet diapers per day. Family history is notable for hypertension in his father. Physical examination shows jaundice and reduced muscle tone throughout the body. In addition, the patient has scleral icterus and impaired upward gaze in the left eye. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  16.5 mg/dL 
 Hematocrit  49.5% 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin  27.8 pg/cell 
 Leukocyte count  7,100/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  23.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
Which of the following interventions will provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I, a congenital condition characterized by the absence of UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. Therefore, affected individuals cannot conjugate bilirubin at all. This deficiency ultimately leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with a very high total bilirubin levels that can range from 20-50 mg/dL.  

Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I typically develop symptoms soon after birth. These symptoms include persistent neonatal jaundice and kernicterus, which can cause neurological deficits ranging from hypotonia to extraocular palsy.

Temporizing treatment to bring down bilirubin levels include plasmapheresis and phototherapy. Plasmapheresis removes albumin and any bound bilirubin. Phototherapy works by increasing the polarity and water solubility of unconjugated bilirubin, hence allowing it to be excreted via urine. However, the only definitive treatment for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I is liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is used to treat Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, a condition characterized by reduced UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. The medication increases UDPGT activity, thus reducing unconjugated bilirubin levels. However, phenobarbital is not effective in managing Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I, in which there is no UDPGT to stimulate.
❌ Initiation of plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is an intervention that can temporarily reduce serum bilirubin levels. This therapy works because unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin, which is removed by plasmapheresis. However, plasmapheresis does not provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition.
✅ Liver transplantation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of phototherapy  :
Incorrect: Phototherapy increases the polarity and water solubility of unconjugated bilirubin. This therapy helps increase the unconjugated bilirubin’s excretion from the body. However, phototherapy is only a temporizing measure for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1, and patients will ultimately need a liver transplant.
❌ Surgical splenectomy:
Incorrect: Hereditary spherocytosis can cause increased hemolysis and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Splenectomy can provide definitive treatment for this condition. However, patients with hereditary spherocytosis will likely have laboratory findings showing anemia, increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, and increased reticulocyte count. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned findings.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of nasal congestion. His parent reports the patient has had nasal congestion and an evening cough for two weeks. The patient’s three-year-old brother had similar symptoms that have since resolved. The patient was improving, but four days ago, he developed worsening nasal discharge and fever to 39.2°C (102.6°F). His parent has not noticed a change in appetite. The patient has not had a sore throat, ear pain, or headache. He is otherwise healthy. Current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/71 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for edematous and erythematous nasal turbinates, and purulent mucus is visualized in the posterior nasopharynx. The pediatrician suspects acute bacterial sinusitis. This infection most likely spread to which of the following anatomic spaces?
questions.solution:
The nasal cavity has numerous connections to its surrounding spaces. It is important to remember the relationship between the nasal cavity and its surrounding structures because nasal congestion can cause inflammation and swelling of the mucosa close to the openings of these spaces. When the surrounding spaces are unable to drain properly, infection can develop and spread.

In particular, the maxillary sinuses are the most common site to which an infection in the nasal cavity might spread. The openings (or ostia) to the maxillary sinuses are small and can be easily obstructed when the surrounding nasal mucosa becomes congested. Also, because of the orientation of the maxillary sinuses in the skull, it is difficult for them to drain properly when the head is upright or lying on one side; the ostia are directed towards one another, so when lying on the side, only the top sinus can actually drain.  



Option Analysis

❌ Frontal sinus  :
Incorrect: The frontal sinus is located in the frontal bone and opens into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct. While it is possible for an infection to reach the frontal sinuses, the maxillary sinuses are a more common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Anterior ethmoidal cells:
Incorrect: Anterior ethmoidal cells drain directly or indirectly into the middle nasal meatus through the ethmoidal infundibulum. The anterior ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Middle ethmoidal cells  :
Incorrect: The middle ethmoidal cells open directly into the middle meatus and are called “bullar cells”  because they form the ethmoidal bulla–a swelling over the superior border of the semilunar hiatus. The middle ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Sphenoidal sinus  :
Incorrect: The sphenoid sinus lies inferior to the sella turcica and communicates with the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess. It is an uncommon site of sinus infection.
✅ Maxillary sinus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male infant is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of purulent discharge from both eyes for the past day. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery at home. He has been breastfed exclusively. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral conjunctival injection, purulent discharge from the eyes, and associated edema of the upper and lower eyelids. Which of the following medications is used to prevent this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This neonate, recently born at home, is presenting with purulent eye discharge and bilateral eyelid swelling, consistent with gonococcal conjunctivitis. Application of ophthalmic erythromycin is routinely applied at birth to prevent the development of this condition.  

Neonates are at higher risk of conjunctivitis due to decreased tear production, lack of IgA in tears, poor native immune function, and absence of lymphoid tissue in conjunctiva. Neonatal conjunctivitis, also called ophthalmia neonatorum, typically presents during the first four weeks of life and is usually acquired from the mother (as the patient passes through the birth canal) or following the application of chemical agents.    

The age of the neonate is an important clue towards determining the etiology of neonatal conjunctivitis:  
  •  First 24 hrs of life: Chemical causes from prophylactic medications, such as silver nitrate drops (now rarely used because of the increased risk of chemical conjunctivitis) or erythromycin drops for gonococcal conjunctivitis 
  •  24 - 48 hrs of life: Bacterial causes are most likely (Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause in the time range, Staphylococcus aureus).  
  •  5 - 14 days of life: Chlamydia trachomatis  
  •  6 - 14 days of life: Herpes keratoconjunctivitis  


Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic erythromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous acyclovir:
Incorrect: Intravenous acyclovir is an effective treatment for neonatal herpes simplex infection, which instead presents with excessive watery discharge from the eyes, eye pain, and conjunctival erythema. If untreated, patients can develop irreversible vision impairment or blindness. 
❌ Intravenous ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is an effective treatment for patients with cytomegalovirus (CMV)-induced retinitis. This neonates patient’s presentation, however, is more consistent with bacterial conjunctivitis. 
❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Intravenous ceftriaxone is an appropriate treatment for gonococcal conjunctivitis, but it would not have prevented the condition even if given initially at the time of delivery. 
❌ Ophthalmic levofloxacin :
Incorrect: Ophthalmic levofloxacin is useful in patients presenting with bacterial conjunctivitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Haemophilus influenzae. It is not useful against N. gonorrhoeae, nor is it used prophylactically in the prevention of gonococcal conjunctivitis.
❌ Oral erythromycin :
Incorrect: Oral erythromycin is the preferred treatment for neonatal C. trachomatis infections, including both conjunctivitis and pneumonia. C. trachomatis typically presents 5-14 days after birth with mucopurulent discharge, as opposed to this neonate’s discharge which is purulent. Additionally, oral erythromycin is not used for prophylaxis of gonococcal conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the pediatrician for evaluation of pain in multiple joints. The symptoms began 5 months ago. Joint pain initially started in the right knee but subsequently spread to the elbows and ankles. The symptoms are worse in the morning and improve after 1-2 hours of activity. Over the past several weeks, the patient has had a daily fever and an erythematous macular rash over his chest during the evenings. The patient lives with his parents in rural Maryland. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. Physical examination reveals mild swelling and tenderness to palpation in the bilateral elbows, knees, and ankles. Hyperemia of the uvea and mild pain with extraocular movement is noted in both eyes. Administration of which of the following medications is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has juvenile idiopathic arthritis, which occurs in individuals under the age of 16. The cause is unclear, but it is associated with the haplotype HLA-B21 and triggers such as infections. It is also thought to have an autoimmune basis, wherein immune cells are activated and release proinflammatory cytokines. The condition typically affects large joints (e.g., knee, ankle) and presents with symmetrical joint pain that is worse in the morning and improves with activity.

It can be subdivided into three types: oligoarticular arthritis, polyarticular arthritis, and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. In oligoarticular arthritis, up to 4 joints are affected. In polyarticular arthritis, 5 or more joints are affected. These two types can also be associated with uveitis and enthesitis. Finally, there is systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. It affects not only the joints but the whole body. The condition can cause a salmon pink macular rash, daily spiking fever, pericarditis, and pleuritis.

Laboratory testing will show leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, anemia, and increased levels of ESR and CRP. Treatment involves NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, and disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs). NSAIDs, such as naproxen, are the first-line option.



Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin can be used to treat septic arthritis caused by gram-positive bacteria. However, septic arthritis typically affects a single joint and causes high fevers. It would be atypical for septic arthritis to manifest as symmetrical involvement of multiple joints and a low-grade fever.
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: Prednisolone can be used in the treatment of inflammatory arthritides. This patient’s history of multiple joint involvement, fatigue, and uveitis raise concerns for juvenile idiopathic arthritis. However, prednisolone can have many side effects (e.g., osteoporosis, impaired growth) and is not the first-line treatment option.
✅ Naproxen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline can be used to treat Lyme disease, which can manifest as a migratory arthralgia. The condition typically affects large joints, such as the knee or elbow. However, Lyme disease arthralgia is usually asymmetric and causes marked swelling at the affected joints. Moreover, pain secondary to Lyme disease arthralgia would not improve with activity.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone can be used in the treatment of gonococcal arthritis. The condition typically presents with migratory and asymmetric arthritis. In contrast, this patient has symmetrical arthritis. Moreover, gonococcal infection would not explain the patient’s ocular findings.

questions.text: A newborn boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for cyanosis after being born to a 30-year-old woman via a normal vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation. The mother had poor prenatal care and follow up. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows 80% oxygen saturation on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a hypoplastic mandible, cleft palate, orbital hypertelorism, and bifid uvula. Chest x-ray shows decreased soft tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Echocardiographic findings are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot. A genetic disorder with pure T-cell dysfunction is suspected. Which of the following modalities would be most useful to confirm the genetic abnormality underlying this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with cyanosis at birth, abnormal facies, absence of thymic shadow on chest x-ray, and Tetralogy of Fallot--suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome (DGS). This syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder which results from a microdeletion at chromosome 22q11.2, and it is best diagnosed via fluorescence in situ hybridization.

The diagnosis of DGS is based upon a reduced number of CD3+ T cells in combination with either  characteristic clinical findings or a demonstrated microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. Genetic analysis is normally performed using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), which is more sensitive than the standard karyotyping and can be applied to both dividing (metaphase) and non-dividing cells (interphase). It uses a single-stranded complementary DNA segment tagged with a radiotracer specific for the localization of genes, allowing for direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies at the molecular level. In the case of DGS, FISH would demonstrate absence of fluorescence on the affected chromosome 22q11.2 compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of unaffected chromosome 22.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Karyotyping:
Incorrect: With karyotyping, chromosomes are stained, ordered, and numbered according to morphology, size, arm-length ratio, and banding pattern. It is usually used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances (e.g., autosomal trisomies and sex chromosome disorders). FISH, however, is more reliable for the definitive diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.  
✅ Fluorescence in situ hybridization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Flow cytometry:
Incorrect: Flow cytometry is commonly used for workup of hematologic abnormalities and immunodeficiencies. This technique evaluates surface markers of individual cells, not chromosomal deletions.
❌ Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay:
Incorrect: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is an immunologic test used to identify specific antibodies or antigens in a patient’s blood sample. It cannot detect chromosomal microdeletions.
❌ Western blotting:
Incorrect: Western blotting is a technique that employs proteins in a gel followed by administration of  antibodies to target specific proteins. It is often used to confirm a positive ELISA test for HIV or Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 4430-g (9-lb 10-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 30-year-old woman. The pregnancy was unremarkable, but the second stage of labor was complicated by recurrent late decelerations and required vacuum assistance. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is evaluated 6 hours later for scalp swelling. Temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F), the pulse is 186/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 40/28 mm Hg. The patient appears pale. Physical examination shows a diffuse, fluctuant swelling of the head that extends to the orbital ridges anteriorly, to the nape of the neck posteriorly, and the level of the ears laterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This infant has diffuse scalp swelling that spreads to involve the ears, supraorbital ridge, and nape of the neck along with signs of blood loss (e.g., tachycardia and pallor), findings concerning for a subgaleal hemorrhage.  

Subgaleal hemorrhage results from laceration of one of the emissary veins, with bleeding between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum. While it is most common with operative deliveries, cases with spontaneous vaginal delivery have been described. Physical examination shows diffuse, fluctuant scalp swelling that extends beyond the suture lines and potentially beyond the skull to the neck, orbits, and the temporal fascia. The swelling may shift with movement and expand due to continued bleeding that may last for hours to days after delivery. Bleeding can be catastrophic and result in hypovolemic shock or disseminated intravascular coagulation.  

It should be differentiated from other scalp swelling, including caput succedaneum and cephalhematoma.



Option Analysis

❌ Cephalohematoma:
Incorrect: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood caused by the rupture of vessels beneath the periosteum. It presents within hours of birth with a firm, non-fluctuant mass that does not cross suture lines or spread to the entire skull. It resolves on its own, and the infants are hemodynamically stable. 
✅ Subgaleal hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Epidermoid cyst:
Incorrect: Epidermoid cysts are painless, rubbery masses that move on palpation and commonly occur on the scalp. It does not spread to involve the ears, neck, and orbital ridges. Additionally, they have no association with vacuum-assisted delivery. 
❌ Encephalocele:
Incorrect: An encephalocele lies over a suture line or a fontanelle and presents as a pulsatile mass that increases in size when the infant cries. It does not spread to involve the ears, neck, and orbital ridges. Additionally, they have no association with vacuum-assisted delivery. 
❌ Caput succedaneum:
Incorrect: Caput succedaneum, like subgaleal hemorrhage, is not limited by suture lines and typically presents as diffuse swelling at birth. However, it self-resolves within a few hours in contrast to the spread of this infant’s hemorrhage to involve the ears, supraorbital ridge, and nape of the neck. Moreover, infants with caput succedaneum are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental delay and poor performance in school. She recently received a prescription for glasses due to an inability to see the blackboard. She is currently in special education classes for learning disabilities. The family immigrated from Ethiopia 2 years ago. A review of her development reveals delayed attainment of milestones. Her weight at the 50th percentile for her age, while her height is at the 90th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the patient reveals a tall, thin habitus with elongated limbs. Ophthalmic examination reveals bilateral inferior lens dislocations. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Urine cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Supplementation of which of the following vitamins is likely to improve this patient’s clinical outcome?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with developmental delay, marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test. This presentation is suggestive of a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

Homocystine is an intermediary amino acid formed from the metabolism of methionine to cysteine. Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive condition that results in elevated levels of homocysteine in plasma and urine due to imparied methionine metabolism. It can be classified into familial or acquired forms of the disease. Familial homocystinuria can result from cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency, methionine synthase deficiency, or decreased affinity of pyridoxal phosphate to cystathionine synthase.






The presenting symptom in most adolescents and children is developmental delay. Other clinical manifestations include marfanoid features, lens dislocation (downward and inward), osteoporosis, kyphosis, and premature atherosclerosis. Complications include thrombotic events such as transient ischemic attacks, stroke, angina and myocardial infarctions, and venous thromboembolic events.







Diagnosis is made by detecting elevated homocysteine levels in blood and urine and a positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test that detects amino acids containing sulfur.  Treatment of homocystinuria varies depending on the underlying biochemical defect and the severity of the defect. Supplementation of folate, cobalamin (vitamin B12), and pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is sufficient to lower homocysteine levels in most patients.

Option Analysis

✅ Cobalamin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect:  Thiamine is supplemented in the treatment of maple syrup urine disease, as it serves as a cofactor for the deficient enzyme branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase. It classically presents with severe neurological deterioration, dystonia, and developmental delay. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Riboflavin:
Incorrect: Riboflavin deficiency manifests with cheilosis, corneal vascularisation, and stomatitis. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Ascorbic acid:
Incorrect: Scurvy is characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, and subperiosteal hemorrhages and is treated with vitamin C (ascorbic acid) supplementation. Absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tetrahydrobiopterin:
Incorrect: Malignant phenylketonuria results from a deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin and clinically manifests with symptoms of neurologic deterioration and hypopigmentation. BH4 supplementation is advised in malignant phenylketonuria. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 2-day old neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born to a 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 34 weeks gestation. After multiple hours of active labor, the fetus developed bradycardia, and the decision was made to proceed with operative vaginal delivery using forceps. The mother has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the neonate shows asymmetry of the face upon crying, with incomplete closure of the left eye. Upon feeding, he starts drooling from the left side of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this neonate’s examination findings?
questions.solution:
This neonate with facial asymmetry and drooling from one side of the mouth has likely suffered trauma to the facial nerve during forceps-assisted delivery, leading to paralysis of the facial muscles.

Congenital traumatic facial nerve paralysis is the loss of controllable (voluntary) muscle movement in an infant's face due to pressure on the facial nerve just before or at the time of birth. Risk factors include primiparity, birth weight > 3.5 kilograms, prolonged labor, and forceps-assisted delivery. Patients usually present with asymmetric facial expressions, difficulty feeding, and incomplete eye closure. Associated findings include ecchymosis, hemotympanum, facial swelling, and head molding. Traumatic congenital facial nerve paralysis usually resolves spontaneously and does not require intervention. If the patient’s eye does not close all the way, an eye pad and eye drops are used to prevent corneal damage.

There is no guaranteed way to prevent pressure injuries during vaginal delivery. The proper use of forceps and improved childbirth methods have reduced the rate of congenital traumatic facial nerve palsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Trauma during forceps delivery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Viral-associated ischemic demyelination:
Incorrect: Viral-associated ischemic demyelination is one of the described etiologies of Bell palsy. Incidence in the neonatal population is negligible. Common pathogens include herpes simplex virus, Epstein Barr virus, etc.
❌ Preterm birth:
Incorrect: Preterm birth has been associated with hypothermia, patent ductus arteriosus, respiratory distress syndrome, glucose abnormalities, necrotizing enterocolitis, and intraventricular hemorrhage. It is not associated with neonatal mononeuropathy.
❌ Maternal hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Untreated maternal hypothyroidism has been associated with preeclampsia, placental abruption, preterm delivery, postpartum hemorrhage, and cognitive impairment in the child. It is not associated with neonatal mononeuropathy.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of the entire left side of the face, making UMN lesion less likely.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents to the primary care physician with recurrent epistaxis. She reports persistent, intermittent nosebleeds that take greater than one hour to achieve hemostasis. The patient’s mother, who is also present during the visit, reports similar symptoms in her own youth. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Platelet count is normal, and a ristocetin cofactor assay does not demonstrate platelet aggregation. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication used to treat this condition?

choices.text: Releases von Willebrand factor from endothelium
Binds to the glycoprotein receptor IIb/IIIa on activated platelets
Increases the synthesis of hemoglobin F

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent mucosal bleeding, indicative of a primary hemostatic disease. The platelet count is normal, and the ristocetin cofactor assay does not demonstrate platelet aggregation. Additionally, she has a first degree relative with a history of mucosal bleeding. Together, these findings are consistent with von Willebrand disease (vWD), the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Treatment for this disease involves administration of DDAVP or desmopressin, which works by releasing vWF from the vascular endothelium. 

vWD is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, so at least one first degree relative is affected as well. The disease is caused by a quantitative or qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF), which acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and the GpIb receptor found on the platelet surface. The disease is divided into three subtypes: type I is the most common and is associated with a decrease in vWF, whereas type II has dysfunctional vWF, and type III with no detectable vWF.  

With decreased amounts, defective, or complete loss of vWF, platelet plug formation is impaired. This manifests as mucosal bleeding, easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding, and prolonged bleeding following dental extractions. Diagnosis relies on family history and laboratory findings that typically show a normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, and normal to slightly increased PTT since vWF carries and protects factor VIII. Additionally, no platelet aggregation will occur with the ristocetin cofactor assay. This test assesses the ability of the patient’s vWF to bind GPIb, collagen, and factor VIII using the antibiotic ristocetin, which promotes platelet aggregation.  


 

Option Analysis

✅ Releases von Willebrand factor from endothelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increases coagulation factor levels :
Incorrect: Administration of treatments such as fresh frozen plasma or cryoprecipitate are rarely indicated in von Willebrand disease. They are reserved for patients with severe bleeding refractory to desmopressin therapy. 
❌ Increases platelet cAMP levels:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of phosphodiesterase inhibitors, including cilostazol and dipyridamole, which are more commonly used to prevent further platelet aggregation. These medications can be used to treat patients experiencing intermittent claudication. 
❌ Binds to the glycoprotein receptor IIb/IIIa on activated platelets :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of glycoprotein receptor IIb/IIIa inhibitors, such as abciximab and tirofiban. These medications are used to help prevent, rather than promote, platelet aggregation. 
❌ Increases the synthesis of hemoglobin F:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea can be administered to increase hemoglobin F synthesis. The medication is used in the treatment of sickle cell disease.

questions.text:
A 5-hour-old male neonate is noted to have a large cephalohematoma after a vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. The birth was otherwise uncomplicated, and the mother has no medical problems. The patient's family history is notable for an uncle who had severe joint deformities. Laboratory testing is obtained and reveals the following findings:  

Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Hydrolyzes factor X to form factor Xa
Assists factor IXa in converting factor X to factor Xa
Promotes endothelial release of von Willebrand factor
Activates factor IX by selectively cleaving peptide bonds

questions.solution:
This male neonate presents with a large cephalohematoma after vacuum-assisted extraction. The laboratory testing reveals a prolonged PTT and low factor IX level, which is concerning for hemophilia B. The condition is treated with recombinant factor IX.

Hemophilia B is an X-linked recessive disease, so patients may have a history of a maternal family member with a bleeding disorder (e.g. joint deformities from recurrent hemarthrosis). The disease is caused by a deficiency in factor IX, a coagulation factor involved in the intrinsic pathway of secondary hemostasis. Deficiency of factor IX results in impaired hydrolysis of factor X to form factor Xa, causing prolongation of the PTT.    

Hemophilia A and B are clinically indistinguishable and present with symptoms including hemarthrosis, deep soft tissue hematomas, prolonged bleeding after procedures, and intracerebral hemorrhage. Most patients with hemophilia present in early infancy or childhood. If left untreated, recurrent hemarthrosis can cause chronic joint pain and deformity, and intracerebral hemorrhage can cause chronic neurologic disorders or death.    

Diagnosis of hemophilia B is performed by obtaining coagulation parameters and performing a mixing study. In a mixing study, the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma, which will demonstrate a correction of PTT since factor IX is now present. Treatment involves replacement with recombinant factor IX.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hydrolyzes factor X to form factor Xa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Assists factor IXa in converting factor X to factor Xa:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of factor VIII, which is deficient in hemophilia A. Recombinant factor VIII is administered along with desmopressin to treat patients with hemophilia A. However, this patient has a normal factor VIII level but reduced factor IX level, making another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Promotes endothelial release of von Willebrand factor:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of desmopressin. The medication is used in the treatment of von Willebrand disease and hemophilia A, since von Willebrand factor helps to stabilize and carry factor VIII. However, desmopressin would not be useful in treating this patient’s hemophilia B. 
❌ Activates factor IX by selectively cleaving peptide bonds:
Incorrect: Hemophilia C is caused by a deficiency of factor XI and is treated with recombinant forms of this clotting factor. Unlike hemophilia A and B, patients with hemophilia C do not have spontaneous bleeding, hemarthrosis (joint bleeding), or muscle hematomas. Patients typically bleed only after major surgeries or trauma. This patient’s reduced factor IX level makes another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Removes autoantibodies from bloodstream:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is used in the treatment of immune-mediated conditions ranging from autoimmune hemolytic anemia to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. However, this patient has reduced factor IX levels, which is concerning for hemophilia B. Plasmapheresis is not used in the treatment of hemophilia B.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered at term to a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The midwife noticed a swelling on the presenting part of the infant’s head during the delivery. The second stage of labor was prolonged and required vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. Examination of the neonate following birth shows a soft, boggy scalp swelling that crosses the suture lines. The overlying skin is normal, with no apparent tenderness or discoloration. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. The spine is normal. Serum bilirubin levels are within normal limits. Which of the following best describes this infant’s scalp swelling prognosis?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with scalp swelling at birth after a prolonged vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery, suggestive of caput succedaneum. Shearing forces often cause soft tissue injuries in infants’ scalps during vacuum or forceps delivery.    

Caput succedaneum results from subcutaneous edema over the presenting part of the head owing to pressure against the cervix during the prolonged engagement of the fetal head in the birth canal or after vacuum extraction. It is a common occurrence in newborns. Caput succedaneum is soft to palpation with ill-defined borders as it crosses the suture lines. The caput is maximal at birth, rapidly grows smaller, and usually disappears within hours or a few days. Occasionally it becomes infected, and an abscess may form. Petechiae and ecchymosis also may be noted.    

It should be differentiated from other scalp swelling, including cephalhematoma and subgaleal hemorrhage.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Can cause life-threatening blood loss:
Incorrect: Subgaleal hemorrhage develops when blood accumulates in the loose areolar tissue in the space between the periosteum of the skull and the aponeurosis. In contrast to caput succedaneum, the swelling is diffuse, progressive, fluctuant, and involves scalp and neck swelling. It can cause life-threatening blood loss, and infants can become hemodynamically unstable. 
✅ Self-resolves in days:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Calcification of the hematoma:
Incorrect: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood caused by the rupture of vessels beneath the periosteum. In contrast to caput succedaneum, cephalohematoma may not be apparent until hours after delivery and presents with a firm, non-fluctuant mass that does not cross suture lines. Most cases require no treatment, and rarely, calcification of the hematoma can occur with a subsequent bony swelling that may persist for months. 
❌ May cause brainstem compression:
Incorrect: Subdural hemorrhage in the posterior fossa, an area of the brain with less skull plasticity, may cause brainstem compression. A subdural hematoma is rare in infants and presents in symptomatic infants usually within the first 24 to 48 hours of life with seizures, respiratory depression, and apnea. It is an intracranial hemorrhage and does not appear as localized scalp swelling. 
❌ May cause post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Large subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can cause post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus. It is an intracranial hemorrhage and does not appear as localized scalp swelling. Newborns with SAH most often present at 24 to 48 hours of life with apnea, respiratory depression, and seizures.

questions.text: A 2-day-old boy is being evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born at 40 weeks gestation to a primigravid mother who received consistent prenatal care. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and the patient is currently being breastfed. Length and weight are at the 35th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits for age. Physical examination demonstrates a newborn sleeping comfortably. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Genitourinary examination demonstrates a circumcised penis of normal size. The right testis is located within the inguinal canal, and the left testis is palpable in the scrotum. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this neonate?

choices.text: Reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent

questions.solution:
Cryptorchidism is a common congenital condition characterized by incomplete/partial descent of the testis into the scrotum. Approximately 80% of cryptorchid testes descend by the third month of life, and therefore, reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent is appropriate.

Orchiopexy is necessary after four months of persistent cryptorchidism to avoid the complications as documented below:

  •  Testicular torsion: when malpositioned in the inguinal canal, the unfixed testis becomes prone to mobility, blunt trauma, and in particular, testicular torsion. 
 
  •  Testicular cancer: studies suggest the elevated temperature of the abdominal cavity promotes malignant transformation. Another theory postulates an underlying hormonal condition that predisposes some males to both cryptorchidism and testicular cancer. 
 
  •  Subfertility/infertility: Males with a history of undescended testes are at increased risk of low sperm counts, poorer quality sperm, and lower fertility rates than males with normally descended testes. This decreased fertility occurs secondary to increased temperatures in the abdomen and inguinal canal, which impairs spermatogenesis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent surgical correction:
Incorrect: Orchiopexy is a surgical procedure to reposition undescended or ectopic testes. Surgery is recommended after four months of age for congenitally undescended testes.
❌ Pediatric urology referral:
Incorrect: Indications for referral to a pediatric urologist include undescended testis (unilateral or bilateral) between 4 and 12 months of age, as well as for difficulty differentiating between undescended, retractile, or ectopic testis.
❌ Karyotype analysis:
Incorrect: Bilateral non palpable testes in a newborn male requires immediate evaluation at the time of birth. Karyotype analysis is helpful in differentiating a virilized genotypic female from an undervirilized genotypic male. This patient has unilateral cryptorchidism.
❌ Electrolyte monitoring:
Incorrect: Bilateral nonpalpable testes in a newborn male requires immediate evaluation at the time of birth, because the differential diagnosis includes developmental sex disorders, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). CAH requires electrolyte monitoring due to salt wasting, which can lead to a potentially fatal adrenal crisis in neonates.This patient has unilateral cryptorchidism.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right middle finger pain. Several days ago, the patient noticed small fluid-filled sacs in the right middle finger, which progressed into painful lesions yesterday. His mother, who is accompanying him, states, “He has got a finger infection from chewing on his nails all day.” The patient is otherwise healthy and takes only a multivitamin daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has multiple vesicular lesions on his finger, which is concerning for herpetic whitlow, or herpes simplex infection of the finger. Herpetic whitlow occurs frequently in patients with recurrent nail biting, children who suck their fingers, and those who work in healthcare or dentistry. This condition is best treated with oral acyclovir.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a double stranded-DNA virus that causes a characteristic pattern of skin involvement. Patients develop clear vesicles that overtime merge, become cloudy, and eventually burst leaving behind painful ulcerations. In general, HSV-1 is the viral strain implicated in herpes labialis (cold sores), herpetic whitlow, and erythema multiforme, whereas HSV-2 is more commonly implicated in herpes genitalis. Transmission typically occurs via oral-oral, oral-genital, or genital-genital contact. However, it can also occur via contamination of skin abrasions with infected oral secretions.

Regardless of the viral strain involved, recurrent dermatologic lesions are commonplace due to the virus’s ability to lie dormant in the dorsal root ganglion. During acute infection, the virus is able to enter sensory nerve endings and travel via retrograde transport to the dorsal root ganglion. During episodes of reactivation, the virus replicates and travels via anterograde axonal transport to epithelial cells, thus causing recurrent symptoms.

Option Analysis

✅ Acyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a second generation cephalosporin used for a variety of treatments including skin and soft tissue infections, urinary tract infections, and pharyngitis. However, cephalexin lacks antiviral properties and is not used in the treatment of herpetic whitlow.
❌ Ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is used in the treatment of cytomegalovirus infection, but not herpes simplex viral infections.
❌ Needle aspiration:
Incorrect: This patient has multiple vesicular rashes on his finger, which is concerning for herpetic whitlow. Needle aspiration, along with incision and drainage, are inappropriate for the treatment of herpetic whitlow. These interventions may actually result in disseminated HSV.
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Simple incision and drainage is performed for skin abscesses or paronychia but not for herpetic whitlow. Incision and drainage can actually increase the risk of disseminated HSV.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the office for his first postnatal visit. The patient was born at 34 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old via normal vaginal delivery. The patient’s parent otherwise had an uncomplicated pregnancy and took prenatal vitamins regularly. The patient currently breastfeeds every 2-3 hours with adequate elimination. Height, weight, and head circumference are at the 50th percentile, adjusted for the gestational age. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an open, soft, and flat anterior fontanelle. Red reflex is present bilaterally. Abdomen is soft and nontender. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Genitourinary examination shows a palpable right testis in the scrotum and a poorly rugated hypoplastic left scrotum. The left testis is palpable in the inguinal area. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Advise the parents that the testes will descend after 2 years of age
Start hormonal treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone

questions.solution:
This infant has a normally palpable right testis in the right scrotum and a poorly rugated left scrotum with the left testis palpable in the inguinal area. The abnormal or partial descent of unilateral/bilateral testes is known as cryptorchidism.   

The testes develop in the abdominal cavity during the first trimester and normally begin to descend into the scrotum (via the inguinal canal) guided by the gubernaculum during the third trimester of pregnancy.  



Cryptorchidism is the most common birth defect of the male genitalia. Most cryptorchid testes are undescended but some may be absent or atrophied. Risk factors include prematurity, low birth weight (<2.5 kg), or small for gestational age. The cryptorchid testes usually descend by the age of 6 months (therefore, this infant should be monitored for this duration). Surgical correction by orchiopexy (pinning of the testes) should be done ideally before 1 year of age if the testes fail to descend by 4-6 months. Untreated cases are at increased risk of impaired spermatogenesis (infertility), seminoma, and testicular torsion. Serum inhibin B levels are decreased, while FSH and LH levels are increased. Serum testosterone is decreased in bilateral cryptorchidism but normal in the unilateral variant.  

Option Analysis

❌ Immediate surgical correction by orchiopexy:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical correction is not appropriate at this age as most testes descend spontaneously by the age of 6 months. Therefore, the patient should be closely monitored for this duration.
❌ Advise the parents that the testes will descend after 2 years of age:
Incorrect: Most of the testes that have not descended by the age of 6 months are unlikely to descend spontaneously and require surgical correction by orchiopexy before the age of 2 years (ideally 1 year).
❌ Start hormonal treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone:
Incorrect: The use of hormonal treatment for the descent of testes is controversial, and it is not indicated at this time in this patient.
✅ Monitor for spontaneous descent:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform a scrotal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Imaging, such as an ultrasound, is not routinely indicated for the identification of a nonpalpable testis as it does not alter the need for surgical correction. It can be used in patients with evidence of other gonadal abnormalities, such as gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass. She first noticed the mass five weeks ago, following an upper respiratory infection. She has not experienced any dyspnea or dysphagia. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 109/72 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. On physical examination, a midline mass is observed over the anterior neck around 1 centimeter below the hyoid bone. The mass is soft and nontender to palpation. The mass moves when the patient swallows. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct
Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless, midline neck mass that moves with swallowing. These findings suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst, an embryologic remnant that forms when the thyroglossal duct fails to close after birth.  

During embryological development, the thyroid gland originates in the floor of the embryonic pharynx in an area called the foramen cecum, found on the dorsum of the tongue. The thyroid gland subsequently migrates from the tongue into the neck, passing anterior to the hyoid bone through the thyroglossal duct. This duct normally disappears after birth; however, in some cases, part of this duct remains, and a thyroglossal duct cyst can develop.  

Thyroglossal duct cysts are typically located along the anterior midline portion of the neck. They can form a visual and palpable mass. The cysts move with swallowing or tongue movement, which can help distinguish them from other neck masses (e.g. malignant tumors). Most cases are asymptomatic, but some can cause neck pain or dysphagia if they grow large or become infected. In rare cases, a thyroglossal duct cyst carcinoma can develop from ectopic thyroid tissue within the cyst. Other complications may include infections, rupture, and formation of a thyroglossal fistula.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatous thyroid gland inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also called de Quervain thyroiditis. The condition typically presents as a painful swelling of the thyroid gland following an upper respiratory infection. In contrast, this patient’s mass is painless.
✅ Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Outpouching of the cervical esophagus:
Incorrect: A Zenker diverticulum is characterized by outpouching of the esophageal mucosa through an area of muscle weakness in the posterior esophageal wall. The condition most commonly develops at Killian’s triangle and involves the cervical esophagus. The condition can present with dysphagia, regurgitation, cough, aspiration, and foul-smelling breath. However, it would not typically present as an anterior neck mass.
❌ Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a branchial cleft cyst. The condition typically presents as a nontender, lateral neck mass. In contrast, this patient has a midline neck mass that moves when she swallows, suggesting a thyroglossal duct cyst.  
❌ Malignant proliferation of thyrocytes:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancer is characterized by malignant proliferation of thyroid gland tissue. The condition presents as a firm and usually painless nodule. If the cancer invades surrounding tissue, the tumor can remain fixed and will not move with swallowing or tongue movements. In contrast, this patient has a soft and mobile neck mass, which suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician to evaluate recurrent ear infections and sinusitis. The parent states, “He always seems to be sick with something. Every week, he is coughing or tugging on his ear. His nose runs constantly.” The patient was born full-term without complications during pregnancy or delivery. He has no other medical problems and does not take any medications daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear nasal secretions and hyperemia of the nasal mucosa bilaterally. After appropriate work-up and first-line medication trials, a nasal mucosa biopsy is performed and sent for transmission electron microscopy. Upon analysis of the specimen, the patient is found to have an absence of dynein arms on microtubule assemblies. Which of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be present given this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Apex of the heart located in the right chest
Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum

questions.solution:
This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia (sometimes known as Karatagener syndrome), which arises due to defective dynein arms of the microtubule, resulting in impaired ciliary function. Ciliary dysfunction manifests as recurrent sinopulmonary infections, infertility (secondary to immotile sperm or immotile fallopian cilia), and bronchiectasis. This condition is highly associated with situs inversus, an embryological folding defect in which the thoracic and abdominal viscera are transposed across the midline (including the heart, a phenomenon termed dextrocardia).  

Patients with dextrocardia (whether in isolation or in association with situs inversus) will often have a palpable apex heartbeat over the right chest. On screening electrocardiogram, patients will have evidence of right axis deviation, inversion of all complexes in lead I, upright p waves in AVL, and an absent R wave progression in the anterior leads. A chest x-ray will demonstrate the apex of the heart in the right chest.  

It should be noted that when the condition occurs in isolation, dextrocardia is often associated with additional, more severe cardiac anomalies as compared to situs inversus, which is typically benign and often diagnosed incidentally.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Apex of the heart located in the right chest :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle :
Incorrect: Ebstein anomaly is caused by in utero exposure to lithium. This condition is also associated with tricuspid regurgitation and isolated right heart failure. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes Tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cause of early childhood cyanosis. This condition more commonly presents with tet-spells–episodes of cyanosis on exertion resulting from right to left shunting. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Transpositioned aorta and pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels is a rare congenital cardiac defect that results in death within the first few months of life if untreated. It is not associated with ciliary dysfunction or upper respiratory infections. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Tricuspid atresia :
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of a tricuspid valve, with a subsequently hypoplastic right ventricle. This condition requires both a ventricular septal and atrial septal defect for survival. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.

questions.text: A 48-hour-old male neonate is under evaluation in the neonatal ICU for an episode of a seizure. Since starting breastfeeding, he has been irritable, has been feeding poorly, and has had several episodes of vomiting. He was born at 40 weeks gestation to a 35-year-old woman following an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 145/min, and respiratory rate is 34/min. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Neurological examination reveals intermittent cycling movements in his lower extremities.   Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated serum levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Supplementation of which of the following could be considered in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Elevated serum levels of branched-chain amino acids, along with symptoms of neurologic deterioration, is suggestive of a diagnosis of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).



MSUD is caused by an inability to break down branched-chain amino acids, including leucine, isoleucine and valine, due to branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency. During the catabolism of these branched-chain amino acids, metabolites are formed which are then metabolized by branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase, generating products that eventually enter the Krebs cycle, ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis. Decarboxylation of these alpha-keto acids is mediated by thiamine pyrophosphate, a cofactor containing thiamine (vitamin B1).



The clinical manifestations of MSUD result from the accumulation of these branched-chain amino acids in the CNS, liver, and skeletal muscle. Metabolic products of leucine interfere with the transport of other amino acids across the blood brain barrier, particularly those involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and dopamine. The presence of a derivative of leucine, alloisoleucine, contributes to the sweet maple syrup odor of urine in these patients. Classic MSUD is the most common form of the disorder and presents in the early neonatal period with irritability, dystonia, vomiting, poor feeding and detection of ketonuria.

Diagnosis is made by detecting branched-chain amino acids in the analysis of serum samples and urine. Treatment is directed at restricting dietary intake of branched-amino acids and thiamine supplementation. Hemodialysis may be used in severe cases.

Option Analysis

✅ Thiamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vitamin B12:
Incorrect: Cobalamin deficiency is characterized by macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia and neurologic findings which include subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and peripheral neuropathy. Vitamin B12 deficiency may cause elevated levels of homocysteine, but it would not result in elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine and valine.
❌ Pyridoxine:
Incorrect: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is advised with administration of isoniazid to prevent peripheral neuropathy. There is no indication for pyridoxine in this patient. 
❌ Tetrahydrobiopterin:
Incorrect: Malignant phenylketonuria results from a deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) and clinically manifests with symptoms of neurologic deterioration and hypopigmentation. BH4 supplementation is advised in malignant phenylketonuria. However, PKU results in elevated phenylalanine levels in serum, not branched-chain amino acids (e.g., leucine, valine, isoleucine).
❌ Arginine:
Incorrect: Urea cycle disorders respond to arginine supplementation, as it promotes disposal of nitrogenous wastes. Urea cycle disorders do not lead to elevated levels of branched-chain amino acids.

questions.text: A 4430-g (9-lb 10-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The second stage of labor was prolonged and required vacuum assistance.  Apgar scores are 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination of the neonate 2 hours later shows a soft, non-pulsatile swelling over the left parietal bone with no apparent tenderness or discoloration. The swelling does not cross suture lines. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. The spine is normal. Ultrasound shows no skull fracture. This infant’s scalp swelling affects which of the following spaces or potential spaces?
questions.solution:
This infant’s scalp mass is located beneath the periosteum and is limited by suture lines. Bleeding between the periosteum and skull is described as a cephalhematoma.  

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood caused by the rupture of vessels beneath the periosteum (usually over the parietal or occipital bone). It occurs in 1–2% of live births and presents as a palpable, soft, nontender mass that develops slowly over several hours after birth. As it occurs in the subperiosteal plane, a cephalohematoma is limited by suture lines to the surface of one cranial bone. Forceps delivery and vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery (ventouse) are risk factors. Cephalohematomas usually require no treatment because the hematoma is reabsorbed within a few weeks. Acute complications include hyperbilirubinemia due to erythrocyte breakdown and sometimes infection. Rarely, calcification of the hematoma can occur with a subsequent bony swelling that may persist for months.  

It should be differentiated from other scalp swelling, including caput succedaneum and subgaleal hemorrhage.



Option Analysis

✅ Between periosteum and skull:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Between periosteum and galea aponeurosis:
Incorrect: Subgaleal hemorrhage results from bleeding from emissary veins in the loose areolar tissue between the periosteum and the galea aponeurosis. It can occur in neonates during birth. In contrast to cephalhematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage presents as a diffuse, progressive, fluctuant scalp and neck swelling that can cross suture lines and canvas the entire skull.  
❌ Between skull and dura mater:
Incorrect: Bleeding between the skull and dura mater describes an epidural hematoma. An epidural hematoma presents as a brief loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and then progressive confusion or somnolence. It is infrequent in neonates and is often accompanied by a linear skull fracture usually located in the parietotemporal area. 
❌ Between dura and arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: Bleeding between the dura and arachnoid mater describes a subdural hematoma. It is an intracranial hemorrhage and does not appear as localized scalp swelling. A subdural hematoma is rare in infants and presents in symptomatic infants usually within the first 24 to 48 hours of life with seizures, respiratory depression, and apnea. 
❌ Between arachnoid and pia mater:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is caused by rupture of bridging veins in the subarachnoid space (between arachnoid and pia mater). It is an intracranial hemorrhage and does not appear as localized scalp swelling. Newborns with SAH most often present at 24 to 48 hours of life with apnea, respiratory depression, and seizures.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant boy is evaluated for the first time since delivery. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery and had a normal prenatal and postnatal birth history. He feeds 2-3 oz of breastmilk and formula every 2-3 hours. He is in the 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for height, 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight, and 50<sup>th</sup> percentile for head circumference. On physical examination, there is prominent head posturing. The head is tilted to the right side, and the chin is rotated to the left shoulder. A mass is palpable in the inferior portion of the neck on the right side. The mass is firm and does not transilluminate with a penlight. The rest of the physical examination, including the reflexes and muscular tone of the extremities, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Torticollis results from a contraction or shortening of the neck muscles, such as the sternocleidomastoid or trapezius muscle. This condition typically presents with the head tilted towards the affected side and the chin rotated away from the affected side, limiting the neck’s range of motion. This posturing is because the condition mimics the action of the sternocleidomastoid, which functions to flex the head toward the side of contraction (in this case, the right) and laterally rotate the head or chin away from the side of the contraction (in this case, the left).  

Torticollis can be congenital or acquired, as described below: 
  •  Congenital torticollis is the most common type of torticollis. This postural deformity of the neck develops prenatally and is most often caused by the development of a fibrous tissue tumor in the sternocleidomastoid muscle and less often by neurological or bony abnormalities.  
  •  There is also congenital muscular torticollis, a postural deformity that is typically evident 2-4 weeks after delivery and often occurs during delivery when there is tearing of the muscle fibers of the baby's neck, resulting in subsequent fibrosis and shortening of the neck muscles.   
  •  Acquired torticollis typically appears after delivery and can be caused by various conditions that cause injury or inflammation to the muscles of the neck. These can range from trauma to infection or neurological disorders. Acquired torticollis typically occurs in children but can occur in adults as well.  
Adults usually acquire a type of torticollis referred to as spasmodic torticollis, or cervical dystonia, resulting from strenuous movement or awkward positioning for too long. Spasmodic torticollis is a chronic and painful condition characterized by involuntary contraction of the neck muscles, leading to involuntary tilting, turning, flexing, or extending the neck. In most cases, the cause of spasmodic torticollis is unknown, but more serious causes include cervical spine injuries, such as fractures and subluxations.  



Option Analysis

❌ Clavicle fracture:
Incorrect: Clinical findings of a clavicle fracture include asymmetric contour, crepitus, edema, decreased or absent movement of the arm on the affected side, and crying with passive movement of the arm on the affected side. This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Vertebral anomaly:
Incorrect: Although a radiograph was not performed on this patient, the clinical symptoms suggest congenital muscular torticollis, not a vertebral anomaly.  
❌ Central nervous system lesion:
Incorrect: Central nervous system (CNS) lesions may also cause a head tilt in young infants. However, infants with CNS lesions usually have abnormal neurologic findings (e.g., cranial nerve palsy, recurrent vomiting). This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Lymphangioma:
Incorrect: Lymphangioma (previously known as a cystic hygroma) is another cause of a neck mass in a young infant. In contrast to this sternocleidomastoid mass of congenital muscular torticollis, which is firm and does not transilluminate, cystic hygromas are soft and do transilluminate.  
✅ Congenital muscular torticollis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old Caucasian infant is brought to the pediatrician’s office by his parents for evaluation of failure to thrive and persistent frothy stools. He was born at term with no antenatal or delivery problems. His parents and older brother are all healthy. The patient is below the 10th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination reveals that the patient has difficulty with balance and poor muscle coordination. In addition, the patient is found to have normal central vision but impaired peripheral vision. A peripheral smear is obtained, and the results are as follows:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate high-dose supplementation to prevent further neurologic deterioration in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has abetalipoproteinemia, an autosomal recessive condition characterized by a deficiency of both apolipoprotein B-48 and B-100 secondary to a MTTP gene mutation. Both of these proteins are necessary for normal fat absorption and chylomicron formation. As a result, patients with the condition have fat malabsorption and a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.  

Symptoms manifest shortly after birth. Patients present with failure to thrive, muscle weakness, and steatorrhea. Absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) are also affected. Vitamin A deficiency can contribute to the development of retinitis pigmentosa. Persistent deficiency of vitamin E, a crucial substance for myelin formation and antioxidant properties, contributes to the development of spinocerebellar degeneration. Vitamin D deficiency can cause osteomalacia.  

Laboratory testing will reveal low serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Blood smears will reveal acanthocytes, abnormal red blood cells with a spiked membrane. Colonoscopy will show lipid-laden enterocytes. Genetic testing will confirm the presence of a MTTP gene mutation.  

Treatment is initiation of high-dose vitamin E supplementation and restriction of long-chain fatty acids;  limiting dietary fat reduces steatorrhea and facilitates absorption of other essential nutrients required for maintaining growth and development.  


Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium:
Incorrect: Magnesium is required for N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors, which prompt a calcium influx after stimulation with excitatory amino acids, such as glutamate. While hypomagnesemia may lead to severe neurological sequelae, it is not precipitated by fat malabsorption.  
❌ Omega-3 fatty acid  :
Incorrect: Long-chain fatty acids, such as omega-3, require ApoB-containing lipoproteins in order to be transported through the blood. In addition to nutritional supplementation, treatment of abetalipoproteinemia requires restriction of omega-3 fatty acid (and other long-chain fatty acids) since it can exacerbate steatorrhea and malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.   
❌ Vitamin A:
Incorrect: Vitamin A is required for the production of rhodopsin, a light-absorbing molecule. Rhodopsin is necessary for vision in low-light environments. Vitamin A is often malabsorbed in patients with abetalipoproteinemia and can cause visual deficits. However, vitamin A deficiency is not associated with neurological dysfunction.  
✅ Vitamin E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zinc:
Incorrect: Zinc is a cofactor for many of the body’s important enzymes. It is required for wound healing, connective tissue maintenance, and adequate growth. However, mineral absorption is typically not affected in patients with fat malabsorption.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female neonate is evaluated in the nursery for a heart murmur. She was born at 36-weeks gestational age to a 27-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Family history is notable for atrial fibrillation in her father. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic machine-like murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. An echocardiogram is performed which confirms the patient’s diagnosis. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This preterm neonate with a holosystolic machine-like murmur in the left infraclavicular area most likely has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. Preterm babies are at increased risk of having a PDA. Other risk factors include congenital rubella syndrome and chromosomal abnormalities.  

The condition presents with a continuous machine-like murmur most prominent at the left infraclavicular area. In addition, patients can develop differential cyanosis, wherein the lower extremities are cyanotic, but the upper extremities are acyanotic. Echocardiogram is performed to confirm the presence of clinically significant PDA.  

Indomethacin, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication, blocks the synthesis of prostaglandin E and is used to close the PDA. If this fails, surgical intervention is needed. In contrast, prostaglandin E can be used to keep the ductus arteriosus open. 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of prostaglandin E :
Incorrect: Prostaglandin E is used to keep ductus arteriosus open. This treatment is necessary in certain patients, such as those with transposition of the great vessels, who need the shunt to survive. However, this patient most likely has an isolated PDA (given the echocardiogram confirmation), and medications should be administered to close the defect. 
❌ Referral for surgical intervention :
Incorrect: Surgical ligation is not the first-line treatment in patients with a PDA because surgical intervention can cause potential complications including infection, hemodynamic instability, and respiratory compromise. Surgery is generally reserved for patients who have failed medical management. 
✅ Administration of indomethacin :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Order chest radiograph :
Incorrect: This patient has a patent ductus arteriosus. Her condition has already been confirmed by echocardiography. A chest radiograph is less sensitive and specific. Hence, it would not provide additional information about the patient’s condition. 
❌ Administration of propranolol :
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used to manage patients with atrial fibrillation. This patient has a family history of atrial fibrillation. However, the physical examination finding of a machine-like murmur is more consistent with the diagnosis of PDA.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to recurrent episodes of dyspnea and wheezing over the past several weeks. The patient came to the clinic 3 months ago and was diagnosed with intermittent asthma. He was prescribed an albuterol inhaler and instructed to use it as needed. The patient’s parent states the patient uses the inhaler several times per day and has found mild relief. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is resting comfortably. Physical examination reveals scattered wheezes on chest auscultation. Which of the following drugs should be added to this patient’s treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient has frequent asthma exacerbations despite being on a short-acting bronchodilator. The next step in management would be to start an inhaled corticosteroid.  

While there is no cure for asthma, there are treatments to help manage the symptoms and prevent future asthma attacks. In acute exacerbations, a short acting bronchodilator, such as albuterol, is often administered through an emergency inhaler. As a beta-2 agonist, albuterol causes smooth muscles in the bronchioles to relax, resulting in airway dilation.  

In patients with chronic asthma, inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, budesonide) are the first-line treatment option. Corticosteroids inhibit cytokine synthesis, which in turn prevents airway hyperresponsiveness, mucus secretion, smooth muscle hypertrophy, and structural airway remodeling. As a result, use of inhaled corticosteroids can help prevent future asthma exacerbations and reduce mortality rates.  



Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate can be administered to patients with acute asthma exacerbations who do not respond to initial treatment. However, this patient lacks signs of an acute asthma exacerbation (e.g., accessory muscle use, hypoxia, tachypnea). Medications such as inhaled corticosteroids would be more effective than magnesium sulfate in reducing the frequency of asthma flare-ups in this patient. 
❌ Theophylline:
Incorrect: Theophylline causes smooth muscle relaxation and can be used in refractory cases of asthma. However, the medication is rarely used in patients prior to addition of inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists. 
✅ Fluticasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Montelukast:
Incorrect: Montelukast is a selective leukotriene receptor antagonist that inhibits the cysteinyl leukotriene receptor. It is used in refractory cases of asthma but is rarely used in patients prior to addition of inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists.
❌ Formoterol :
Incorrect: Formoterol, a long-acting beta-agonist, is effective in managing patients with persistent asthma. However, it does not effectively manage the underlying pathogenesis of the condition, which is airway inflammation. As a result, inhaled corticosteroids should be tried first before proceeding to long-acting beta-agonist therapy.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old African-American boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to shortness of breath and  fatigue. The patient states that he first noticed the symptoms a couple months ago, but that they became much worse recently. He is diagnosed with a hemolytic condition, treated for his symptoms, and discharged. Over the following year, the symptoms worsen, and he presents to the hospital 3 more times with severe chest pain.
