Family history includes renal papillary necrosis in his paternal grandfather and sickle cell anemia in his maternal uncle. Current temperature is 37°C (98.9°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below.


The patient is administered the appropriate preventative treatment. Which of the following is most likely increased as a result of this patient’s treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient with anemia, family history of sickle cell anemia and renal papillary necrosis, and medical history of severe chest pain from vaso-occlusive crises has sickle cell disease (SCD) that warrants treatment with hydroxyurea. SCD, also called sickle cell anemia, is an autosomal recessive disorder that is caused by a genetic mutation that substitutes glutamic acid with valine in the sixth position of the beta globin chain in adult hemoglobin. Replacing glutamic acid, a negatively charged molecule, with valine, a neutral molecule, creates a hydrophobic effect on the surface of the beta globin chain and creates what is called Hemoglobin S (HbS). This hydrophobic surface interacts with the hydrophobic molecules on other beta globin chains and causes them to polymerize. Especially when there is acidosis, hypoxia, or dehydration, HbS changes its shape and aggregates with other HbS proteins to form long chains that distort erythrocytes into a crescent or sickled shape. This distortion leads to both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.  

Since inheritance of SCD is autosomal recessive, a patient must have both copies of the gene to get the disease. If the person has just one copy of the mutation and one normal hemoglobin A gene, or HbA, then they have sickle cell (HbS) trait and are said to be a carrier for SCD. In this scenario, the family history of sickle cell disease in the maternal uncle and renal papillary necrosis in the paternal grandfather indicate that the patient’s parents likely both have sickle cell trait. Peripheral blood smear may show sickled erythrocytes or Howell-Jolly bodies, which are basophilic nuclear remnants seen in erythrocytes and indicative of a nonfunctional or absent spleen.  



Testing for sickle cell anemia may be done prenatally via amniocentesis, in newborns, or during sickle cell crisis in children and adults. Definitive diagnosis is achieved via hemoglobin electrophoresis.  Management of patients with sickle cell disease includes a modified vaccination schedule, regular hydration, prophylactic penicillin (due to increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria), pain management, and avoidance of extreme heat or cold, intense exercise, and hypoxic conditions. Patients with six or more vaso-occlusive episodes in a year also require treatment with hydroxyurea, which increases levels of fetal hemoglobin, also called hemoglobin F (HbF).








Option Analysis

❌ Hemoglobin A1c:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin A1c, which is used to monitor disease progression in patients with diabetes, may be lower than expected in patients with sickle cell anemia due to increased turnover. Hydroxyurea, which is the treatment for sickle cell anemia, increases levels of HbF.
❌ Hemoglobin S:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin S is increased in sickle cell anemia; however, hydroxyurea, which is the treatment for sickle cell anemia, specifically increases levels of HbF.
✅ Hemoglobin F:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hemoglobin C  :
Incorrect: Hemoglobin C is increased in Hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. Hydroxyurea, which is the treatment for sickle cell anemia, increases levels of HbF.
❌ Hemoglobin A2:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin A2, which is made up of two alpha and two delta chains, is the less common form of adult hemoglobin. Hydroxyurea, which is the treatment for sickle cell anemia, increases levels of HbF.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl was brought to the emergency department by her parents for the evaluation of high fever and a rash. The rash first appeared on her face last night and has now spread over her entire body. Prior to the onset of the rash, the patient had intermittent cough and runny nose. She did not receive any vaccinations since birth due to parental preference. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows an irritable and restless child with a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash all over the body sparing the palms and soles bilaterally. Oral examination shows tiny, white round lesions on the buccal mucosa. Administration of which of the following is associated with decreased morbidity and mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with measles (rubeola), which is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles). Administration of vitamin A to children with measles is associated with decreased morbidity and mortality.  

Vitamin A acts as an immunomodulator that boosts the antibody response to measles. The WHO recommends vitamin A to be administered to all children with acute measles. It has shown to prevent complications associated with measles (e.g., pneumonia, keratitis, etc.) and reduce the recovery time and hospital stay.  

There is no specific antiviral treatment for measles. Instead, the medications are generally aimed at treating superinfections, maintaining good hydration with adequate fluids, and pain relief. In an outbreak setting, the measles vaccine can be given to household contacts, and measles immunoglobulin can be given to pregnant women and young infants to help prevent others from getting sick. 

Option Analysis

❌ Folic acid:
Incorrect: Folic acid plays an important role in the production of erythrocytes and helps in the development of the neural tube into the brain and spinal cord. It is shown to decrease the risk of neural tube defects in newborns. It has no proven benefit in the treatment of measles.
✅ Vitamin A:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: In the active phase of viremia, use of steroids will suppress the immunological response, which may worsen the disease course. There is no evidence of the role of steroids in the prevention of morbidity and mortality associated with measles.
❌ Live-attenuated measles, mumps, rubella vaccine:
Incorrect: Although administration of live-attenuated measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is important for the prevention of these infections, it is not indicated in patients in the active phase of viremia.
❌ Airborne precautions:
Incorrect: Airborne precautions are indicated for four days after the onset of rash in otherwise healthy patients infected with measles. This measure is important to prevent the spread of infection to susceptible individuals. However, it does not help reduce morbidity and mortality associated with measles in the affected individual.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit and raises a concern for recent voice changes. The patient has noticed a deepening and hoarseness of his voice over the past eight weeks and is worried “something is wrong with my voice box.” His parent reports the patient has been sleeping 10-12 hours per day and had a “head-cold” two months ago. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. He does not smoke, use illicit drugs, or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a tall, thin male in no acute distress with comedonal acne noted on the face. The patient’s posterior oropharynx is without evidence of edema, exudates, or erythema. There is no tenderness to palpation of the trachea. When asked to speak, the patient's voice intermittently enters higher frequency registers. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds
Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of voice changes consistent with normal development during puberty. During the physical examination, the patient has a characteristic “voice crack,” which refers to a person's voice suddenly and unintentionally entering a higher register.  

The hormonal changes males experience during puberty influence the anatomy of the larynx, ultimately resulting in enlargement of the larynx and the development of longer, thicker vocal folds. As these structures enlarge and change, the fundamental frequency of the vocal cords decreases, resulting in a deeper pitch to the voice.    

Option Analysis

✅ Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus :
Incorrect: Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, may cause transient changes in phonation, including deepening of the voice. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Subglottic stenosis :
Incorrect: Subglottic stenosis refers to a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords and above the trachea. This condition is often congenital or acquired after prolonged mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Vocal fold paralysis:
Incorrect: Unilateral vocal fold paralysis results in a hoarse or breathy voice. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis causes dyspnea and potentially a complete airway obstruction. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Respiratory papillomatosis :
Incorrect: Respiratory papillomatosis is a rare disorder characterized by the development of small, wart-like growths in the respiratory tract.  Involvement of the larynx can result in voice change, most commonly a hoarse, gravelly voice. It is more likely this patient’s symptoms are related to normal anatomic changes associated with puberty.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent for a routine evaluation. The boy has a known medical condition that requires frequent checkups. The parent states that the patient has been healthy, except for frequent episodes of chronic diarrhea. Current medications include an inhaled bronchodilator, an inhaled corticosteroid, and inhaled N-acetylcysteine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Weight is at the 5th percentile for age and height is at the 10th. There is painless swelling of the distal phalanges. Which of the following tests should be done at this visit?
questions.solution:
This boy, who is coming in for a routine evaluation, likely has cystic fibrosis (CF). Previously considered lethal in infancy and early adolescence, patients with CF can now survive to a median age of 50 years. This improvement is mainly due to early diagnosis through neonatal screening, routine evaluation, and improved pharmacotherapies.  

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) can be used to track CF progression. PFTs are used to determine the severity of pulmonary exacerbations as well as disease progression. Pulmonary exacerbations present with increased sputum production, chronic cough, and lung function decline noted by pulmonary function testing.  

Additionally, chest x-rays (CXRs) are a common diagnostic tool to follow disease progression. CXRs are extremely useful for diagnosing chronic infection as well as preventing and managing pulmonary exacerbations. In patients with early disease, CXRs may show hyperinflation. As the disease progresses, bronchiectasis, air trapping, and hyperinflation become more prominent on radiographs.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Chest x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Routine echocardiogram would be useful in patients with congenital heart defects. Although it can also present with failure to thrive, patients do not typically present with loose stools or chronic rhinosinusitis. 
❌ Slit lamp eye examination:
Incorrect: Slit lamp eye examination should be performed in patients who are predisposed to anterior uveitis, such as children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Patients typically complain of swollen joints that are painful with movement, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Regular screening with abdominal ultrasounds is typically done in patients with congenital syndromes that predispose them to abdominal tumors, such as WAGR and Beckwith-Widemann. 
❌ Colonoscopy :
Incorrect: Colonoscopy should be routinely performed in patients 8 years after the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis to screen for colorectal cancer. Although this patient is presenting with diarrhea and failure to thrive, his other symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parent after she felt pulsations on the infant’s head.  The infant was born to a 24-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He has been breastfeeding well. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight and 60th percentile for head circumference. The patient cries when picked up by the physician but is easily consoled by the mother. Moro and grasp reflexes are present. Examination of the head shows soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle. Firm stroking of the soles of the feet causes the big toes to turn up. Which of the following is the best next step?

choices.text: Admit to the infant to the hospital
Alert the department of human services
Refer the patient to a neurosurgeon

questions.solution:
This infant is developing typically, and no intervention is indicated at this time. A soft pulsation may be palpable at the anterior fontanelle.  

There are two fontanelles (the space between the bones of an infant's skull where the sutures intersect) that are covered by tough membranes that protect the underlying soft tissues and brain. The fontanelles include: 
  •  The anterior fontanelle (diamond shaped) is bounded by the two frontal and two parietal bones. Thus it is located at the junction of the sagittal, coronal, and frontal (metopic) sutures, the future site of bregma. It remains soft until about 18 months to 2 years of age. A soft pulsation may be palpable at the anterior fontanelle. 
  •  The posterior fontanelle (triangular shaped) is bounded by the two parietal bones and the occipital bone. It is located at the junction of the lambdoid and sagittal sutures, the future site of lambda. The posterior fontanelle usually closes first, before the anterior fontanelle, during the first several months of an infant's life. 
A sunken anterior fontanelle is primarily due to dehydration. Furthermore, a bulging fontanelle may indicate a rise in intracranial pressure, suggesting multiple pathologies: hydrocephalus, hypoxemia, meningitis, trauma, or hemorrhage. 

Option Analysis

❌ Admit to the infant to the hospital:
Incorrect: The infant is developing normally and should be sent home after scheduling the next well visit. 
❌ Alert the department of human services :
Incorrect: Human services should be alerted in cases of suspected child abuse, which may present with a large, heavy head, retinal hemorrhages, and skeletal fractures. The infant is developing normally and should be sent home after scheduling the next well visit. 
❌ Refer the patient to a neurosurgeon:
Incorrect: A referral to neurosurgeon is indicated in abusive head trauma which may present with a disproportionately large head, full fontanelle, papilledema and retinal hemorrhages. Soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle are a normal finding. 
✅ Reassure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Perform a CT head scan:
Incorrect: A CT head scan is indicated in a neonate with suspected head trauma which may present with a disproportionately large head, full fontanelle, papilledema, and retinal hemorrhages. Soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle are a normal finding.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is evaluated on inpatient rounds for a retropharyngeal abscess. Temperature is 102 °F, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is awake and oriented and appears tired. He is not struggling to breathe and is otherwise resting comfortably. An area of erythematous inflammation is seen in the posterior oropharynx, and the patient has mild submandibular lymphadenopathy. Parenteral antibiotic therapy is initiated with clindamycin and metronidazole. The physician explains to the parents at the bedside that urgent treatment is required due to the potential spread of infection into a region called the “danger space.” Which of the following best describes the boundaries of this space?

choices.text: Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly
Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly

questions.solution:
Posterior to the pharynx, there is a potential space called the retropharyngeal space. This space is bounded anteriorly by the buccopharyngeal fascia, the superior continuation of the pretracheal fascia, and posteriorly by the alar fascia. Infection in the retropharyngeal space can also lead to a retropharyngeal abscess, resulting in difficulty swallowing and speaking.

Another important space is the ‘danger space,’ which is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia. This space extends from the base of the skull into the posterior mediastinum and down to the level of the diaphragm, making it the most important route for the spread of infection between the neck and thorax.



Option Analysis

❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: These are the boundaries of the retropharyngeal space. The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
✅ Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A few hours ago, he was playing basketball with his friends when he first developed mild abdominal pain. The pain increased gradually, and since then, the patient had increasing nausea and three episodes of vomiting. The patient has had similar, milder episodes in the past that resolved with rest. The review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen. There is marked swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right hemiscrotum. The pain is worsened when the right testis is elevated, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. Physical examination of the left hemiscrotum and testis is unremarkable. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute-onset severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting, in combination with diffuse right scrotal swelling, erythema, tenderness, a negative Prehn sign (pain that does not resolve with the elevation of testicles), and an absent cremasteric reflex; this presentation is consistent with testicular torsion, which occurs as a result of the twisting of the spermatic cord.

Testicular torsion is one of the most common causes of acute scrotal pain in infants and post pubertal individuals. It occurs due to the insufficient fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis, leading to hypermobility, which allows for the twisting of the testis around the spermatic cord, cutting off its blood supply. Testicular torsion may occur after an inciting event (e.g., trauma, vigorous physical activity) or spontaneously.

Testicular torsion typically presents as an acute onset of scrotal pain with a negative Prehn sign. Some patients may present with diffuse lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical examination shows a tender, enlarged, high-riding testes with its long axis oriented transversely instead of longitudinally due to the shortening of the spermatic cord (“bell clapper deformity”). Cremasteric reflex is typically absent.





Diagnosis is based on physical examination and doppler ultrasound for confirmation. Treatment includes surgical correction (orchiopexy) or manual detorsion if the surgery is not possible. Delay in detorsion by a few hours may lead to testicular nonviability and infertility. If the testis is not viable, orchiectomy should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Twisting of the spermatic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dilation of the pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Dilation of the pampiniform plexus results in a varicocele. It is more common on the left side, presents with dull abdominal pain that gets worse with standing, and feels like “a bag of worms” on physical examination. Cremasteric reflex is normal in cases of varicocele.
❌ Bacterial infiltration of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Acute epididymitis can result from the bacterial infiltration of the epididymis. It is characterized by localized testicular pain with tenderness and swelling on palpation of the affected epididymis (posterior testis). The pain is usually relieved by the elevation of testes (positive Prehn sign), unlike this patient. Dysuria and/or urethral discharge can also be present.
❌ Twisting of the appendix testis:
Incorrect: Testicular appendage torsion can present with acute onset testicular/abdominal pain. The swelling and tenderness, however, is localized to the head of the affected testes (unlike diffuse tenderness/swelling). Cremasteric reflex is typically present. A “blue dot” sign is often visible on physical examination, and the scrotal skin and testicles are usually normal-appearing and minimally tender.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele can result from an accumulation of fluid between the layers of tunica vaginalis due to a  persistently patent processus vaginalis. Although scrotal swelling is apparent on the affected side, it does not cause acute severe testicular pain, and it transilluminates well.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent, who states the patient has been lethargic for the past several weeks. The patient is in the 30th percentile for height and weight and has no significant past medical history. He has no abnormal bleeding, recent infections, or loss of sensation in the limbs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  78 fL 
 Reticulocyte count  0.5% 
 Serum iron  45 μg/dL 
 Ferritin  180 ng/mL 
 Lead  1 μg/dL (Normal < 5) 

Bone marrow aspirate reveals the following sample with Prussian blue stain.


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Treatment with which of the following is most likely to improve this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young boy is presenting with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, conjunctival pallor, low hemoglobin) and has a bone marrow aspiration showing sideroblasts. He likely has X-linked sideroblastic anemia (XLSA).   

XLSA is due to a defect in the δ-aminolevulinate (ALA) synthase gene. Since heme synthesis takes place in the mitochondria, iron is normally delivered to the mitochondria. Due to the enzyme defect, however, iron accumulates in the mitochondrial matrix of these erythrocytes and forms the characteristic sideroblastic ring. Since ringed-sideroblasts are immature red blood cells, they are usually seen on bone marrow biopsy and rarely seen in the bloodstream. In addition, due to the accumulation of iron, patients typically have increased iron levels, increased ferritin levels, and low/normal total iron binding capacity (TIBC).  

ALA synthase uses pyridoxine (vitamin B6) as an essential cofactor in the first step of heme synthesis. Therefore, in children with XLSA, supplemental pyridoxine should be given to stimulate the defective enzyme, resulting in improved heme production. Additionally, since ringed-sideroblasts occur due to iron accumulation and improper utilization, many patients develop iron overload, which can be managed with therapeutic phlebotomies.   



Option Analysis

✅ Pyridoxine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Succimer :
Incorrect: Succimer is a chelating agent that would be an appropriate treatment for patients with lead poisoning. Lead poisoning may also present as sideroblastic anemia; however, patients (especially children) typically have other symptoms, such as severe abdominal pain, polyneuropathy, and constipation. Additionally, this patient’s blood lead level is normal. 
❌ Folate:
Incorrect: Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency can manifest in patients who are malnourished (e.g. chronic alcoholic use), have increased demand (e.g. pregnant women), or are taking medications that are folic acid antagonists (e.g. methotrexate). However, folate deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, whereas this patient has microcytic anemia. As a result, folate supplementation is unlikely to improve this patient’s condition.
❌ Cobalamin:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency can be present in patients who are malnourished (e.g. chronic alcohol use), have decreased intrinsic factor production (e.g., pernicious anemia, gastrectomy), or have malabsorption conditions (e.g., Crohn disease, celiac disease). However, B12 deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, whereas this patient has microcytic anemia. As a result, B12 supplementation is unlikely to improve this patient’s condition.
❌ Iron :
Incorrect: Supplemental iron would be an appropriate treatment for patients with iron-deficiency anemia. This patient’s serum iron and ferritin levels indicate there is no deficiency.

questions.text: A 4-day-old girl is evaluated in the nursery for failure to pass meconium and abdominal distention. The patient was born at 40-weeks gestational age to a 35-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is breastfeeding well but has not yet passed meconium. Physical examination is notable for upslanted palpebral fissures, prominent epicanthal folds, and a distended abdomen. Digital rectal exam is performed, causing large quantities of gas and stool to be expelled across the room. Which of the following would be most useful in providing a definitive diagnosis for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Hirschsprung disease (also termed congenital aganglionic megacolon), which occurs due to the defective migration of neural crest cells to the distal colon. As a result, affected segments of the colon lack the Meissner and Auerbach plexus, which are responsible for controlling smooth muscle contraction and relaxation. The condition is associated with Down syndrome and RET gene mutations.    

Patients with Hirschsprung disease typically fail to pass the meconium within the first two days after birth. In addition, since the rectum is affected, feces builds up in the more proximal sections of the bowel. This accumulation results in serious constipation, abdominal distention, and toxic megacolon, which is a risk for rupture. Digital rectal exam will reveal a tight anal sphincter and will trigger the explosive release of feces.  

Diagnosis is made via rectal suction biopsy of the mucosa and submucosa, which reveals the lack of ganglion cells. Treatment is surgical resection of the aganglionic section of the intestine.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Barium enema :
Incorrect: In patients with Hirschsprung disease, a barium enema may reveal narrowing of the rectum and sigmoid colon. However, a rectal suction biopsy is nonetheless needed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Abdominal x-ray :
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray can show distention of the proximal colon in Hirschsprung disease. However, this test would be insufficient to distinguish Hirschsprung disease from etiologies (e.g., volvulus, intussusception) that can cause intestinal obstruction and distention. 
❌ Technetium-99 uptake scan :
Incorrect: A technetium-99 scan can identify areas of heterotopic gastric mucosa and be used to diagnose patients with Meckel diverticulum. Patients with Meckel diverticulum can have abdominal pain and bloody stools. However, it would be atypical for a Meckel diverticulum to present with abdominal distention or an explosive release of feces after digital rectal exam. 
✅ Rectal suction biopsy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌  Chromosome analysis :
Incorrect: This patient’s facial features are consistent with Down syndrome, which can be confirmed via chromosomal analysis. However, the patient’s constipation and abdominal distention are most likely due to Hirschsprung disease, a condition associated with Down syndrome. A biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum is necessary to diagnose a patient with Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of testicular pain and swelling. The patient was running when he felt sudden onset groin pain. Since then, he experienced severe scrotal pain with associated nausea and vomiting. He has had similar episodes of pain over the past two months that have all self-resolved without intervention. He has no significant past medical history and has received all age-appropriate vaccinations. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 141/80 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an uncomfortable adolescent male in significant pain. Examination demonstrates an edematous and erythematous right scrotum. Stroking of the right inner thigh does not result in elevation of the right testis. The pain is worsened with elevation of the scrotum, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical fixation of the bilateral testicles
Surgical fixation of the right testicle

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with acute right-sided scrotal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The physical examination reveals an absent cremasteric reflex and negative Prehn sign, suggestive of testicular torsion. The most common abnormality associated with testicular torsion is known as the "bell clapper" deformity, where the testicle lacks the normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis, allowing for increased mobility and susceptibility to torse.

The most appropriate initial step when testicular torsion is suspected is immediate urologic consultation, as delays in surgical management may result in loss of the testicle from ischemia. Detorsion and fixation of both the affected testis and the contralateral uninvolved testis should be performed (termed an orchiopexy), since inadequate fixation is typically a bilateral defect. Prolonged periods of ischemia (>8 hours) may lead to infarction of the testis with necrosis, requiring removal of the affected testis (termed an orchiectomy).

Additional management includes ultrasonographic evaluation of blood flow to the testes, analgesia, and peri-operative clearance blood work. If surgical consultation is not immediately available, patients should undergo a trial of manual detorsion--wherein the testicle is rotated medial to lateral in one or two full 360 degree turns with the hope of restoring blood flow to the testicle.    

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical fixation of the bilateral testicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical fixation of the right testicle:
Incorrect: Although surgical fixation of the right testicle is emergent, bilateral fixation is almost always required, since inadequate gubernacular fixation is typically a bilateral defect.
❌ Ceftriaxone and doxycycline:
Incorrect: Antibiotic treatment for epididymitis in those under age 35 includes coverage for sexually transmitted infectious etiologies. Patients with epididymitis experience pain relief with elevation of the testis (Prehn sign), whereas patients with testicular torsion experience pain with any testicular manipulation.
❌ Reassurance and monitoring:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis, and it is typically managed with reassurance if patients are asymptomatic. Although hydrocele is an potential cause of testicular swelling, it is almost always painless.
❌ Biopsy:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer can present as a firm, nontender nodule or mass that does not transilluminate. This young patient, in contrast, has severe, acute testicular pain, making another etiology more likely.

questions.text:
A 5-hour-old male infant is evaluated in the nursery for a skin lesion present at birth. He was born at term to a 32-year-old woman who had consistent prenatal care. The lesion is located next to the umbilicus and is shown below. The parents are worried that it might affect their child cosmetically. They would like to know what is the most appropriate treatment and prognosis for their child’s condition.  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the doctor at this time?

choices.text: Excisional surgery therapy now, as this lesion carries a high risk for complications
Observation, as this lesion is likely to regress without treatment
Oral propranolol now, as this lesion carries high-risk potential
Topical imiquimod now, as this lesion carries a high risk for disfiguration
Intralesional corticosteroids now, as this lesion is deep and unlikely to regress without treatment

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic newborn has a strawberry hemangioma, a benign tumor of vascular endothelium. They are the most common tumors of childhood. These tumors are characterized by an early growth phase followed by involution in the first few years of life.  

The approach to treatment is individualized and based upon the size of the lesion, location, morphology, potential or current complications, scarring or disfigurement potential, patient’s age, and the rate of growth or involution. The potential risk of treatment should be carefully weighed against the benefits. Hemangiomas are further classified into low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas and high-risk/complicated hemangiomas.  

 
  •  Low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas are located in away from cosmetically sensitive locations, as seen here. These are treated with observation, as they are likely to involute after the first year of life. Topical therapies such as topical beta-blockers, and less commonly corticosteroids and imiquimod, can be used for the treatment of low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas as an alternative to observation, especially if there is ulceration. 
 
  •  High-risk/complicated hemangiomas include large hemangiomas with a risk of scarring or disfigurement (e.g. facial hemangiomas), life-threatening hemangiomas (e.g. airway hemangiomas), lesions with functional risks (e.g. periocular hemangiomas), and hemangiomas with ulceration that are unresponsive to standard wound care. In general, these are treated with oral propranolol (first line) or other surgical modalities.  

Option Analysis

❌ Excisional surgery therapy now, as this lesion carries a high risk for complications:
Incorrect: Surgical excision is typically reserved for involuted lesions with residual scars, hemangiomas that failed to involute by age 4, pedunculated cutaneous hemangiomas, and small periorbital hemangiomas. This patient’s lesion is low risk/uncomplicated (see main explanation).  
✅ Observation, as this lesion is likely to regress without treatment  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral propranolol now, as this lesion carries high-risk potential:
Incorrect: Oral propranolol is the first-line treatment for hemangiomas with the potential to impair function or disfigurement if there are no contraindications (i.e. heart condition). This patient’s lesion is low risk and uncomplicated (see main explanation).    
❌ Topical imiquimod now, as this lesion carries a high risk for disfiguration  :
Incorrect: Topical imiquimod is sometimes used for small, localized hemangiomas, especially when ulceration is present. However, it has been less commonly used since the introduction of topical beta-blockers. This patient’s lesion is low risk and without ulceration.  
❌ Intralesional corticosteroids now, as this lesion is deep and unlikely to regress without treatment:
Incorrect: The use of intralesional corticosteroids (e.g. triamcinolone acetonide) is reserved for small, localized, deep hemangiomas. Deep hemangiomas are present below the skin and appear as blue discoloration of the skin. This patient’s lesion is superficial.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of intractable vomiting and lethargy. The patient’s parent reports that the family was on vacation for the past six days. Three days ago, the patient developed a headache, cough, coryza, sore throat and a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F). The parent reports that the patient was given multiple medications to bring down his fever. The fever resolved yesterday, but the patient has become increasingly lethargic and began having non-bilious, non-bloody emesis one day prior to presentation. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 95/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a lethargic child who is minimally reactive. Abdominal examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000/mm3 
 Platelet count    180,000/mm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  405 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  417 U/L 
 Ammonia  94 mcg/dL 
 Coagulation studies
 Prothrombin time  19 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  45 sec
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vomiting, lethargy, hepatomegaly and laboratory evidence of hepatic injury after taking over-the-counter medications for a presumed viral infection. Together, these findings are suspicious for Reye syndrome secondary to aspirin administration.   

Reye syndrome is caused by aspirin metabolites that inhibit hepatic mitochondrial enzymes, thereby decreasing beta-oxidation in the liver. This manifests clinically with nausea, vomiting, encephalopathy and hepatomegaly. Laboratory derangements include abnormal hepatic aminotransferases, coagulation profile (prolonged PT and PTT) and hyperammonemia. Histologically, the liver may demonstrate microvesicular steatosis, which is characterized by small intracytoplasmic liposomes within hepatocytes that do not distort the hepatocyte nucleus. Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children except in the case of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the antipyretic/analgesic of choice in children with viral infections. Its use is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitor, which can be used as an anti-inflammatory agent in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It does not have antipyretic effects and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
❌ Cetirizine:
Incorrect: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of seasonal allergies.  It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.   
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of allergic reactions. It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents with her parents for a follow-up appointment. Past medical history is notable for Turner syndrome. Last year, the patient was seen due to concerns of short stature and was started on a medication to promote height growth. The patient consumes a well-balanced diet and is physically active. Vitals are within normal limits. The physical examination shows the patient has a webbed neck, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and swelling of the lower extremities. The patient’s height is in the 30th percentile and weight is in the 40th percentile. The patient’s height was in the 12th percentile last year. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. The patient’s HbA1C was normal last year. Which of the following most likely accounts for this change?
 
Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Hematocrit
42%
Leukocyte count  
4800/mm3   
Platelet count  
300,000/mm3   
HbA1C  
6.7%

choices.text: Blockage of pancreatic ducts with viscous secretions

questions.solution:
This patient has Turner syndrome and presents with an elevated hemoglobin A1C. This laboratory finding is due to elevated blood glucose levels, likely arising as a complication of growth hormone therapy used to treat short stature in patients with Turner syndrome.

Growth hormone (GH) is an anabolic hormone that exerts its physiological effects via two mechanisms. First, GH binds and activates GH receptors found in various tissues (e.g., bones, muscles, adipocytes). Second, GH stimulates hepatocytes to produce insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which also promotes growth and development.

Both GH and IGF-1 affect almost every tissue in the body and enhance their growth. Their most notable growth promoting effects are in the bones and cartilage. In patients whose growth plates are not yet fused, GH therapy leads to enhanced growth velocity and final height.

In addition to promoting growth, GH plays a major role in affecting peripheral tissue metabolism. These effects are mainly mediated by IGF-1 and include increased protein synthesis, increased amino acid uptake, decreased protein catabolism, and increased fat metabolism. GH also decreases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and promotes hepatic gluconeogenesis, thereby resulting in hyperglycemia.

Recombinant human GH (HGH) is indicated in the treatment of short stature in Turner syndrome. Moreover, it is used in patients with growth hormone deficiency, Prader-Willi syndrome, idiopathic short stature, and children with chronic kidney failure.

Adverse effects are mainly due to the increased metabolism and growth. They include diabetes mellitus, arthralgias, hypertension, and heart failure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Autoimmune destruction of the pancreas:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of type I diabetes mellitus. Although patients with Turner syndrome have an increased incidence of type I diabetes mellitus, this patient’s interval increase in HbA1C is more likely due to the side effects of growth hormone therapy.  
✅ Medication side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blockage of pancreatic ducts with viscous secretions:
Incorrect: Patients with cystic fibrosis produce viscous secretions that can lead to pancreatic ductal obstruction and subsequent pancreatic insufficiency. However, this patient does not have a history of cystic fibrosis.  
❌ Amyloid deposition in the pancreas:
Incorrect: Amyloid deposition in the pancreas is one of the hallmarks of type II diabetes mellitus. In this condition, amyloid polypeptide deposition in the islets of Langerhans results in β-cell dysfunction. Patients with Turner syndrome have an increased incidence of type II diabetes mellitus; however, this is seen in older age (e.g. age 40). Furthermore, this patient’s glucose intolerance developed after starting growth hormones, making this the most likely cause.  
❌ Mutation in glucokinase:
Incorrect: Glucokinase mutation is seen in patients with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). MODY is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by impaired insulin secretion and onset of diabetes often before the age of 25. However, this patient’s interval increase in HbA1C is more likely due to a side effect of growth hormone therapy.

questions.text: A three-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to gait disturbance. The patient’s parents have noticed that their son has been falling more frequently while running. In addition, they have observed that he appears to have “knock knees.” They deny any significant injury, and the boy has not been complaining of pain. He was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and is up to date on vaccinations. He can name familiar objects, climbs well, and follows instructions. On physical examination he is well-developed, well-nourished, and speaks in 3-4 word sentences. Physical examination is notable for bilateral genu valgum. His knees are nontender and he has full range of motion without pain. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral genu valgum on physical examination. Clinically and radiographically, valgus deformity will present as “knock knees,” whereas varus deformity will present as “bow legs”. Genu valgum can be a normal finding in patients between the ages of 2-5 years. In the majority of toddlers with physiologic genu valgum, the condition will resolve with age as the long bones of the legs continue to ossify. While genu valgum may be a standard variant in toddlers, it can also represent a pathologic disturbance in the development of long bones.

Measurement of the Q-angle can be used to assess the alignment of the knee joint This angle is found by measuring the angle formed between the quadriceps muscles and the patella tendon. The normal Q angle falls between 12 and 20 degrees when the knee is extended, with males normally falling at the low end of this range and females in the high end.

Large Q-angles outside of the normal range are associated with varus deformities that can be caused by underlying nutritional deficiencies, skeletal dysplasias, growth disorders, or persistence of severe physiologic genu varus after the age of 2 years. Small Q-angles outside of the normal range are indicative of valgus deformity, which may be physiologic in toddlers, or the result of rickets or an underlying skeletal dysplasia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Physiologic genu valgum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cozen fracture:
Incorrect: Cozen fractures are fractures of the proximal tibial metaphysis that can occur in children. They  typically present after an injury with pain of the affected knee. Patients with proximal tibial metaphysis fractures are at risk for developing valgus deformity secondary to medial physeal overgrowth during the healing response. In contrast, this patient has not suffered an injury, is not in any pain, and has bilateral valgus deformity.  
❌ Vitamin D deficiency:
Incorrect: Rickets from Vitamin D deficiency is a common cause of valgus deformity in countries without access to advanced medical care. The bone deformities associated with Rickets typically appear before the age of 18 months. The condition is unlikely in this child given his age and history of adequate nutritional intake.  
❌ Chondroectodermal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Chondroectodermal dysplasia (Ellis van Creveld syndrome) is an autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia that results in short-limbed disproportionate dwarfism. This disorder is also known to be associated with cardiac anomalies. Patients can have genu valgum, but this patient does not have other features consistent with disproportionate dwarfism.  
❌ Skeletal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Skeletal dysplasia refers to a category of rare genetic disorders that affect the development of bones and joints and can lead to genu valgum. The condition causes abnormally shaped bones, especially in the head, spine, arms, and legs. This patient is without other associated skeletal anomalies on physical examination.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother to be evaluated for elbow pain. He was forcefully pulled onto the curb by his mother after inadvertently stepping into the street. The patient has refused to move his right arm since the incident. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an irritable child holding his right upper limb with his left hand. The affected elbow is flexed and the forearm pronated. There is no visible erythema, swelling, or deformity. There is limited range of motion on physical examination. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Radial head subluxation (i.e. nursemaid’s elbow) is a common injury in young children (1-4 years of age). It is the most common upper extremity injury in infants and young children presenting to the emergency department. It is typically caused by axial traction on an outstretched, pronated forearm. With sudden traction on the distal radius, the annular ligament slips over the head of the radius at the level of the radiohumeral joint, where it becomes entrapped.    

Children with radial head subluxationIt typically present holding the injured arm in a flexed and pronated position and refusing to move it. Patients present with sudden, acute pain of the affected arm. Notably, pain does not always localize to the elbow and there is typically no swelling, bruising, or deformity of the arm. The diagnosis is clinical and most patients can be managed with closed manual reduction by either hyperpronation of the forearm (preferred) or supination of the forearm with flexion of the elbow.  

Option Analysis

❌ Biceps tendon:
Incorrect: Biceps tendon rupture typically occurs in older adults secondary to forceful extension of the elbow on a fully contracted biceps muscle. Patients may hear or feel a “popping” sensation.There is often a visible ‘Popeye deformity' in the mid-upper arm reflective of the shortened biceps brachii. Limited range of motion at the elbow joint as seen in this patient would not be expected.  
✅ Annular ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the lateral elbow. However with this condition there is full range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Medial epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Medial epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the medial epicondyle. However with this condition there is full  range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Interosseous membrane of the forearm:
Incorrect: The interosseous membrane of the forearm is a connective tissue that lies between the radius and ulna. It is usually affected in patients with a radius or ulna fractures following a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a new rash on his left arm. His parent noticed the rash a few days ago, and it has been expanding since then. Past medical history is unremarkable.  The patient is feeling well. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is a bright red targetoid lesion on the patient’s left arm. The pediatrician suspects an infectious etiology and recommends starting an oral antibiotic course. The patient has no known drug allergies. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a targetoid erythematous rash after returning from a camping trip, which is concerning for Lyme disease. While doxycycline is the preferred antibiotic to treat Lyme disease in adults, it should be avoided in children under 8-years-old due to the risk of tooth discoloration and impaired bone growth. Instead, amoxicillin is the preferred drug of choice.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics that inhibit the 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, thereby preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Tetracyclines are also used to treat infections caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Rickettsia rickettsii, Chlamydia species, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

The most common adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress, photosensitivity, tinnitus, and hepatotoxicity. Tetracyclines can also accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old.

Finally, they should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations as they contain divalent cations (calcium, magnesium) that can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cefuroxime:
Incorrect: Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin that can be safely used to treat Lyme disease in children. Cefuroxime can also treat infections caused by organisms including Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria species, Proteus mirabilis, and Escherichia coli.  
✅ Doxycycline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Though not a first-line agent, azithromycin may be used to treat Lyme disease in patients who cannot tolerate amoxicillin, doxycycline, or cefuroxime. It is not contraindicated for use in children.  
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: This is the preferred first-line antibiotic treatment for Lyme disease in children under 8-years-old. It does not carry the same risks of tooth discoloration and impaired bone growth as tetracyclines.  
❌ Erythromycin:
Incorrect: Although not a first-line agent, erythromycin may be used to treat Lyme disease in patients that do not tolerate amoxicillin, doxycycline, or cefuroxime. It is not contraindicated for use in children.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a well child visit. She has been meeting all developmental milestones. Vitals are within normal range. The patient is well-appearing and cooperative. Physical examination reveals a mass in the left abdomen. A CT scan is performed and shows a unilateral heterogeneous renal mass. A biopsy is taken, and the patient is diagnosed with a stage II Wilms tumor. The tumor is resected, and the patient is started on a chemotherapeutic agent that works by binding with DNA and preventing RNA synthesis. The new agent does not interfere with topoisomerase activity. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with Wilms tumor, also termed nephroblastoma, and started on actinomycin D.

Actinomycin D is an antitumor antibiotic that intercalates with DNA and prevents DNA-dependent RNA polymerase from binding, thereby inhibiting RNA synthesis. This, in turn, halts RNA protein synthesis, ultimately leading to cellular arrest and inhibition of cellular division. In addition, actinomycin D can generate free radicals to cause DNA strand breaks. Actinomycin D is frequently used to treat pediatric tumors, such as Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, and Ewing sarcoma.

Side effects of actinomycin D include bone marrow suppression, alopecia, as well as hepatotoxicity. Liver injury associated with actinomycin D can range from asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes, which is usually transient and resolves without intervention, to fulminant liver injury, which can be severe and fatal.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hematuria:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a known complication of cyclophosphamide. It usually presents with hematuria, dysuria, and suprapubic pain. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
✅ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral sensory neuropathy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapeutic agents such as paclitaxel, cisplatin, and vincristine are associated with neurotoxicity, which usually manifests as peripheral neuropathy. However, this patient was most likely started on actinomycin D. Actinomycin D does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary fibrosis is a side effect of the chemotherapeutic agents bleomycin and busulfan. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Doxorubicin is known to cause irreversible cardiotoxicity. This can result in dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Although doxorubicin can intercalate with DNA, this medication also works by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase II.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to an immediate care center for evaluation of ear pain. The parent reports that yesterday the patient returned home from his third week of weekly swimming lessons complaining of left ear fullness and pain. They noticed clear drainage from the ear. He does not have rhinorrhea or nasal congestion. The patient has otherwise been healthy recently and does not take any regular medication. Temperature is 37.44°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 102/62 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.  Physical examination demonstrates edema and otorrhea of the left ear canal. Culture of the fluid is positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be consistent with the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Pain with manipulation of the pinna
Air-fluid level along the tympanic membrane
Impaired mobility of the tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient who swims frequently presents with acute ear pain with associated edema and otorrhea of the ear canal which is consistent with acute otitis externa. A common physical examination finding associated with this diagnosis is pain with manipulation of the pinna.    

Otitis, or inflammation of the ear, is commonly caused by bacterial infections and is most often seen in children, but it can occur at any age. Pediatric patients typically present with either acute otitis media, which is an infection of the middle ear most commonly caused by Moraxella catarrhalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Haemophilus influenzae; or acute otitis externa, which is an infection of the outer ear canal that is usually caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus.    

Historical findings associated with otitis media include increased fussiness, appetite changes, trouble sleeping, as well as tugging, rubbing or holding the affected ear in non-verbal patients. Verbal patients will report new onset ear pain (otalgia) with or without ear drainage, fever, as well as preceding symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection (e.g. rhinorrhea, congestion, cough). Physical examination findings specific to this diagnosis include an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with impaired mobility. Purulent drainage may occur if the tympanic membrane has ruptured.  

In contrast, historical findings associated with otitis externa include new onset ear pain with a sense of “fullness” and decreased hearing, with or without otorrhea. Patients will often report a history of recent swimming, or manipulation of the ear canal (e.g. use of Q-tips or instrumentation). Physical examination will reveal pain with manipulation of the pinna, which is not typically observed in patients with otitis media. In addition, patients typically have edema, erythema, otorrhea, and associated debris from the ear canal. 

Option Analysis

✅ Pain with manipulation of the pinna:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bulging tympanic membrane:
Incorrect: A bulging tympanic membrane is suggestive of otitis media. This patient presents with history and physical examination that is more consistent with otitis externa (e.g. recent history of swimming, a paucity of preceding URI symptoms, and growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on culture). 
❌ Air-fluid level along the tympanic membrane :
Incorrect: An air-fluid level along the tympanic membrane is an indication of middle ear effusion and is a common finding in acute otitis media. This patient presents with a history and physical examination more consistent with otitis externa (e.g. recent history of swimming, and a paucity of preceding URI symptoms, and growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on culture). 
❌ Swollen nasal turbinates:
Incorrect: Swollen nasal turbinates can be suggestive of an upper respiratory tract infection, which is a common precursor to the development of acute otitis media, not otitis externa. 
❌ Impaired mobility of the tympanic membrane:
Incorrect:  A tympanic membrane with impaired mobility is suggestive of otitis media. This patient presents with a history and physical examination more consistent with otitis externa (e.g. recent history of swimming, a paucity of preceding URI symptoms, and growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on culture).

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant boy is brought to the primary care office by his parents for a well-check. The parents have no concerns. The child was born vaginally at 40 weeks gestation and weighed 8 lb, 1 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 152/min, respiratory rate is 44/min, weight is in the 70<sup>th</sup> percentile, length is 64<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is 70<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the baby is crying on the exam table with his mother standing next to him attempting to console him. Which of the following findings would be concerning in this patient?

choices.text: Holds fisted hands near the face most of the time
Inability to lift chest in tummy time
Inability to focus on an object three feet away

questions.solution:
This one-month-old infant is expected to startle at a loud sound, making it concerning if there is no response to loud sounds. Startling to loud sounds is considered a part of the language development of an infant, and also provides information about hearing status.

The developmental milestone assessment of an infant begins with a thorough history and physical examination. History-taking should begin with the birth history, including gestational age and birth weight, as well as whether there is a family history of developmental delays. Caregivers should be asked to provide details about what new skills their baby has learned since the last clinic visit, as well as whether they have any concerns about the child’s development. Important aspects to include in the history of a one-month-old infant include how the child is feeding and moving, and whether the infant responds to loud noises and can focus on an object placed a few inches from his or her face. If any of these areas are not met, or the child is not feeding well and gaining weight appropriately, it would be considered a red flag.

Typical physical examination findings for a one-month-old include lifting the head off of the exam table when placed prone, moving both arms and legs equally, and keeping the hands fisted and near the face most of the time. Young infants have a “startle” reflex known as the Moro reflex, where sudden movements, loud sounds, or a dropping feeling cause the baby to throw back his or her head, extend out the arms and legs, cry, and then pull the arms and legs back in (image below). Another important aspect to consider during an infant assessment, especially for very young infants, is to take note of any caregiver indifference, meaning a caregiver who is not responsive to their infant. Caregiver indifference is a red flag and should be investigated further.
 

 Moro Reflex by tawamie is licensed CC BY-SA 3.0 DEED Reproduced from WikimediaCommons  

Option Analysis

✅ No response to loud sounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Moro reflex is present:
Incorrect: The Moro or “startle” reflex is present from birth until around 2-6 months of age.  It would not be concerning for a one-month-old to still have a Moro reflex.  
❌ Holds fisted hands near the face most of the time:
Incorrect: Holding fisted hands near the face most of the time is expected for a one-month-old.  This will typically decrease to about 50% of the time by two months old and further decrease after that.  
❌ Inability to lift chest in tummy time:
Incorrect: A one-month-old is expected to be able to lift their head during tummy time, but an infant typically cannot lift the chest until two months of age.  
❌ Inability to focus on an object three feet away:
Incorrect: A one-month-old infant should be able to focus on an object placed a few inches from his or her face.  Infants begin to track objects and focus on objects further away after two months of age.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent for evaluation of staring spells. The parent tells the physician that he often stares and becomes unresponsive for several seconds at a time. Afterward, the child does not recall the event. The physician gives the patient a paper bag and asks him to blow in it quickly while having an EEG performed. After a few minutes of hyperventilation, the child stares at the wall appearing unresponsive for several seconds. During the episode, the EEG shows 3-hertz spike-and-wave discharges. The physician decides to start the patient on ethosuximide. Which of the following is the primary target of the medication most likely used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This child presents clinical findings consistent with absence seizures confirmed via EEG testing showing 3-hertz spike-and-wave discharges. Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment of absence seizures.    

Ethosuximide is an anti-epileptic medication that inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels in presynaptic nerve terminals. Specifically, ethosuximide inhibits T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are thought to contribute to the pathophysiology of absence seizures directly. Inhibition of T-type calcium channels prevents excitatory neurotransmitters (i.e. glutamate) from being released, halting the propagation of the action potential and thus seizure activity.  

Other anti-epileptic medications that also work by inhibiting the voltage-gated calcium channels include gabapentin and levetiracetam.    



Option Analysis

✅ Voltage-gated calcium channels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Voltage-gated sodium channels:
Incorrect: Blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels is the mechanism of action of multiple anti-epileptics including carbamazepine, phenytoin, and lamotrigine. Absence seizures are best treated with ethosuximide, which works via inhibition of T-type calcium channels. 
❌ GABA-A receptors:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates directly stimulate GABA-A receptors–not ethosuximide. 
❌ Potassium channels:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide does exert effects on potassium channels. Ezogabine is an anti-epileptic that works by opening neuronal potassium channels. 
❌ N-methyl-D-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptors:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide does not affect NMDA receptors. Felbamate anti-epileptic has NMDA receptor antagonist properties.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother for a routine well-child exam. They recently moved to the area and have missed several routine appointments. The patient has been eating, drinking, and sleeping well. Height and weight are in the 90th and 85th percentiles, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 95/58 mmHg, and pulse is 126/min. On physical examination with the patient supine, there is limited hip abduction on the right and there is asymmetry of the gluteal skin folds. With the patient lying supine with flexed hips at 90 degrees and feet flat by the buttocks, the right knee is lower than the left. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 5-month-old infant presents with limited hip abduction and thigh-length discrepancy with a positive Galeazzi test on the right, which is strongly suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). DDH results from misalignment of the femoral head and acetabulum. The Ortolani and Barlow maneuvers should be used to screen all infants less than 6 months of age for DDH, since early identification and intervention can prevent severe complications, such as hip joint osteoarthritis. If either of these tests is positive, bilateral hip ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of DDH.  

Normally, the femoral head sits within the acetabulum of the hip creating a “ball and socket” joint. However, in cases of DDH, the acetabulum is too shallow, preventing the femoral head from sitting in it. This results in the independent growth of both bony structures, which causes misalignment of the femoral head and acetabulum. Ultimately, this leads to an unstable hip joint.    

The Ortolani maneuver is performed with the patient in the supine position. The examiner slowly abducts the hip and then gently presses upwards on the lateral thigh. If the femoral head is dislocated, the Ortolani maneuver will push the femoral head up and into the acetabulum, making a “clunk.” The Barlow maneuver is performed with the patient in the supine position. The examiner slowly adducts the hip and then gently presses down on the knee. If there’s hip joint instability, the femoral head will be pushed down and out of the acetabulum, making a “click.” If either test is positive or if patients are at high risk for DDH, bilateral hip ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  

For pediatric patients who are > 6 months of age, the Ortolani and Barlow maneuvers are less sensitive. Examiners should test for decreased abduction, limitations in range of motion, asymmetry, and thigh-length discrepancy on exam. If any of these are present, bilateral hip X-rays should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of DDH. Older children may present with leg-length discrepancy and uneven gait.      



Option Analysis

✅ Positive Ortolani and Barlow maneuvers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Negative Galeazzi test:
Incorrect: This patient has a positive Galeazzi test. When the patient is lying supine with flexed hips at 90 degrees and feet flat by the buttocks, the right knee is lower than the left.
❌ Osteonecrosis :
Incorrect: Osteonecrosis occurs from death of bone tissue secondary to compromised blood supply and is most commonly caused by trauma or chronic steroid use. It is not a likely finding in infants with developmental dysplasia of the hip, which this patient most likely has.    
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and is typically caused by bacteria. Symptoms usually include pain, swelling, warmth and redness at the site of infection. Fever and chills can also be present. This patient more likely has developmental dysplasia of the right hip and will have positive Ortolani and Barlow maneuvers on exam.
❌ Hemihyperplasia:
Incorrect: Hemihyperplasia refers to asymmetric overgrowth of one or more regions of the body due to irregular cell proliferation (i.e. hyperplasia) and is associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS). Other features of BWS include macrosomia, macroglossia, omphalocele, and visceromegaly. None of these features are present in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to 24-hours of increased irritability and decreased feeding. The parents note that the infant appears drowsy and has been crying more frequently. The mother frequently consumed soft cheeses during this pregnancy. The pregnancy and delivery were otherwise uneventful. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate is 162/min, respiratory rate is 44/min, blood pressure is 92/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The infant is lethargic with increased head circumference. He demonstrates a high-pitched cry and shows discomfort when picked up. Which of the following physical examination findings would be expected given the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Petechial rash on the trunk and extremities

questions.solution:
This 2-week-old patient presents with fever, irritability, decreased feeding, high-pitched crying, and increased head circumference in the context of maternal soft cheese consumption during pregnancy. This patient most likely has acute meningitis with increased intracranial pressure due to Listeria monocytogenes. In neonates with acute meningitis, increased head circumference is most likely from a full anterior fontanelle due to increased intracranial pressure.     

The clinical presentation of meningitis in neonates and children differs due to varying physiological responses based on developmental stages. In infants 60 days of age or younger, the presentation is often subtle and nonspecific, making early diagnosis challenging. Common signs include poor feeding, irritability, decreased activity, and high-pitched crying. Fever is not always present, and in some cases, neonates may develop hypothermia. An increase in head circumference and a bulging anterior fontanelle can be seen due to increased intracranial pressure. Other symptoms like vomiting or diarrhea can mimic gastrointestinal illnesses. Due to physiologic differences between neonates and older children, classic signs of meningitis such as nuchal rigidity and Brudzinski and Kernig signs are often absent.    

In older children, the presentation is more pronounced and can include fever, photophobia, headache, vomiting, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. Nuchal rigidity or neck stiffness is a more reliable sign of acute meningitis in older children. Additionally, older children may demonstrate a positive Brudzinski sign (neck flexion causes involuntary knee and hip flexion) and Kernig sign (resistance or pain with passive leg extension when hips and knees are flexed).    

Signs of increased intracranial pressure can include papilledema, diplopia, cranial nerve paralysis, as well as the Cushing triad, which includes hypertension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression. In severe cases, children may present with altered mental status, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.   

Option Analysis

✅ Full anterior fontanelle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Petechial rash on the trunk and extremities:
Incorrect: A petechial rash is commonly associated with meningococcal meningitis. However, meningococcal infection is not a common cause of meningitis in 2-week-olds. This patient has findings and a history consistent with bacterial meningitis with increased intracranial pressure from late-onset listeriosis. 
❌ Nuchal rigidity:
Incorrect: Nuchal rigidity is uncommon in neonates with meningitis due to the presence of open fontanelles and underdeveloped neck musculature. This patient has findings and history consistent with bacterial meningitis with increased intracranial pressure from late-onset listeriosis.
❌ Retinal hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Bilateral retinal hemorrhages in a neonate may suggest trauma or abuse. They are not associated with acute meningitis. 
❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Jaundice can be seen in neonates due to a variety of conditions, including biliary dysfunction or hemolysis; however, it is not associated with meningitis. This patient has findings and a history consistent with bacterial meningitis with increased intracranial pressure from late-onset listeriosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of 3-days of fever and irritability following an upper respiratory tract infection that started one week ago. His parents note a persistent runny nose and cough that began one week ago and has been improving. Today the patient developed a fever reaching 38.7°C (101.7°F) and the patient exhibited decreased activity and increased sleepiness. The patient's vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 112/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a pale, lethargic child who is responsive to voice. He has clear fluid from the nares bilaterally without purulent discharge and several oral ulcers. Neck stiffness and photophobia are present without evidence of papilledema or focal neurological deficits. Bloodwork shows normal white blood cell count, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and normal procalcitonin. The patient undergoes lumbar puncture without complications and empiric antibiotics are started. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis?

choices.text: White Blood Cell (WBC) count (cells/mm3)  Cell types  Glucose (mg/dL)  Protein (mg/dL)  RBC count (cells/mm3)  1300Predominantly neutrophils10400 5
White Blood Cell (WBC) count (cells/mm3)  Cell types  Glucose (mg/dL)  Protein (mg/dL)  RBC count (cells/mm3)  300 Predominantly lymphocytes 10400 5

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, irritability, lethargy, neck stiffness, and photophobia suggestive of acute meningitis. Aseptic viral meningitis is the most likely diagnosis given this patient's recent upper respiratory illness and the absence of severe systemic or focal neurological signs and findings. The normal white count and normal procalcitonin level also indicate that bacterial meningitis is less likely. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for patients with aseptic viral meningitis will show moderately elevated white blood cell count with lymphocytic predominance, normal or slightly low glucose, and mildly to moderately elevated protein. This is seen in answer A: WBC count of 150 predominantly lymphocytes, glucose of 50, and protein of 100.     

The gold standard for the diagnosis of acute meningitis is a lumbar puncture (LP) with CSF analysis and culture. In bacterial meningitis, the CSF generally reveals a high white blood cell (WBC) count with a neutrophil predominance, significantly reduced glucose levels, and a markedly increased protein concentration. In contrast, viral (aseptic) meningitis is characterized by a moderately elevated WBC count with lymphocytic predominance, normal or slightly decreased glucose level, and mildly to moderately elevated protein level.  

In certain children with suspected meningitis, lumbar puncture may be contraindicated. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated when there is evidence of increased intracranial pressure (such as papilledema), severe systemic shock, respiratory compromise, or focal neurological deficits indicative of a brain mass or abscess.
