❌  Heterophile antibody testing:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with scarlet fever due to Group A Streptococcus and not infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. While both conditions can present with fever and sore throat, the specific signs of scarlet fever, such as strawberry tongue and rash, are more consistent with scarlet fever and strep pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby is brought to the pediatrician by her parent for a pruritic vesicular rash. She recently visited her grandparents. Her grandparent had a rash at that time and was just diagnosed with shingles. The baby was born full-term with no complications. She has had appropriate weight gain and is hitting her developmental milestones. She is in the 60th percentile for weight and the 45th percentile for length. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, she is well-appearing and has erythematous vesicles diffusely that are in different stages of healing. Some look like “dew drops on a rose petal.” At what age are children routinely first vaccinated against this virus?
questions.solution:
The child in this vignette is presenting with a rash consistent with chickenpox caused by the varicella virus, which is the same virus that causes shingles. Children are first vaccinated against varicella at 12 months and then again at 4 years.     

Vaccinations are essential in preventing infection in children. They work by activating an immune response and producing antibodies. The antibodies produced as a result of vaccines help fight off future invading microbes. Vaccinations are given throughout childhood, starting with the Hepatitis B vaccine which is given within the first 24 hours of life. This child would have received a vaccination against Hepatitis B at birth. Hepatitis B is a 3-dose series and is also given at 2 months and 6 months. She would also have received RSV immunoprophylaxis with monoclonal antibodies if mom did not receive the vaccination between 32 and 36 weeks of gestation. At 2 months she would have received Hepatitis B, rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, pneumococcal conjugate (PCV), and inactivated poliovirus (IPV). Rotavirus is a 2 or 3-dose series (depending on the manufacturer) given at 2, 4, and +/- 6 months. DTaP is a 5-dose series given at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 months, and 4 years. Hib is a 2 or 3-dose series (depending on the manufacturer) given at 2, 4, and +/- 6 months. A booster dose is given at 12 months. PCV is a 4-dose series given at 2, 4, 6, and 12 months. Lastly, IPV is a 4-dose series given at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, and 4 years. In addition to MMR, Varicella, PCV13, and Hib at 12 months, patients also receive Hepatitis A. The second dose of Hepatitis A is given 6 months later at 18 months.        

The CDC provides guidelines regarding the vaccination schedule. The timing for each dose of a vaccine was determined by looking at age-specific risks for disease, risks for complications, and responses to vaccination, as well as maternal immunity transmitted to newborns/infants. In general, the recommendation is to vaccinate as early as possible as long as vaccine efficacy and safety have been proven. Most children receive vaccinations following the standardized CDC schedule but, as mentioned above, there are certain scenarios such as international travel, immunocompromised state, cochlear implants, and prematurity which may alter which vaccines are given and when. Below is the CDC vaccination schedule from birth to 18 years of age:  



Option Analysis

❌ Birth:
Incorrect: At birth, babies are vaccinated against Hepatitis B. Hepatitis B is a 3-dose series and is also given at 2 months and 6 months. As of fall of 2023, babies are also offered RSV monoclonal antibodies at birth if mom did not receive the vaccination between 32 and 36 weeks of gestation. The RSV immunization is a one-time shot. 
❌ 2 months:
Incorrect: At 2 months, babies are vaccinated against Hepatitis B, rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV.   
✅ 12 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 2 years:
Incorrect: No routine vaccinations are given at 2 years. 
❌ 4 years:
Incorrect: At 4 years, children are vaccinated against MMR, Varicella, DTaP, and IPV. However, at this age, they are given the second and final dose in the series for MMR and Varicella, and the fourth and final dose in the series for IPV. At 4 years, children receive the fifth dose of DTaP but then continue to receive a Tdap booster at 11 years of age and approximately every 10 years thereafter.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well visit. He is accompanied by his parent and grandparent. Weight is in the 75th percentile and length is in the 55th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, he is well-appearing with normal cardiac and respiratory findings and dry eczematous patches on his flexor surfaces. The boy is tearful when the pediatrician mentions there are vaccines today. The grandparent shares a story of when he was a little boy and how he developed an illness that caused inflammation of the parotid glands in his face and also inflammation in both testicles. He explains that vaccines now help protect against this illness. What type of vaccine protects against the infection that the grandparent had?
questions.solution:
This patient’s grandparent is describing the signs and symptoms of mumps which can cause parotitis and orchitis. Children are now vaccinated against mumps with a live attenuated vaccine that is part of the MMR series that protects against measles, mumps, and rubella viruses. Live attenuated vaccines contain live pathogens that have been attenuated or weakened. The body is exposed to enough of the pathogen to create an immune response with a low risk of actually becoming infected with the pathogen.      

Examples of live attenuated vaccines include the MMR and varicella vaccines. The MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella viruses. Mumps is a virus that is associated with parotitis and orchitis. Measles, also known as rubeola, is a virus that typically presents with a specific morbilliform rash in addition to cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots. Rubella, also known as german measles, is a virus that also presents with a morbilliform rash. If a mother is infected with Rubella while pregnant, the fetus can have congenital rubella syndrome, which has severe complications. Varicella, also known as chickenpox, presents with diffuse pruritic vesicles.        

The most common infections that are protected against with pediatric immunizations are Hepatitis B, Respiratory Syncytial Virus, Rotavirus, Corynebacterium diphtheria, Clostridium tetani, Bordetella pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae b, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Poliovirus, Influenza, COVID-19, Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Hepatitis A, Neisseria meningitis, and Human papillomavirus.   

Option Analysis

❌ Inactivated vaccine:
Incorrect: Inactivated vaccines include Hepatitis A, flu, and polio vaccines. Inactivated vaccines work by administering a small amount of an inactivated pathogen to build an immune response. Mumps causes parotitis and orchitis, and children now receive vaccinations against mumps with a live attenuated virus. 
✅ Live attenuated vaccine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Toxoid vaccine:
Incorrect: Toxoid vaccines include diphtheria and tetanus vaccines. Toxoid vaccines work by using inactivated toxins to create antibodies to the toxin produced by the bacteria rather than the bacteria itself. Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria, which affects mucous membranes and can cause upper airway obstruction and respiratory distress. Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which results in painful muscle contractions. Neither of these infections causes parotitis or orchitis. 
❌ Conjugate vaccine:
Incorrect: Conjugate vaccines include Hib and S pneumoniae vaccines. Conjugate vaccines work by combining a weak antigen with a strong antigen so that the immune system mounts a stronger response to the weak antigen. Hib and S pneumoniae are bacteria that can cause otitis media, pneumonia, and bacterial meningitis. Neither of these infections causes parotitis or orchitis. 
❌ mRNA vaccine:
Incorrect: mRNA vaccines include the COVID-19 vaccine. mRNA vaccines work by injecting RNA which will produce a protein unique to the virus. This triggers an immune response and the body produces antibodies as a result. COVID-19 is a virus that usually causes respiratory symptoms and can lead to viral pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome. COVID-19 is not known to cause parotitis or orchitis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parent for evaluation of persistent coughing. The parent states that she has had a dry, non-productive cough for three days. She has not had a runny nose, sore throat, fever, or chills. She has had no sick contacts. The patient loves peanuts and went to the fair four days ago where she had peanuts and popcorn. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate of 90, blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 with SpO<sub>2</sub> of 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a well-appearing child with decreased right-sided breath sounds and wheezing anteriorly. Which of the following historical factors, if present, would pose an increased risk for this patient developing a cough?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with three days of persistent coughing in the setting of recent peanut ingestion. Lung exam is notable for decreased breath sounds and wheezing heard over the right anterior lung field. These findings are suggestive of a foreign body aspiration (FBA). Developmental delay in young children can lead to an increased risk of foreign body aspiration and ingestion.

Approximately 80 percent of pediatric FBA episodes occur in children younger than three years of age, with a peak incidence between one and two years of age. At this age, most children can stand, are independently mobile, and have the fine motor skills to put small objects into their mouths. However, they do not have molars or premolars to chew food adequately and may have uncoordinated or immature swallowing mechanisms and a narrow pharynx. Additional predisposing factors to FBA in this age group include access to improper foods or small objects, being active while eating, and older siblings (who may place food or objects into the mouths of infants or toddlers). 

The most common symptom of FBA is a cough, followed by tachypnea and stridor--often with localized wheezing and decreased air entry on physical exam. Regional variation in aeration is an important clue to the diagnosis and is often detected only when the clinician completes a thorough examination while the child is quiet. Nonspecific findings of cough and generalized wheezing are often present.    

Option Analysis

❌ Recent upper respiratory infection:
Incorrect: This patient presents with an acute cough in the setting of recent peanut ingestion. Given her lack of systemic symptoms and sick contacts, her cough is likely from an aspirated foreign body for which developmental delay would be a risk factor. 
❌ Non-peanut nut allergy:
Incorrect: Patients with a non-peanut nut allergy may develop an allergy to peanuts over time. Patients with food allergies present with signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis, including hives and coughing from laryngeal edema. However, this patient’s cough likely developed secondary to a foreign body aspiration for which developmental delay can pose an increased risk. 
✅ Developmental delay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Daycare attendance:
Incorrect: Attending daycare can increase the risk of infection but would not increase the risk of a foreign body aspiration or ingestion. 
❌ Unvaccinated status :
Incorrect: Lack of vaccination does predispose children to a higher risk of infections, such as rotavirus and epiglottitis. This patient does not have systemic symptoms suggestive of infection. Instead, she has isolated coughing in the setting of a likely aspirated peanut. For which developmental delay poses an increased risk.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent after a suspected toy ingestion. The patient’s parent states their son was playing with magnets, and they saw him swallowing one. They immediately took him to the hospital. The patient is otherwise healthy, is up-to-date on vaccinations, and is meeting developmental milestones. The patient is currently asymptomatic. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate of 82, blood pressure of 94/52 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22/min with SpO<sub>2</sub> of 100% on room air. Physical exam shows a well-appearing child in no distress with clear lung fields bilaterally and a normal abdominal exam. Labs are sent and pending. X-rays of the neck, chest, and abdomen reveal eight magnetic balls connected within the distal stomach. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This four-year-old boy presents to the emergency department in stable condition after witnessing ingestion of magnets. He is asymptomatic with normal vital signs. Imaging reveals eight connected magnets in the distal stomach. Because of multiple magnets, emergency upper endoscopy is required (ideally within two hours) to identify and remove them to prevent development of a pressure-induced stomach injury.

For patients with suspected foreign body ingestion, the initial diagnostic testing includes anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the neck, chest, and abdomen. When plain radiographs do not reveal a foreign body or abnormalities, further evaluation depends on the characteristics of the patient (i.e., symptomatic, asymptomatic) and the characteristics of the suspected foreign body (e.g., sharp object, large), but most patients should undergo CT imaging.

Emergent endoscopy is recommended when the ingested object is sharp, long (>5 cm), or a superabsorbent polymer and is in the esophagus or stomach, or when the ingested object is a high-powered magnet or multiple magnets. If there are signs of airway compromise, inflammation, or intestinal obstruction, emergency endoscopy should be performed.        

Option Analysis

❌ Observation in the emergency department :
Incorrect: Patients can be observed clinically if only one magnet is present. This patient has ingested eight magnets that are seen in the distal stomach on abdominal X-ray. Emergency endoscopy is required to remove them, as magnets can induce pressure necrosis and perforation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with intravenous (IV) contrast :
Incorrect: A CT can be obtained in patients who have equivocal or negative findings on X-ray, when there remains a high clinical suspicion for an ingested foreign body. This patient has a positive X-ray finding.  
✅ Emergent upper endoscopy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with follow-up in two days :
Incorrect: Patients may be discharged if the object swallowed is seen in the duodenal bulb or distal to it. If the object is radiopaque, X-rays should be performed to track the object’s progress. If it is radiolucent, stools should be checked for passage. The object in this patient is seen in the distal stomach, so discharge is not appropriate.  
❌ Emergent bronchoscopy  :
Incorrect: Patients who have a foreign body aspiration may need emergency bronchoscopy to remove the object. This patient, however, requires an emergent upper endoscopy, because he has evidence of multiple connected magnets in the stomach.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to an urgent care center for evaluation of cough and fever for the past 4 days. The patient’s parent reports that the patient had been complaining of a headache, sore throat, and cough initially 4 days ago; and has subsequently developed audible wheezing at night. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medication. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), blood pressure is 106/60mmHg, pulse is 111/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a well-hydrated boy with no acute respiratory distress. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals mild erythematous changes and cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals wheezing and diffuse crackles throughout the lung fields bilaterally.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 7-year-old patient presents for evaluation of sore throat, headache, cough, and wheezing at night. On examination, he has a fever, diffuse wheezing, and diffuse crackles concerning pneumonia. Given this patient's good appearance and paucity of risk factors for hospitalization, it is reasonable to pursue outpatient management. This patient's presentation is most consistent with either viral pneumonia (e.g., influenza) or atypical pneumonia(e.g., due to mycoplasma). Viral PCR testing should be performed to evaluate for a potential viral pathogen that is responsive to antiviral therapy (e.g., influenza, COVID-19). If viral testing is negative, then he can be treated as an outpatient with a macrolide antibiotic.

Pediatric patients with pneumonia who present with mild symptoms can be treated as outpatients and typically need little diagnostic testing. A viral PCR assay can be performed to rule out influenza or COVID-19 which can be treated with antiviral therapy, and basic laboratory studies may be done if there is concern for metabolic abnormalities. Diagnosis is typically made based on historical factors and physical examination. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment with antiviral or macrolide therapy depending on patient age and results of viral pcr testing.

Patients with indications for hospitalization require additional testing including complete blood count (CBC), c-reactive protein (CRP), procalcitonin, and blood cultures. In addition, these patients should have an anterior-poster (AP) and lateral chest X-ray. Patients < 3 months of age should undergo lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis to assess for concomitant central nervous system (CNS) infection. Diagnostic features of the distinct types of pneumonia and their specific treatments in pediatric patients are outlined in the table below.
       

Option Analysis

✅ Viral polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest:
Incorrect: A CT chest is typically not indicated initially in the evaluation of suspected uncomplicated viral respiratory infections, as it exposes the patient to unnecessary radiation without offering diagnostic benefit in this clinical context. 
❌ Procalcitonin:
Incorrect: Procalcitonin levels are often used in the inpatient setting for monitoring response to treatment of bacterial pneumonia. In the outpatient setting, this test has limited clinical utility. 
❌ C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: C-reactive protein has limited clinical utility in the management of bacterial pneumonia in the outpatient setting.  
❌ Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) nasal swab:
Incorrect: MRSA pneumonia in the outpatient pediatric population typically follows infection with influenza. These patients typically appear ill and require hospitalization.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to the pediatrician with his parent for a well-child check. They have no specific concerns. He eats a variety of healthy foods regularly and rarely consumes high-sugar drinks. He is physically active for at least two hours per day and has good sleeping habits. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 22/min. Height is 59 inches (52nd percentile), weight is 76 lbs (16th percentile), and BMI is 15.3 kg/m2 (9th percentile). On physical examination, the child is talkative and engaging. Pulmonary and cardiovascular exams are within normal limits. The patient is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation?

choices.text: Heart rate of 108 beats per minute
1000 Hz is heard in the right ear at 10 dB
BMI in the 9th percentile or 15.3kg/m2 in this patient
Lack of development of secondary sex characteristics

questions.solution:
his 12-year-old boy presenting for a well-child visit should have further evaluation for a blood pressure that reads at or above 120/80 mmHg or is greater than or equal to the 90th percentile (whichever is lower). Up until the age of 13 years, blood pressure in children is evaluated based on percentiles relative to the child’s biological sex, age, and height. Any blood pressure above 120/80 mmHg is considered elevated in the pediatric population; therefore, this child’s blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg should have further evaluation.         

The well-child visit for an adolescent begins with a focused history, including discussion of any health changes since the last visit, followed by a physical examination consisting of vital signs and a full body exam, including chaperoned genitourinary and breast exams, if applicable. Important features to note are the height, weight, and body mass index, which are interpreted by percentiles based on the child’s age and biological sex. Body mass index is considered healthy when it falls between the 5th and 85th percentiles. Screening for hypertension is done by measuring a yearly blood pressure, which is also interpreted based on percentiles up until age 13. Vision and hearing are screened at regular intervals throughout the adolescent years.        

An important part of the physical examination in an adolescent is evaluation of puberty-related changes. This is done using the sexual maturity rating, or SMR, which is also called Tanner staging. SMR starts with Stage 1, which is prepubertal, and ends at Stage 5, which is complete sexual maturity. This scale consists of two independent criteria including the appearance of pubic hair in both sexes and either the increase in testicular volume in biological males or breast development in biological females. Puberty typically occurs between the ages of 8 to 13 years for females and 9 to 14 years for males. Failure to develop secondary sex characteristics by the end of these ranges should prompt further evaluation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Heart rate of 108 beats per minute:
Incorrect: The normal heart rate for a 12-year-old child ranges from 60-110 beats per minute while awake. If the child is otherwise healthy, asymptomatic, and well-appearing, a heart rate of 108 would not require further evaluation.  
❌ 1000 Hz is heard in the right ear at 10 dB:
Incorrect: Normal hearing in children includes the ability to hear 1000 Hz at anywhere from zero to 20 dB. This hearing test is considered normal.  
❌ BMI in the 9th percentile or 15.3kg/m2 in this patient:
Incorrect: In children, body mass index is calculated using the same formula as adults, but the value is then charted on a graph based on the age and biological sex of the child to see where it falls relative to other children. A BMI between the 5th and 85th percentile is considered to be a healthy BMI.  
❌  Lack of development of secondary sex characteristics  :
Incorrect: The onset of puberty typically occurs between the ages of 9 and 14 years old in males. Lack of secondary sex characteristics would not yet be concerning in a 12-year-old boy.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of persistent severe right testicular pain that started one hour ago. The patient has had similar episodes occurring in the right testicle in the past; however, each episode lasted for only a few minutes and resolved spontaneously. The pain was sharp and localized to the right testicle, radiating to the lower abdomen. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 125/92 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient appears uncomfortable. The right testicle is high-riding with a transverse lie. There is marked scrotal erythema and swelling. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. The left testicular examination is within normal limits. Urology is emergently consulted and takes the patient to the operating room. During the surgery, the right testicle is determined to be viable and lacking a normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Detorsion of the right spermatic cord

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with intermittent testicular torsion that has progressed to acute testicular torsion. Given the history of recurrent episodes and the absence of a normal attachment of the right testicle to the tunica vaginalis (i.e. bellclapper deformity), orchiopexy of both testicles is indicated to prevent future episodes of torsion and preserve testicular viability. 

When testicular torsion is suspected, obtaining an emergent surgical consult is crucial, and manual detorsion should be attempted as an interim measure. Manual detorsion involves rotating the testicle in an "open book" motion, first in a medial-to-lateral direction, aiming to restore blood flow and alleviate pain. If unsuccessful, a lateral-to-medial rotation attempt can be made. Regardless of the success of the detorsion procedure, emergent surgical consultation should be pursued. Surgical intervention involves exploration of the scrotum for detorsion and fixation with orchiectomy reserved for cases of nonviable testes. Because the anatomical anomalies predisposing to torsion occur bilaterally, contralateral orchiopexy can be considered intraoperatively.    

Option Analysis

❌ Orchiopexy of the right testicle:
Incorrect: The patient's history of recurrent torsion and the anatomical anomaly discovered intraoperatively suggests potential bilateral involvement, necessitating bilateral orchiopexy. 
❌ Orchiectomy of the right testicle:
Incorrect: Orchiectomy of the right testicle is not warranted because it is still viable and further torsion can be prevented with the appropriate intervention. 
✅ Orchiopexy of both testicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Detorsion of the right spermatic cord:
Incorrect: Detorsion without orchiopexy addresses the acute torsion but does not prevent future episodes of torsion. Orchiopexy of the bilateral testicles is warranted. 
❌ Orchiectomy of both testicles:
Incorrect: Orchiectomy of both testicles is not appropriate for this patient with right testicular pain and a viable right testicle.

questions.text:
Full-term twin girls are delivered vaginally at 37 weeks 5 days gestation. There was appropriate prenatal care and there were no significant complications during the pregnancy. The infants are taken to the newborn nursery for evaluation. Twin A is 90th percentile for weight and twin B is 23rd percentile for weight. Vital signs are appropriate for age. On examination, twin A is ruddy and dusky whereas twin B is pale. Cardiopulmonary examination in both infants is normal. Lab work is obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following most likely was a feature of the pregnancy or the delivery? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Twin A    
 Hemoglobin     18.1 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     52.9%    
 Leukocyte count     17,600/mm3    
 Platelet count     190,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     108 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     3.0%    
 Coombs test     Negative    
 Peripheral smear     Normal    
 Twin B    
 Hemoglobin     9.8 g/dL    
 Hematocrit      28.8%    
 Leukocyte count     15,7000/mm3    
 Platelet count     208,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     110 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     6.1%    
 Coombs test     Negative    
 Peripheral smear     Normal

choices.text: Maternal history of parvovirus B19 during pregnancy

questions.solution:
The twins in this vignette were born full-term but have vastly different presentations. One twin is 90th percentile for weight and ruddy, while the other twin is 23rd percentile and pale, which is concerning for twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). Lab work confirms the diagnosis since there is an intertwin hemoglobin difference ≥ 8.0 g/dL and an intertwin reticulocyte ratio >1.7. TAPS occurs in monochorionic twin gestations. 

When newborn or infant anemia is due to blood loss, history can help identify the underlying cause. There may be a history of blood loss in the peripartum period such as caused by placental abruption, or history of excessive blood draws causing iatrogenic anemia. Monochorionic twin pregnancies are at risk for TAPS and twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

When anemia is secondary to red blood cell destruction, family history is important to obtain since certain conditions, such as sickle cell disease and thalassemia, are inherited. Jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly may be seen on physical exams. During pregnancy, the mother’s blood type should always be obtained since certain blood types (i.e., O and rhesus negative) are at higher risk for ABO incompatibility.   

Option Analysis

✅ Monochorionic twin gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal history of parvovirus B19 during pregnancy:
Incorrect: Intrauterine infection with parvovirus B19 can cause fetal anemia and other complications. In this vignette, one twin is anemic, and one twin is polycythemic, making the diagnosis of twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS) most likely.  
❌ Oligohydramnios:
Incorrect: Oligohydramnios occurs in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Although TTTS is similar to twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS), the intertwin reticulocyte count ratio is >1.7 making TAPS the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Maternal hemorrhage during delivery:
Incorrect: Maternal hemorrhage during delivery can cause neonatal anemia. This vignette with anemia in one twin and polycythemia in the other twin is more consistent with twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). 
❌ Placental hypoplasia:
Incorrect: This vignette with anemia in one twin and polycythemia in the other twin suggests twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). The placental findings in TAPS are small placental arteriovenous anastomoses with flow in a single direction and not placental hypoplasia.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for polydipsia and polyuria for 3 months. His parent reports that he plays basketball at school but seems to remain excessively thirsty even when not playing sports. The patient has no vomiting, diarrhea, edema, or headaches. Past medical and surgical history are non-contributory. Family history is positive for diabetes mellitus in many family members. The patient’s parent is being treated for DM type 2 that she developed in her early 30’s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. Body mass index (BMI) is at the 67th percentile. Mucous membranes are moist, and skin turgor is normal. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c)     7%    
 Fasting blood glucose      140 mg/dL    
 C-peptide      1.26 nmol/L (reference range; 0.26 – 1.27 nmol/L)    
 Islet antibodies      Negative     
 Gene mutation     Hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-alpha
questions.solution:
This patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia, and a strong family history of diabetes mellitus including a mother who was diagnosed with DM type 2 at an early age. Laboratory findings show hyperglycemia, normal C-peptide value, and negative islet-antibody testing. A non-immune-mediated form of diabetes mellitus (DM) should be considered. The patient’s phenotypic characteristics and family history are more consistent with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) or (Monogenic diabetes) rather than type 2 DM, and the positive genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of MODY.        

Diagnostic criteria for diabetes mellitus in a symptomatic patient include hemoglobin A1C of 6.5 percent or greater; fasting blood glucose of 126 milligrams per deciliter or greater; a random blood glucose 200 milligrams per deciliter or greater; or a blood glucose during a 2-hour OGTT that is 200 milligrams per deciliter or greater. Once the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus has been established in a child, labs including a C-peptide level and islet cell autoantibodies will help determine which type of DM is present. If C-peptide levels are low and islet cell autoantibodies are positive, type I DM can be diagnosed. Normal or elevated levels of C-peptide with negative islet cell autoantibodies is suggestive of either type II DM or MODY. Patient characteristics and genetic testing can differentiate between these types.    

MODY is a type of non-immune-mediated diabetes mellitus that often presents with hyperglycemia in patients younger than 25 years old. Patients have impaired insulin secretion. A diagnosis of MODY should be considered in patients with atypical diabetes (negative diabetes-associated autoantibodies, no obesity, lack of metabolic features) and with a family history of multigenerational diabetes. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis of MODY which has autosomal dominant transmission.    

Option Analysis

❌ Type I diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: Type I diabetes mellitus can present with polyuria and polydipsia but is associated with low C-peptide levels and positive islet cell autoantibodies, which are not seen in this patient, making type I diabetes mellitus unlikely.  
❌ Type II diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: Type II diabetes mellitus (DM) can present with polyuria, polydipsia, and hyperglycemia; however, this patient does not have classic phenotypic features of type II DM and genetic testing is positive for a single gene mutation, making maturity-onset diabetes of the young the correct diagnosis.  
✅ Maturity-onset diabetes of the young :
Correct: See Main Explanation.       
❌ Cystic fibrosis-related diabetes mellitus  :
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis-related diabetes mellitus (CFRD) is a common complication of cystic fibrosis in school-aged patients and older. This patient has no past medical history of cystic fibrosis or signs of cystic fibrosis such as failure to thrive or recurrent pulmonary infections.  
❌ Diabetes insipidus :
Incorrect: Both diabetes insipidus and diabetes mellitus can cause polyuria and polydipsia; however, diabetes insipidus is caused by either lack of secretion or lack of response to anti-diuretic hormone and is not related to abnormalities of blood glucose. This patient’s hyperglycemia is indicative of diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 15-day-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of one day of fussiness and not nursing well and a rectal temperature of 38.4 °C (101.1 °F). The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation without complications. The pregnancy was unremarkable. Maternal prenatal labs (including group B streptococcus carriage) were negative. There have been no known sick exposures. Until this illness, the patient has been breastfeeding well with appropriate weight gain. Parents deny upper respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 44/min, blood pressure is 74/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears alert and fussy in parent’s arms. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is <2 second capillary refill and 2+ peripheral pulses. The patient is tachypneic without increased work of breathing. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. There is no rash. Lab work is obtained and includes complete blood count (CBC), inflammatory markers, blood culture, urinalysis, urine culture, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies and culture, and respiratory viral panel (RVP). Results are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit and start empiric intravenous Ampicillin and Ceftazidime
Admit for observation and defer antibiotics while awaiting culture results
Admit and start empiric intravenous Ampicillin and Acyclovir
Discharge home and defer antibiotics while awaiting culture results

questions.solution:
This previously healthy 15-day-old girl presents to the emergency department with fever and fussiness for <24 hours. Given this patient's age, the recommendation is to admit her for empiric intravenous (IV) antibiotics while awaiting laboratory testing results. Empiric treatment for a patient this age includes intravenous Ampicillin and Ceftazidime (+/- Acyclovir if the infant is at risk for or shows signs of herpes simplex virus).        

Patients 60 days or younger with a fever are at a higher risk of invasive bacterial infections than older infants. The initial step in management is Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) assessment to ensure the patient is stable. Patients with a fever at this age require IV access with vital sign monitoring. They may also require supplemental oxygen and vasopressors.       

The fever can be treated with acetaminophen. Additional treatment and disposition depend on the patient's specific age and on an identified source. Patients 0-21 days old with fever should always be admitted to the hospital and started on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics until a source is identified and treatment narrowed. Infants 22-60 days old with a fever should be admitted and started on empiric antibiotics if inflammatory markers are abnormal. If inflammatory markers are normal in this age group, hospital admission and empiric antibiotics depend on the patient’s clinical status, lab results, and physician preference.       

Once a source is identified, treatment is narrowed to treat the specific infection. For bacterial infections, antibiotic treatment is determined based on culture results, if available. For viral etiologies, antivirals may be necessary, or the patient may solely need supportive care such as oxygen support.   

Option Analysis

✅ Admit and start empiric intravenous Ampicillin and Ceftazidime:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Admit for observation and defer antibiotics while awaiting culture results:
Incorrect: Infants less than 21 days old with fever and no evident source of infection require empiric treatment with intravenous antibiotics while awaiting lab work results. 
❌ Admit and start empiric intravenous Ampicillin and Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Infants less than 21 days old with fever and no evident source of infection require empiric treatment with intravenous antibiotics (Ampicillin and Ceftazidime) while awaiting lab work results. The addition of Acyclovir is recommended if the infant is at increased risk for HSV (e.g., mom with active lesions) or the patient presents with vesicles, seizures, hypothermia, or mucus membrane lesions. 
❌ Discharge home and defer antibiotics while awaiting culture results :
Incorrect: This patient needs to be observed and started on empiric intravenous antibiotics until lab work returns due to the risk of invasive bacterial infection in infants less than 21 days old. 
❌ Discharge home on Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: This patient needs to be observed and started on empiric intravenous antibiotics until lab work returns due to the risk of invasive bacterial infection in infants less than 21 days old.

questions.text: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an observed seizure-like episode that has resolved. Parents are visibly upset and have difficulty providing a clear clinical history. They report that they had limited prenatal care. Parents report that the pediatrician believes the infant was born at 38 weeks per the Ballard score. He has been formula-feeding well and has seen the pediatrician once since discharge from the hospital. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 46/min, blood pressure is 75/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears lethargic. The anterior fontanelle is open and bulging. There are no rhinorrhea, hepatomegaly, or skeletal abnormalities. No murmur is appreciated. Pulmonary examination is normal. A rash is noted along the right shoulder and arm. Which of the following tests would confirm the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

questions.solution:
This 8-day-old patient presents with fever, lethargy, and a witnessed seizure. There is a dermatomal rash and bulging anterior fontanelle on physical examination concerning for herpes simplex virus (HSV) meningoencephalitis, which can be confirmed by HSV cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) polymerase chain reaction (PCR).        

Fever in a child 0-60 days old is typically secondary to an infectious process. These infections can present in the bloodstream, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, respiratory tract, or gastrointestinal tract. When infants <60 days old present with fever, broad-spectrum screening labs are obtained.        

Lab work for patients with bacteremia will show leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers and the diagnosis is confirmed by bacterial growth on blood culture. Lab work for a urinary tract infection (UTI) will show elevated leukocyte esterase and nitrates on urinalysis. A UTI is confirmed by >10,000 CFU from a catheterized urine specimen (when fever and pyuria are present). Occasionally, this can lead to bacteremia when untreated. Blood work for meningitis also shows leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers but will also demonstrate pleocytosis on CSF studies. A positive PCR on CSF will confirm viral meningoencephalitis, whereas bacterial growth on CSF culture will confirm bacterial meningitis.       

Chest x-ray and respiratory viral panels differentiate pneumonia from viral upper and lower respiratory tract infections. On chest x-ray, pneumonia will present as an infiltration or consolidation. Bronchiolitis, a lower respiratory tract infection, will show hyperinflation and peri-bronchial thickening, without infiltrates or consolidations on chest x-ray. Patients with upper respiratory tract infections will have normal chest x-rays. Viral respiratory infections are occasionally identified on respiratory viral panels.       

If the patient presents with fever and diarrhea and there is concern for infectious gastroenteritis, stool cultures, and viral PCRs can identify the source.   

Option Analysis

✅ Herpes simplex virus (HSV) cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) polymerase chain reaction (PCR):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rapid plasma reagin:
Incorrect: Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) serves as a screening test for syphilis. Congenital syphilis presents with hepatomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, rash, lymphadenopathy, and skeletal abnormalities. This patient’s seizures, bulging fontanelle, and dermatomal rash makes herpes simplex virus meningoencephalitis more likely, which can be confirmed with HSV PCR. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture:
Incorrect: A CSF culture would confirm bacterial meningitis. This patient’s seizures, bulging fontanelle, and dermatomal rash makes herpes simplex virus meningoencephalitis more likely, which can be confirmed with HSV PCR. 
❌ Blood culture:
Incorrect: A blood culture would confirm bacteremia. This patient’s fever, seizures, bulging fontanelle, and rash makes HSV meningoencephalitis more likely, which can be confirmed with HSV PCR. 
❌ Head computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: This patient most likely has HSV meningoencephalitis, which is best diagnosed with HSV CSF PCR. A head CT can show parenchymal brain edema or attenuation, hemorrhage, or destructive lesions but is not diagnostic for HSV meningoencephalitis and can also be normal early in the disease.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office for vaginal bleeding for three days and mucosal vaginal discharge for one week. The patient was born at full term with normal delivery to non-consanguineous parents. The patient has a history of multiple fractures. She has no surgical history, and she does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Weight is at 95th percentile for age, height is at 60th percentile for age, and head circumference is at 66th percentile for age. Skin examination reveals the skin lesions shown below. Breast development is at Tanner stage II and pubic and axillary hair is at Tanner stage I and female genitalia with signs of maturation. Abdominal and cardiopulmonary exams are unremarkable. Labs show elevated growth hormone levels and prepubertal levels of gonadotropins. X-ray of the femur shows cortical thinning and ground-glass radiolucency. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s vaginal bleeding?
 

McCune-Albright syndrome” by Claudia E Dumitrescu, Michael T Collins. Orphanet Journal of Rare Diseases. 3, 12. 2008. Licensed under CC BY 2.0. Reproduced from Wikipedia.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of precocious puberty, including breast and genitalia maturation and vaginal bleeding. She also has café-au-lait skin lesions and X-ray findings consistent with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone. She is found to have prepubertal levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating (FSH) and estrogen. She most likely has McCune-Albright syndrome.

Precocious puberty is defined as pubertal development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 in biological females and age 9 in biological males. Precocious puberty can be classified as central or peripheral. In peripheral precocious puberty, the HPG axis has not been activated, so lab work will show prepubertal results (i.e. low luteinizing hormone [LH] and follicle-stimulating hormone [FSH] levels with elevated estradiol and testosterone levels).

McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is defined as a triad of peripheral precocious puberty, café-au-lait skin pigmentation, and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone (PFD). It is associated with other endocrinopathies, including hyperthyroidism, growth hormone (GH) excess, renal phosphate wasting with or without rickets, and Cushing syndrome. Biological females presenting with premature episodic vaginal bleeding consistent with menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for features of MAS. In MAS, the cafe-au-lait spots have irregular borders with characteristic “coast of Maine” appearance and are often isolated to one side of the body. The skeletal disease (PFD) almost always involves the proximal femurs and the skull base. If the diagnosis of MAS is suspected based on skin findings and lab work consistent with peripheral precocious puberty, then X-rays or CT scans of the affected bones should be performed. If imaging demonstrates expanded bone with a ground glass appearance, this indicates fibrous dysplasia, and together, these findings confirm the diagnosis of MAS.    

Option Analysis

❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically presents with virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females and salt wasting. This patient has no signs of virilization or ambiguous genitalia. She has cafe au lait spots, precocious puberty, signs of fibrous dysplasia, and prepubertal level of labs, making McCune Albright syndrome more likely. 
❌ Idiopathic central precocious puberty :
Incorrect: Idiopathic central precocious puberty is the most common cause of central precocious puberty in biological females. Patients present with signs of precocious puberty without neurological signs and symptoms and with pubertal levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating (FSH), and estrogen. In this patient, the presence of cafe au lait spots, precocious puberty, and signs of fibrous dysplasia with prepubertal level of labs make McCune Albright syndrome more likely.  
✅ McCune Albright syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurofibromatosis  :
Incorrect: Patients with neurofibromatosis (NF) present with café-au-lait spots with smooth regular borders resembling the “coast of California” located on the neck and lower back without associated skeletal involvement and with associated optic gliomas and iris hamartomas. This patient has cafe au lait spots with irregular borders, precocious puberty, and signs of fibrous dysplasia with prepubertal level of labs, making McCune Albright syndrome more likely. 
❌ Ovarian tumor:
Incorrect: Patients with ovarian tumors may present with vaginal bleeding and findings of an adnexal or abdominal mass on physical exam. This patient has vaginal bleeding and other signs of precocious puberty with café-au-lait spots, radiological signs of skeletal disease, and prepubertal levels of hormones making McCune Albright syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of breast enlargement over the past four months and significant height increase over the past five months. She has no history of headaches, neurological deficits, visual problems, or behavioral changes. Family history is unremarkable, and the pregnancy and perinatal period was uneventful. She has met all her developmental milestones. At the current visit, height is at the 99th percentile for age and weight is at the 87th percentile for age. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 99/56 mmHg. Physical exam reveals an elevated areolar mound above the contour of the breasts, thin pubic hair, and no axillary hair. On abdominal examination, no masses are noted. A radiograph of the left hand and wrist reveals bone age of 9 years. She has pubertal levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and estradiol. Thyroid studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide reassurance without the need for further testing

questions.solution:
This 5-year-old patient with symptoms and signs of precocious puberty and pubertal range luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and estradiol has central precocious puberty (CPP). A brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is indicated at this time. If MRI shows no abnormalities and thyroid studies are normal, then the diagnosis of idiopathic CPP can be made.

CPP is defined as the full activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis before 8 years of age in biological females and 9 in biological males. The diagnosis may be considered in biological females who have progressive breast development and increased linear growth velocity, as seen in this patient with Tanner stage IV breast development and rapidly increasing height velocity. Brain tumors, such as glial and germ cell tumors; head trauma; cranial irradiation; and subarachnoid cysts may cause CPP. These patients may present with frequent headaches and visual deficits.

Pubertal levels of LH and FSH and estradiol (F) or testosterone (M) is the most reliable screening for CPP. Stimulation testing with a GnRH analog may be required in some cases. When CPP is diagnosed, severe hypothyroidism should be excluded by obtaining thyroid labs. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be performed, especially for females younger than 6 years old with signs of precocious puberty, such as in this patient, or if there are any neurological signs. Brain MRI is used to rule out structural abnormalities, such as hypothalamic hamartoma or pituitary tumors. If brain MRI is normal and thyroid studies are normal, idiopathic CPP can be diagnosed, which is the most common cause of central precocious puberty in biological females.   

Option Analysis

❌ Measure dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) level :
Incorrect: Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) should be ordered in patients with signs of virilization, such as hirsutism, clitoromegaly, acne, and deepening of the voice, to help differentiate non-classical congenital adrenal hyperplasia from adrenal tumors. 
❌ Measure alpha fetoprotein (AFP) level :
Incorrect: Alpha fetoprotein can be measured to evaluate for ovarian tumors, which can lead to peripheral precocious puberty. This patient has no pelvic masses and the pubertal levels of LH, FSH, and estradiol make central precocious puberty (CPP) more likely in this case.  
✅ Obtain brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound may be helpful to exclude ovarian tumors in biological females with precocious puberty. These patients typically present with vaginal bleeding, abdominal or adnexal masses, and prepubertal hormone levels, which are not seen in this case. This patient has pubertal hormone levels. 
❌ Provide reassurance without the need for further testing :
Incorrect: Reassurance in a patient with suspected central precocious puberty (CPP) based on lab work results is not appropriate. Central nervous system (CNS) processes should be ruled out and some patients may need treatment with gonadotropin hormone-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogs because untreated CPP may result in premature cessation of growth and short stature.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain for eight days. He has had more than five episodes of diarrhea per day and bright red blood was noted to be mixed in the stool today. He had mild nausea at the onset of the illness but has not vomited. The patient reports that he ate grilled chicken last week at a restaurant that recently was in the news for having a Campylobacter outbreak. He does not have any chronic medical conditions. He has not taken antibiotics recently and has not travelled. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg. On examination, the patient is awake and alert. Mucus membranes are mildly dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits other than mild tachycardia. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies are shown below. A stool sample is collected. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory values    
 Hemoglobin     13.5 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     39.3%    
 Leukocyte count     7,800/mm3    
 Platelet count     242,000/mm3    
 Sodium      139 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     24 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen     18 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     1.0 mg/dL    
 Glucose     75 mg/dL    
 Calcium     9.1 mg/dL    
 Potassium      3.7 mEq/L

choices.text: Intravenous rehydration and fecal calprotectin testing

questions.solution:
This child presenting with bloody diarrhea and fever after consuming poultry during a Campylobacter outbreak likely has bacterial gastroenteritis. Given his stable vital signs, mild dehydration without electrolyte abnormalities, and lack of vomiting, a trial of oral rehydration is the best initial approach to rehydration. Antibiotics are rarely indicated in cases of acute gastroenteritis; but given this child’s fever, bloody stools, and length of the illness, it is reasonable to start empiric antibiotic treatment with azithromycin.  

The acute management of a pediatric patient with diarrhea depends first on the child's stability. Diarrhea can cause severe hypovolemia, critical electrolyte disturbances, and significant blood loss, all of which require emergent correction. The management of a child in stable condition with mild or moderate dehydration begins with rehydration therapy, preferably by the oral route. Evidence suggests that patients with gastroenteritis can maintain a regular diet, as food restrictions, such as avoidance of dairy or solid foods, have not been shown to be of benefit. Loperamide should be avoided in children with diarrhea when bloody stools or fever are present as it can prolong the length and worsen the severity of infection. Most cases of bacterial gastroenteritis are self-limited; antibiotics are typically reserved for patients with severe disease or those who are at risk for severe disease (e.g. immunocompromised). Signs of severe disease include bloody stools, high fever, evidence of extraintestinal infection, worsening symptoms, and symptoms lasting longer than one week. 

Option Analysis

✅ Oral rehydration and oral azithromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral rehydration and loperamide:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration is the preferred method of rehydration therapy in stable patients with mild dehydration, normal electrolytes, and no emesis. However, loperamide should be avoided given the bloody stools and fever seen in this patient. There is concern that loperamide can prolong the length and worsen the severity of infection. 
❌ Intravenous rehydration and fecal calprotectin testing:
Incorrect: A trial of oral rehydration is preferred in most stable children with gastroenteritis. Fecal calprotectin is used to evaluate patients with chronic diarrhea that contains blood to evaluate for inflammatory bowel disease. This patient’s short duration of symptoms and presumed source of infection is more suggestive of an infectious cause of diarrhea, and a fecal calprotectin is not necessary. 
❌  Intravenous rehydration and intravenous ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Given this child’s mild dehydration and hemodynamic stability, a trial of oral rehydration is preferable. This patient does not require intravenous antibiotics. Oral azithromycin is appropriate and would be preferred over ciprofloxacin given this patient’s age.  
❌ Intravenous rehydration and supportive care:
Incorrect: Given this child’s mild dehydration and hemodynamic stability, a trial of oral rehydration is preferable to intravenous fluids. Additionally, this patient would benefit from antibiotics, given the bloody stools, fever, and length of illness. Since he is also at risk for infection with Campylobacter, azithromycin is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to left leg pain. During the past four months, she has been experiencing left thigh pain that is worse at night and aggravated by movement. She did not have an associated injury or trauma to the area prior to symptom onset. She has also had intermittent night sweats and an unintentional weight loss of 8 lbs. (3.6 kg). Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), heart rate is 96/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 103/61 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness to palpation of the left proximal thigh with overlying erythema and a palpable tender mass. Plain radiographs of the left femur show a large lytic lesion with a poorly defined border and a periosteal reaction with an “onion peel” appearance. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old girl presents with a four-month history of atraumatic left thigh pain that is worse at night and associated with night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals a palpable, tender mass with overlying erythema, and plain radiographs showed a lytic lesion with poorly defined borders and periosteal reaction. These findings strongly suggest an aggressive or malignant bone tumor, such as Ewing sarcoma. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be performed next to help make the diagnosis, followed by bone biopsy for confirmation and staging and likely additional imaging to evaluate for metastases.

Plain radiographs can be initially used when bone lesions are suspected to assess for high-risk features (e.g., poorly defined borders, lytic or sclerotic lesion, periosteal reaction) that suggest malignant or aggressive/ destructive lesions (i.e., aneurysmal bone cyst). If any high-risk findings are detected on radiography as in this case, then MRI should be performed next to help make the diagnosis. Bone biopsy should be performed for histologic confirmation and staging. Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcomas and Ewing sarcomas. Aneurysmal bone cysts are aggressive non-malignant bone tumors that can have high-risk findings on radiographs.

Benign bone tumors often have characteristic radiograph features and can be diagnosed by radiograph alone. Further evaluation may include MRI and computed tomography (CT) if the lesions are not benign based on radiography or are in areas that are hard to see with a radiograph such as the spine, scapula, ribs, or pelvis.
   

Image courtesy of STATdx 
Figure 1. Classic case of Ewing sarcoma (ES) of the long bone in a 12-year-old boy is shown. There is a permeative lesion in the distal fibular diaphysis (white solid arrow) associated with lamellar periosteal reaction also known as onion skinning (white open arrow) and cortex disruption (white curved arrow).  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT)  :
Incorrect: While CT can be useful to localize a bone lesion and assess its characteristics, it does not provide the accuracy and resolution that an MRI provides for visualizing bone tumors. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and further imaging via MRI is warranted.  
❌ Radionuclide bone scan :
Incorrect: A radionuclide bone scan is used to evaluate the entire skeleton for metastases. It is not useful for diagnosing a primary bone tumor. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion. 
❌ Positron emission tomography (PET)  :
Incorrect: PET imaging is used to assess distant metastases and for staging. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion. 
❌ Ultrasonography :
Incorrect: Ultrasound is helpful for diagnosing disorders of soft tissue structures, but it is not used to diagnose bone lesions. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with 3 days of fever and lymphadenopathy. The patient has not had a sore throat, rhinorrhea, or cough and has no known sick contacts. She has not been traveling. She volunteers at an animal shelter in her free time. She has no significant past medical history. Weight is 37th percentile, height is 58th percentile. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 111/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. After the physical examination, blood work is performed which is positive for Bartonella hensalae. Which of the following findings on lymph node examination would be most consistent with the underlying condition?

choices.text: Single tender erythematous cervical lymph node
Immobile, nontender matted cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and exposure to cats at an animal shelter. Laboratory studies are consistent with infection with Bartonella henelsae, which is the causative agent in Cat-scratch disease. This disease results in regional lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis (erythematous, tender lymph nodes) typically in the cervical or axillary regions. The hallmark of the disease is regional lymphadenopathy proximal to the site of inoculation. A single tender erythematous cervical lymph node is seen in many cases. 

The differential diagnosis for peripheral lymphadenopathy in children is broad and patients should initially be assessed for signs and symptoms of malignancy. Symptoms concerning malignancy include fever, night sweats, weight loss, bleeding, bruising, and pallor. Lymph node exam typically demonstrates enlarged lymph nodes that are non-tender, firm, and immobile. They may also be matted. The work-up for malignancy includes blood work (including a peripheral smear), chest x-ray, and biopsy. 

If malignancy is ruled out, the next step is to rule out autoimmune diseases that can cause lymphadenopathy. These diseases are typically associated with non-tender, mobile lymph nodes and systemic symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and rash. Physical exam can aid in the diagnosis (e.g., a malar rash is consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus). Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis but for other autoimmune diseases, blood work is often necessary to establish a diagnosis (e.g., Lupus confirmed by the presence of anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-smith antibodies). 

If autoimmune disease is ruled out as the cause of lymphadenopathy, infectious processes should be considered. Lymphadenitis tends to present with a single, erythematous, tender lymph node. Localized infections can cause regional lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenitis and local infections with regional lymphadenopathy tend to be clinical diagnoses; however, if lymphadenitis does not respond to empiric treatment, then further evaluation with a lymph node biopsy or serologic testing for Bartonella henselae is necessary. Viral illnesses can cause generalized lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms and testing for specific viruses can be done with serologies and PCR. However, because they are often self-limited, viral testing may not always be done.   

Option Analysis

✅ Single tender erythematous cervical lymph node:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Generalized lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Generalized lymphadenopathy is found in systemic infections such as viral infections. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Tender bilateral cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: Tender bilateral cervical lymph nodes can be found with a localized infection of the head and neck such as bilateral otitis media or strep pharyngitis. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Immobile, nontender matted cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: Immobile nontender matted lymph nodes are associated with malignancy. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Nontender supraclavicular lymph nodes :
Incorrect: Nontender Supraclavicular lymph nodes are typically associated with malignancy. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the office for a routine school physical. The patient looks anxious and says that she has never had a menstrual cycle and is worried. She has noticed that her breasts appear smaller than her peers. There is no history of headaches, smell or visual disturbances, exposure to radiation, or nipple discharge. There is no history of sexual development problems within the family. Height and weight are at the 5th and 50th percentile for her age, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 117/79 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals wide spaced nipples with a webbed neck. Axillary and pubic hair are absent, and the breasts are at Tanner stage I. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is the best test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 15-year-old girl with delayed puberty and physical exam findings of short stature with wide-spaced nipples and a webbed neck likely has Turner syndrome. Karyotyping should be performed to diagnose Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a sex chromosome disorder caused by the loss of part or all of an X chromosome that leads to ovarian insufficiency. Genotypes 45, XO, 45, X with mosaicism, ring chromosome, or 46, XX can lead to Turner syndrome. 

The most consistent characteristic in girls with Turner syndrome is short stature. Turner syndrome often leads to primary hypogonadism, and it is a major cause of premature ovarian failure. Most affected girls have no breast development and primary amenorrhea. Other characteristics include a "shield" chest with the appearance of widely spaced nipples, a short, webbed neck, and cubitus valgus. Neonates may have congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet and webbed neck. Other associations with Turner syndrome include cardiovascular abnormalities such as bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta and autoimmune diseases.

Patients with delayed puberty should be evaluated with gonadotropin and sex hormone levels. Because of lack of appropriate development of the ovaries, patients with Turner syndrome can have elevated levels of FSH and LH and low levels of estradiol (i.e., Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

Patients with characteristic features of Turner syndrome should have a karyotype analysis. If genotypes 45, XO, 45, X with mosaicism, ring chromosome, or 46, XX are found, the diagnosis of Turner syndrome is confirmed.    

Option Analysis

❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Incorrect: Brain MRI is useful to diagnose CNS tumors in patients with delayed puberty and neurological signs such as headaches or visual disturbances who may have a prolactinoma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.  
❌ Insulin growth factor-1 (IGF) level  :
Incorrect: Low insulin growth factor-1 (IGF) level can help diagnose growth hormone deficiency as the cause of delayed puberty. This patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.  
✅ Karyotyping :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prolactin level:
Incorrect: Prolactin levels are used to diagnose hyperprolactinemia and prolactinoma, which can cause delayed puberty. This patient does not have gynecomastia, nipple discharge, or neurological signs suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, making it a less probable cause in this case. 
❌ TSH and free T4 levels:
Incorrect: These tests can be used to diagnose hypothyroidism, which can cause delayed puberty, but this patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl is following up after 2+ proteinuria was found on a prior visit at which the patient was being evaluated for increased urinary frequency. The rest of the urine dip at that time was negative, and the symptoms resolved. The patient is well-developed and well-nourished. There is no joint pain, recent infections, rashes, dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency, fever, or medication use. Past medical and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37� C (98.6�F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. No edema is noted. Repeat dipstick results are shown below. Which of the following tests should be performed next to confirm the likely diagnosis?  

 Laboratory value     Results     
 Specific gravity     1.015      
 pH     6      
 Protein     2+     
 Glucose     Negative      
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative      
 Nitrite     Negative      
 WBCs     1-5 /hpf      
 RBCs     2-5 /hpf
questions.solution:
This patient with proteinuria on a urine sample, and no evidence of edema, recent infections, or hypertension most likely has orthostatic proteinuria. The next best test to confirm the diagnosis is to obtain a first-morning void sample for protein creatinine ratio.        

Proteinuria in children can be classified as transient, orthostatic, or persistent. Orthostatic proteinuria, also known as postural proteinuria, is characterized by increased protein excretion while patients are in the upright position, which returns to normal when the patient is supine. Orthostatic proteinuria is a common cause of proteinuria in adolescents. Patients with orthostatic proteinuria are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally when a urinalysis is done for an unrelated condition or as part of routine care.        
If a child or adolescent presents with proteinuria, repeat urine dipstick should be performed. If the protein is not present on repeat urine dipstick tests, transient proteinuria can be diagnosed. If proteinuria is found on repeat testing, then the urine protein-creatinine ratio in a first-morning void sample should be compared to random spot urine collected after at least an hour of being upright and moving around. A normal urine protein-creatinine ratio on the first-morning void and an elevated ratio on a random specimen confirm the diagnosis of orthostatic proteinuria. However, if the proteinuria does not resolve and is consistently elevated throughout the day, diagnose persistent proteinuria, and assess the underlying cause by obtaining a urinalysis with microscopy, serum albumin, lipid panel, and complement levels.    

Option Analysis

✅ First-morning void urine protein-creatinine ratio :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Renal ultrasound :
Incorrect: Renal ultrasound can help determine the etiology of recurrent febrile urinary tract infections which can include gross anatomic abnormalities or pyelonephritis. This patient has no evidence of infection and is more likely to have orthostatic proteinuria, which can be confirmed with first-morning void urine protein-creatinine ratio. 
❌ Urine culture :
Incorrect: Urine culture is useful for diagnosing urinary tract infections which commonly present with dysuria, urgency, frequency, fever. And nitrites and leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. This patient most likely has orthostatic proteinuria, and a urine culture will not be helpful in the diagnosis. A first-morning void urine protein-creatinine ratio should be ordered next. 
❌ Lipid panel  :
Incorrect: Lipid panel is commonly used to help confirm nephrotic syndrome if it shows hyperlipidemia. This patient’s presentation is consistent with orthostatic proteinuria, which can be confirmed by the first-morning void urine protein-creatinine ratio.  
❌ Renal biopsy  :
Incorrect: Renal biopsy is commonly used to confirm nephrotic or nephritic syndromes causing proteinuria, which can present with edema, rashes, hypertension, and gross hematuria. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with orthostatic proteinuria, which can be confirmed by obtaining first-morning void urine protein-creatinine ratio.

questions.text: A 7-day-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for poor feeding, pallor, and mildly increased work of breathing. The infant was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 8 and 9. The baby had been feeding well until last night. Since then, she has been tired and uninterested in bottle feeding. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 52/min. Right upper extremity blood pressure is 84/55 mmHg and right upper extremity oxygen saturation is 99%. Right lower extremity blood pressure is 64/42 mm Hg and right lower extremity oxygen saturation is 94%. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and irritable and has increased work of breathing, she is tachypneic and exhibits belly breathing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. A systolic murmur is heard and best appreciated at the left upper sternal border just below the left scapula. An S3 is present, and femoral pulses are faint. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 7-day-old girl has new-onset pallor, poor feeding, and increased work of breathing. Vital signs show a discrepancy between the pre- and post-ductal blood pressure and oxygen saturation. Physical examination findings include systolic murmur and faint femoral pulses. Together, these findings are consistent with critical coarctation of the aorta. The first step in management is administration of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent.       

The first step in managing patients with acyanotic congenital heart defect is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment and stabilize the patient. This may include intubation, intravenous access, continuous vital sign monitoring, supplemental oxygen, and ionotropic support.       

Once the patient is stable, further evaluation including an echocardiogram is required to diagnose the underlying congenital heart defect. Subsequent management depends on the specific defect and the severity of symptoms. Some congenital heart defects require only frequent monitoring, whereas others require surgical intervention.      

Differential cyanosis refers to when the pre-ductal oxygen saturation is higher than the post-ductal. This finding is consistent with a critical left ventricular outflow tract obstruction such as critical aortic stenosis or critical coarctation of the aorta. Patients with these congenital heart defects can be dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus for systemic circulation, and therefore, PGE1 should be administered expeditiously in these cases.   

Option Analysis

✅ Prostaglandin E1 infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Surgery:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical evidence of critical coarctation of the aorta. The patient will require surgery, but the first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. 
❌ Balloon angioplasty :
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta. The first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. The patient will need invasive intervention. Surgical repair is preferred over balloon angioplasty since surgical repair is associated with lower risk of reintervention. 
❌ Dopamine infusion:
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta and initial intervention includes prostaglandin E1 infusion. If the patient had signs of associated heart failure, intravenous inotropic support (e.g., dopamine) would be necessary. This patient does not have associated findings to suggest heart failure. 
❌ Stent placement :
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta and the first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. Stent placement is occasionally performed in older patients following balloon angioplasty or surgery but would not be the initial treatment in this patient.
