questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with his parents for evaluation of several months of worsening constipation and fatigue. The patient has tried limiting dairy and increasing fruit and fiber in his diet. Over-the-counter laxatives were also tried with minimal improvement in symptoms. The patient reports intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has received all age-appropriate well-childcare. Weight is 8th percentile and height is 12th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing boy in no acute distress. Abdomen is soft and nontender, there are normoactive bowel sounds, and stool is palpated in the left lower quadrant. Rectal examination does not demonstrate evidence of fissures, hemorrhoids, masses, or fecal impaction. There is an itchy papular vesicular rash on the extensor surfaces of the patient’s knees. Which of the following would likely be present on further questioning?

choices.text: History of delayed passage of meconium
Exposure to a home built in 1956 in the United States

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of constipation that has persisted despite dietary modifications and laxative therapy. The patient’s short stature, intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting, and dermatitis herpetiformis rash make celiac disease the likely diagnosis. Upon further questioning, this patient may report noticing a sensitivity to gluten. 

A focused history and physical examination for a pediatric patient with constipation is important. The history begins with an assessment of the frequency of bowel movements, ease of defecation, and stool consistency. The Bristol stool chart can be used by patients to identify stool consistency.

It is important to ask about medication or toxin exposure associated with constipation. Specifically, patients and families should be questioned regarding potential opiates, antacid, iron, or lead exposure. A review of systems should include questions about systemic symptoms, such as fatigue, rashes, or cold intolerance. A patient’s growth chart can also provide information regarding the underlying cause of constipation.

On physical examination, assessment should include auscultation and palpation of the abdomen. In patients with constipation, stool is often palpated in the left lower abdominal quadrant. A perianal examination is important at all ages, and in newborns, a digital rectal examination should be performed. A neurological examination offers information regarding whether a spinal cord abnormality is causing constipation. Physical examinations should be thorough and include dermatologic and thyroid evaluations.   

Option Analysis

✅ Sensitivity to gluten:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of delayed passage of meconium:
Incorrect: Timing of meconium passage is a key historical element when constipation presents in the newborn period. This patient is 16 years old and has a rash consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the likely cause of constipation and fatigue.  
❌ Family history of neurologic disease:
Incorrect: Neurologic diseases such as Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis can be associated with constipation. However, this patient is young and does not have any signs or symptoms of neurologic disease. This patient likely has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the likely cause of constipation and fatigue. 
❌ Cold intolerance:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause constipation and cold intolerance. However, this patient likely has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Exposure to a home built in 1956 in the United States:
Incorrect: The United States passed legislation in 1978 banning the manufacture of lead-based house paint. Exposure to a home built before this time increases the risk of lead poisoning. High levels of lead can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, such as constipation. This patient's age and lack of other symptoms makes lead poisoning unlikely. This patient has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the primary care office with her parent for a sports physical. She recently recovered from stress fractures of her 4th and 5th metatarsals. She has no residual symptoms and follow-up x-ray demonstrated complete resolution. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) was done after the fractures and her Z-score was -2.0. The patient participates in gymnastics 5-6 days per week. She has never had a concussion and does not experience exertional symptoms with exercise. There is no family history of sudden cardiac death. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. Height is 5 ft 1 inch (154.9 cm), weight is 83 lbs (37.6 kg), body mass index is 15.7 kg/m2 (4th percentile for her age). On examination, the patient is alert and conversant. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs, gallops, or bruits. Pulmonary exam is within normal limits. The feet are non-tender bilaterally with full range of motion of all joints. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following additional clinical findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient experienced metatarsal stress fractures in the setting of decreased bone mineral density (BMD). Given her age, low body mass index (BMI), and active participation in gymnastics, the female athlete triad is the most likely diagnosis. The third clinical feature of the female athlete triad is menstrual dysfunction, making amenorrhea the most likely additional clinical finding in this patient.         

Assessing BMI is an important part of the sports physical. Low BMI can suggest conditions such as disordered eating or female athlete triad. The female athlete triad is a phenomenon characterized by low energy availability from decreased caloric intake or excessive energy expenditure (with or without disordered eating); menstrual dysfunction; and decreased BMI. Biologically, female athletes who participate in sports that emphasize leanness, such as endurance running, ballet, and gymnastics, are especially susceptible to the female athlete triad. These athletes, and those with disordered eating, may still be able to participate in sports, but they may require psychiatric and other medical assessments before it is safe to do so.        

Additional items to ask about when doing a sports physical include history of previous injuries or concussions; screening for signs and symptoms of cardiovascular disease in the patient, family history of genetic cardiac conditions, history of sudden or unexplained cardiac death; screening for mental health conditions and substance abuse including use of performance-enhancing substances. The physical examination should include BMI, blood pressure, vision and hearing, a head-to-toe musculoskeletal and basic neurologic exam, complete cardiac exam including distal pulses, assessment for phenotypic features of Marfan syndrome, and a chaperoned testicular exam in biologically male patients.    

Option Analysis

✅ Amenorrhea:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acne:
Incorrect: Acne can be seen in conditions of androgen excess, which can cause amenorrhea; however, this patient has a decreased body mass index (BMI) and low bone mineral density (BMD) which are consistent with the female athlete triad of low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and decreased BMD.  
❌ Hirsutism :
Incorrect: Hirsutism may be seen in states of androgen excess, which can cause amenorrhea, but patients with androgen excess typically present with central weight gain. This patient has a low body mass index and signs and symptoms consistent with the female athlete’s triad of low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and decreased BMD.   
❌ Pectus excavatum:
Incorrect: Pectus excavatum is a phenotypic feature that may be seen in Marfan syndrome. Additional clinical manifestations of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, arachnodactyly, cardiac anomalies, and an abnormally long arm span. This patient does not have clinical features suggestive of Marfan syndrome, making pectus excavatum unlikely to be seen on physical exam.  
❌ Tachycardia :
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation and findings are consistent with the female athlete triad. Bradycardia, not tachycardia, is an associated finding with the female athlete triad.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a sore throat. The patient was treated as an outpatient for strep throat based on clinical findings without strep testing, one week ago, but she has not had improvement in symptoms despite taking amoxicillin as prescribed. She has a history of allergic rhinitis controlled with a nasal steroid spray. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 131/67 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals erythema and swelling of the tonsils with exudates bilaterally. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Heterophile antibody testing, and rapid influenza testing are negative. Rapid strep is negative, and gram stain comes back positive for gram-negative cocci. NAAT is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pharyngitis that has been unresponsive to initial empiric therapy targeted against Streptococcus sp. Given that the patient is sexually active and has gram-negative cocci isolated from the throat, she likely has gonococcal pharyngitis and should be treated with intramuscular ceftriaxone.        

Pharyngitis or inflammation of the pharynx can be caused by non-infectious conditions, like allergic rhinitis, as well as viral and bacterial infections. Treatment of pharyngitis depends on the likely underlying cause. Non-infectious causes such as allergic pharyngitis and pharyngitis caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease can be treated with antihistamines and acid-reducing medications, respectively. Viral pharyngitis is typically self-limited and will resolve without intervention. The level of care needed for pharyngitis caused by bacteria is dependent on the location and severity of the infection. Pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus can be treated with oral antibiotics, while parenteral antibiotic therapy is preferred for infections caused by Gonococcal species. If it is caused by bacterial infection and there is an associated fluid collection (peritonsillar or retropharyngeal abscess), the airway may be threatened, and drainage, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and surgical consultation are typically necessary.        

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid will not provide appropriate coverage for treatment of gonococcal pharyngitis. This patient requires therapy with high dose ceftriaxone. 
❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Patients with influenza can present with a sore throat, typically along with nasal congestion, cough, and fever. However, this patient tested negative for influenza. Therefore, there is no indication of treatment with oseltamivir. 
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: While dexamethasone may provide symptomatic relief for pharyngitis, it will not treat the likely underlying gonococcal infection, for which antibiotics are needed. 
❌ Cetirizine:
Incorrect: Cetirizine is an antihistamine appropriate for treating allergic rhinitis. However, this sexually active patient with findings consistent with gonococcal pharyngitis and gram stain positive for gram-negative cocci should be treated with ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 5-hour-old male neonate is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit. He was born following an uncomplicated pregnancy and vaginal delivery, with APGAR scores of 5 and 5 (at birth and after 5 minutes, respectively). During evaluation, he develops asynchronous muscle contractions with generalized myoclonus. The patient is urgently intubated; blood samples are drawn for laboratory studies, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) is started. What is the best first-line anticonvulsant medication for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing a neonatal seizure. Neonatal seizures are the most common neurological emergency in the neonate. As opposed to adult seizures, pediatric seizures have a different pathophysiology. Most commonly, areas of hypoxia or ischemia within the white matter act as a focus of seizure activity in a condition broadly defined as hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).        

Although the use of barbiturates has been linked to cognitive and developmental defects, they are still the preferred first line medication for treating neonatal seizures due to their ability to reduce seizure activity in approximately 50% of patients. Bumetanide, a loop diuretic, has been proposed as an alternative or off-label adjunct therapy to phenobarbital; however, it has not been shown to have any benefit when compared to phenobarbital alone.   

Option Analysis

❌ Clonidine  :
Incorrect: Clonidine is a partial alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of hypertension. It can also be helpful in managing alcohol or drug withdrawal symptoms, but it does not treat seizures. 
✅ Phenobarbital :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lorazepam :
Incorrect: Lorazepam is an intermediate acting benzodiazepine used as an anxiolytic and anticonvulsant. Although benzodiazepines are often used in managing seizures in adults, barbiturates are the preferred first-line treatment for neonatal seizures (See Main Explanation.). 
❌ Zolpidem :
Incorrect: Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonist (NBBRA), also called a “hypnotic.” This class of drugs acts on the BZ-1 subtype of GABA receptors, which allosterically increases the frequency of gabanergic potentiation. Zolpidem is used in the treatment of insomnia and is not used to treat seizures.        
❌ Flumazenil :
Incorrect: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist which functions to reverse CNS depression and hasten recovery in patients with benzodiazepine overdose.

questions.text: A 10-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department accompanied by her older sibling for evaluation of diaper rash. The 18-year-old sibling states that the patient has been crying and inconsolable for the past two days due to the rash. They report the patient has otherwise been in her usual state of health. The patient lives with her sibling and both parents. The sibling states their parents have been out of town for the past few days. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and is behind on well-child care. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/42 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is crying in her sibling’s arms. The patient is unwashed and is wearing stained and ill-fitting clothing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. The patient has evidence of severe diaper dermatitis with denuded skin. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the probable cause of this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Bruising around the torso, ears, and neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of neglect, including severe diaper dermatitis, evidence of inappropriate clothing, and poor hygiene. Neglect includes insufficient medical, nutritional, educational, or emotional care. History of poor school attendance and delays in care as well as physical examination findings of poor weight gain, dental caries, and severe diaper dermatitis can be seen in patients who experience neglect.        

The history and physical examinations help identify the specific type of non-accidental trauma that children have suffered. Signs of physical abuse include trauma in nonmobile infants or fractures in non-ambulatory children. Patients may present with suspicious injuries such as handprints, bite marks, or cigarette burns, or appear in a suspicious pattern like circumferential burns (see below). Patients who have been physically abused may have marks or bruising in unusual locations such as on the torso, neck, mouth, or ears. Non-accidental trauma should be suspected when fractures of the posterior or lateral ribs, scapulae, or vertebrae are present if metaphyseal “corner” or “bucket-handle” fractures are seen on radiographs, or if there is evidence of multiple fractures in various stages of healing.        

Sexual abuse can cause age-inappropriate sexual behaviors, dysuria, enuresis, or genital injuries. Patients with psychological abuse may present with somatic complaints, anxiety or depression, declining school performance, or developmental regression. Medical child abuse occurs when the caregiver is responsible for a child receiving unnecessary and potentially harmful medical care and may be suspected when caregivers repeatedly seek care and are unsatisfied with the care provided.        

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.  


Image 1. Handprints 


Image 2. Cigarette burns 

Option Analysis

✅ Poor weight gain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Circumferential burn marks  :
Incorrect: This patient's history and physical exam are concerning for neglect due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, rather than physical abuse. Physical abuse should be suspected in children with circumferential burn marks, while poor weight gain is commonly associated with neglect. 
❌ Genital injury:
Incorrect: Genital injury may be seen in patients who experience sexual abuse. This patient has a history and findings that are more consistent with neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, which is often associated with poor weight gain.  
❌ Bruising around the torso, ears, and neck:
Incorrect: This patient's history is more concerning for neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, rather than physical abuse. Poor weight gain is commonly associated with neglect. 
❌ Developmental regression :
Incorrect: Developmental regression can occur in older children who experience psychological abuse. This patient has a history and exam that are more consistent with neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, which is often associated with poor weight gain.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with her mother for a well-child visit. The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been experiencing abdominal pain. The patient states that the symptoms have been ongoing for months and have worsened over the past few weeks. The parent states the patient was recently evaluated by pediatric gastroenterology and had normal laboratory evaluation and other studies. The patient reports generalized anxiety. She used to be a straight A student, but over the past year, she has started failing two of her classes. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. Her parents are in an acrimonious divorce. The patient spends most of her time at her mother’s house but spends occasional weekends with her father. The abdominal pain is worse after she has stayed at her father’s home. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and is clutching a stuffed teddy bear. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Skin examination does not reveal any suspicious bruising or injury. External genital examination is within normal limits without evidence of injury. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with somatic symptoms without an organic identified cause, developmental regression, anxiety, and declining school performance.  These symptoms along with a history of an acrimonious parental divorce and abdominal pain that worsens after the patient spends time with her father are concerning for psychological abuse that may be occurring in the parent's home.       

While history and physical examination are often enough to identify cases of nonaccidental trauma/neglect, if physical or sexual abuse is suspected, patients should have tailored examinations, imaging, laboratory evaluations, and documentation performed.       

Patients with suspected sexual abuse should have a genital examination for injury. Depending on the specifics of the incident, immediate forensic evaluation may be indicated. This exam should be performed by a trained provider with a trusted caregiver present within 72-100 hours of the incident and followed by appropriate documentation that may include photographs. As part of this evaluation, testing for sexually transmitted infections is usually performed. When physical abuse is suspected, images of injured areas and a skeletal survey should be performed.        

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Psychological abuse:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sexual abuse :
Incorrect: Sexual abuse can cause genital injuries and can cause children to have age-inappropriate sexualized behaviors. This patient presents with a somatic complaint (abdominal pain), anxiety, declining school performance, and developmental regression which can be seen in patients who experience psychological abuse. 
❌ Medical child abuse:
Incorrect: Medical child abuse (i.e. factitious disorder by proxy) occurs when a parent fabricates symptoms on behalf of their child that result in unnecessary testing or invasive measures. Parents frequently seek second opinions or are not satisfied when their child has relief of symptoms. This patient has only seen one gastroenterologist for abdominal pain. Her abdominal pain, anxiety, declining school performance, and developmental regression are more consistent with psychological abuse. 
❌ Physical abuse:
Incorrect: Patients who experience physical abuse often present with suspicious injury patterns or non-congruent mechanisms of injury (e.g. a fall in a non-ambulatory child). This patient has no clinical or historical evidence to support this diagnosis. This patient presents with a somatic complaint (abdominal pain), anxiety, declining school performance, and developmental regression, which can be seen with psychological abuse. 
❌ Neglect:
Incorrect: Patients who have experienced neglect often present with evidence of delays in care. There can be a history of poor growth and difficulty gaining weight. Patients will demonstrate signs of poor physical hygiene; such as tattered or worn clothing, dental caries, or severe diaper dermatitis in young infants. This patient presents with a somatic complaint (abdominal pain), anxiety, declining school performance, and developmental regression which can be seen with psychological abuse.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her parent with a concern for repeated sexual abuse. The patient's parent states that the patient reports several instances this past month when the patient’s 17-year-old stepbrother had sexually inappropriate contact with the patient. The patient reports the stepbrother touched her breasts without her consent on several occasions, the last of which was one week ago. She denies any touching beneath her underwear. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication daily. She primarily lives at home with her mother but does spend occasional weekends with her father, stepmother, and stepbrother. She is in sixth grade and performing well academically. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious with poor eye contact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Skin examination does not reveal any suspicious bruising or injury. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of sexual abuse. Once medically stabilized, the first step in treatment of all patients presenting with abuse involves informing Child Protective Services. Child Protective Services (CPS) functions to gather additional information about incidents and ensure safety plans for patients and their families.        

In addition to calling CPS, all pediatric patients with concern for abuse should have their caregivers informed and be treated by a multidisciplinary team (including behavioral health services, case managers, and specialists in the treatment of pediatric abuse).        

Sexual abuse will often involve additional medical workups and treatment. Pediatric patients concerned for sexual abuse should be assessed for signs of physical injury and pregnancy or infection requiring treatment. If certain indicators are present, patients should undergo a sexual assault examination within 72-120 hours of the incident to document findings of injury. This examination should be performed by a trained provider, chaperone, and additional caregiver at bedside. Patients should also be offered screening and empiric treatment for sexually transmitted infections.        

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Report to Child Protective Services (CPS):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consult psychiatry :
Incorrect: A multidisciplinary approach to the care of patients with sexual abuse should involve behavioral health services. However, mandatory reporting to child protective services takes precedence.  
❌ Consult case manager:
Incorrect: A multidisciplinary approach to caring for patients with sexual abuse should involve social work services. However, mandatory reporting to child protective services takes precedence. 
❌ Sexually transmitted infection (STI) testing:
Incorrect: STI testing is a core component in the management of sexual assault patients. However, this patient denies any genital involvement. Child protective services should be called next to investigate the situation.  
❌ Skeletal survey:
Incorrect: A skeletal survey does not need to be obtained in this pediatric patient who presents with concern for sexual abuse. A skeletal study is usually obtained when there is suspected physical abuse in those less than two years of age. For this case, the next step in management is getting child protective services involved.

questions.text: A newborn boy is evaluated after being delivered by c-section at 31 weeks 5 days gestation due to maternal pre-eclampsia. The pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated and there was appropriate prenatal care. Two doses of betamethasone were administered to the mother in the week before delivery. Maternal prenatal labs were negative. The infant is brought to the warmer immediately after delivery. He appears dusky and has a weak cry. Resuscitation is initiated by drying, stimulating, and warming the infant. Bulb suction is used to clear oral and nasal passages. After one minute, the heart rate is 76 bpm. On examination, there is expiratory grunting, diminished breath sounds, and bradycardia. Peripheral pulses are diminished. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is born prematurely at 31 weeks 5 days gestation due to preeclampsia. Neonatal resuscitation protocol should begin in the delivery room with drying, stimulating, warming, and bulb suctioning. This infant continues to be bradycardic and with signs of respiratory distress including grunting and diminished breath sounds. This patient’s respiratory distress is likely secondary to neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is a complication of prematurity. The best next step in the acute management of this patient is to initiate positive pressure ventilation. 

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants, especially for infants born before 32 weeks' gestation. It is secondary to surfactant deficiency, which is produced by alveolar cells starting at 24-26 weeks' gestation and reaching mature levels at 34-36 weeks' gestation. Newborn patients with respiratory distress syndrome present with progressive respiratory insufficiency shortly after birth.

The initial step in the management of RDS is Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) assessment to ensure patient stability. If the patient has any form of respiratory drive, noninvasive positive pressure ventilation is recommended first. If the patient is apneic or has poor respiratory effort, then endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation is indicated. The goal oxygen saturations for patients with RDS is 90-95%. Following airway stabilization, access should be obtained, usually via an umbilical venous catheter and surfactant should be given.   

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate positive pressure ventilation (PPV) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Place an umbilical vein catheter (UVC) :
Incorrect: Although this patient requires access, he is in respiratory distress and the first step in management is to initiate positive pressure ventilation.  
❌ Intubate:
Incorrect: As per neonatal resuscitation guidelines, the first step in managing a newborn in respiratory distress is to dry and stimulate them and clear secretions. If the infant continues to have respiratory distress or bradycardia, positive pressure ventilation with a mask should be provided. If positive pressure ventilation is unsuccessful, then the patient should be intubated. 
❌ Administer surfactant:
Incorrect: Surfactant is administered to preterm newborns with respiratory distress syndrome once they are stabilized. It is usually administered after intubation should this procedure be necessary. The best next step for this patient is to initiate positive pressure ventilation. 
❌ Perform deep suctioning:
Incorrect: Bulb suctioning is often used to clear oral and nasal passages; however, deep suctioning is not indicated during initial resuscitative measures. The best next step is to initiate positive pressure ventilation.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department following a witnessed syncopal episode while running a half-marathon. The patient collapsed suddenly at mile 11 and was unconscious for approximately one minute. Upon arrival, the patient looks uncomfortable and is experiencing difficulty breathing. Temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 107/65 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical exam, a loud systolic ejection murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Intravenous access is established, supplemental oxygen is administered, and the patient is attached to the cardiac monitor. Telemetry shows the following non-sustained finding which spontaneously converts back to normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with exertional syncope and ventricular tachycardia on telemetry. These findings along with the presence of a systolic ejection murmur on physical examination are concerning for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). This patient is unstable and ABCDE assessment and stabilization. Defibrillation pads should be applied in case there is a recurrence of a shockable, unstable rhythm.

HCM refers to a genetic condition associated with left ventricular hypertrophy that cannot be attributed to another cardiac, systemic, or metabolic cause. In HCM, ventricular hypertrophy causes decreased compliance which results in poor left ventricular filling. Ventricular septal hypertrophy combined with abnormal motion of the mitral valve can cause left ventricular outflow obstruction, which can lead to syncope or sudden cardiac death from ventricular arrhythmias during intense physical activity. Patients with HCM may be asymptomatic or may first present with ventricular arrhythmias or in cardiac arrest.    

Option Analysis

✅ Apply defibrillation pads:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Administer nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Sublingual nitroglycerin should be avoided in this patient where there is concern for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Administration of nitroglycerin, or vasodilators, can reduce left ventricular preload, worsening left ventricular outflow obstruction in patients with HCM.  
❌ Administer adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine is not indicated in this clinical scenario as this rhythm tracing shows ventricular tachycardia, which is a shockable rhythm. Adenosine should be administered to patients with supraventricular tachycardias refractory to vagal maneuvers. 
❌ Place implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD) :
Incorrect: ICD placement is indicated for this patient; however, stabilization takes precedence. Defibrillation pads should be applied in case this patient has a recurrent shockable, unstable rhythm while being treated.  
❌ Perform cardiac bedside ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Cardiac bedside ultrasonography is unlikely to add significant clinical information. This patient should be stabilized. Defibrillation pads should be applied in case she has a recurrent shockable, unstable rhythm.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of recurrent chest pain for the past month.  The symptoms occur primarily with exertion, such as walking up a flight of stairs. He also has trouble breathing and notes associated palpitations with exertion. The patient has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 117/5 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, a loud systolic ejection murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border that decreases in intensity with squatting and increases with standing. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Upon further questioning, which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death
History of high intensity exercise over many years
Family history of bicuspid aortic valve

questions.solution:
This patient presents with exertional chest pain, dyspnea, and palpitations. On physical examination, he has a systolic ejection murmur that decreases in intensity with squatting and increases with standing. These findings are consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), a genetic condition inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Patients with HCM may have a family history of sudden cardiac death in young family members.

HCM should be considered in patients presenting with exertional chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or syncope. Many patients are asymptomatic. History may reveal a family history of sudden cardiac death. On physical exam, patients may have a systolic ejection murmur at the lower left sternal border that decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase preload (e.g., squatting) and increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., Valsalva or standing). Increasing the preload forces the hypertrophied left ventricle (LV) segment open, decreasing the intensity of the murmur; while decreasing the preload with maneuvers like standing allows the hypertrophied LV segment to obstruct left ventricular outflow, increasing the intensity of the murmur. Additional findings may include an S4 gallop, a prominent apical point of maximum impulse and a bifid carotid pulse.    

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of sudden cardiac death:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Untreated prior strep pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is a known sequela of untreated strep throat, but it is not associated with the murmur heard in this patient which is consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Patients with rheumatic fever develop mitral or aortic valvulopathy.  
❌ Recent viral infection:
Incorrect: A recent viral infection can predispose patients to pericarditis which would not be associated with the murmur heard in this patient, which is consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. A friction rub is more often heard in patients with pericarditis.  
❌ History of high intensity exercise over many years:
Incorrect: A history of long-term high intensity exercise can result in left ventricular hypertrophy (i.e., athlete’s heart), which is a non-pathologic condition. The symptoms and physical exam findings in this patient are more consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
❌ Family history of bicuspid aortic valve:
Incorrect: A family history of bicuspid aortic valve is not associated with the development of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for assessment of recurrent palpitations and exertional dyspnea for one month. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no significant past medical history. The patient's grandmother died at an early age from drowning in a lake where she swam regularly. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 117/5 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, a loud systolic ejection murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border and an S4 heart sound is present. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. ECG is ordered. Which of the following additional tests should be performed to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath and palpitations with exertion. Physical examination is significant for a systolic ejection murmur and an S4 heart sound. The patient has a family history of sudden (likely cardiac) death. Together, these findings are concerning for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). A transthoracic echocardiogram should be ordered next to help determine if diagnostic criteria for HCM are met.

HCM refers to a genetic condition associated with left ventricular hypertrophy that cannot be attributed to another cardiac, systemic, or metabolic cause. It should always be considered in pediatric patients with exertional chest pain or dyspnea, especially if a systolic ejection murmur is heard on physical examination. Ventricular hypertrophy causes decreased compliance, which results in poor left ventricular (LV) filling. In some patients, ventricular septal hypertrophy combined with abnormal motion of the mitral valve may cause left ventricular outflow obstruction (LVOO), which can manifest as syncope or sudden cardiac death.

Criteria are met for HCM when the echocardiogram demonstrates left ventricular wall thickness that is more than two standard deviations above the mean for the patient's age, sex, and body surface area. Patients should then undergo genetic testing, which tests for a mutation in a gene coding for sarcomeric proteins, such as MYBPC3 or MYH7, which confirms the diagnosis of HCM.   

Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exercise stress testing:
Incorrect: Exercise stress testing is used to diagnose acute coronary syndromes. Exercise stress testing is not used to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
❌ Right heart catheterization:
Incorrect: Right heart catheterization is used to evaluate for right ventricular function. It is often performed in patients where there is concern for cor pulmonale, or right heart failure. 
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transesophageal echocardiogram is a useful tool in the diagnosis of endocarditis, as it can directly visualize valvular vegetations. It is an invasive procedure, and a transthoracic echocardiogram is typically sufficient to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest angiography:
Incorrect: CT-chest angiography is used to diagnose pulmonary embolism. It is not typically used to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A newborn boy is born at 37 weeks estimated gestational age by spontaneous vaginal delivery and appears cyanotic at the delivery. The mother did not have prenatal care. Rupture of membranes was 12 hours before delivery, group B streptococcus (GBS) is negative, and amniotic fluid is clear. APGAR scores are 4 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively, and there is minimal respiratory effort initially. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 75/min, blood pressure is 65/39 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. There is nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions are seen. No dysmorphic features are seen. Mucous membranes and the extremities are cyanotic. Cardiopulmonary exam is significant for normal heart sounds without murmurs and decreased air entry with bowel sounds heard over the left lung. The abdomen is scaphoid without hepatosplenomegaly. Femoral pulses are equal bilaterally. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient whose mother did not have prenatal care presents with central cyanosis and respiratory distress at birth. Physical exam showing scaphoid abdomen with bowel sounds in the chest is indicative of pulmonary hypoplasia from congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Chest X-ray showing bowel loops in the left hemithorax confirms this diagnosis. This newborn is unstable and in respiratory distress; therefore, intubation and mechanical ventilation are necessary to maintain airway and breathing.  

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to lung compression by abdominal viscera in the chest and is usually identified by prenatal ultrasound. Physical exam in newborns shows respiratory distress at birth, central cyanosis, low oxygen saturation, and scaphoid abdomen with audible bowel sounds in the chest. Chest X-ray will show bowel loops in the left hemithorax with displacement of the cardiac silhouette to the right.

When initially evaluating a newborn with central cyanosis, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Newborns with cyanosis are considered unstable, so maintaining the airway and breathing is essential. Delay in securing adequate airway can lead to severe acidosis and hypoxia, which increases the risk of pulmonary hypertension. Obtaining intravenous access, continuous vital signs monitoring, and oxygen supplementation as needed are the next steps in treatment.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous antibiotics  :
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics should be started in patients with suspected neonatal sepsis and neonatal pneumonia. This patient has no evidence of infection and, instead, is unstable from a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the priority. 
❌ Intravenous prostaglandins infusion :
Incorrect: Intravenous prostaglandins infusion is used in patients with cyanotic congenital heart diseases to maintain ductus arteriosus patency and systemic circulation. This patient is unstable with congenital diaphragmatic hernia; intubation with mechanical ventilation is the priority.  
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation :
Incorrect: Observation of this unstable neonate with cyanosis and respiratory distress is inappropriate and will result in worsening hypoxemia, acidosis, and increased risk for pulmonary hypertension. This patient should be intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is useful for determining the etiology of neonatal cyanosis in patients with suspected congenital heart diseases. This patient is in respiratory distress from a congenital diaphragmatic hernia; intubation with mechanical ventilation is the best next step in management.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for evaluation of vomiting and diarrhea. Over the past week, the infant has had an increasing frequency of vomiting and diarrhea, and she is now less alert and not feeding well. The infant was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a G1P0 mother. Prenatal course was uncomplicated, and the mother received all recommended prenatal care. Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) performed at 10 weeks' gestation was normal. Weight is at the 12th percentile and the patient has not yet returned to birth weight. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 38/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, and she is lying in her parent’s arms. The anterior fontanelle is slightly sunken, and the lips are dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. On genitourinary examination, there is clitoral enlargement, labial fusion, and a urogenital sinus. An in-office glucose level is 42. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 3-week-old patient presents with worsening vomiting and diarrhea and is now dehydrated and hypoglycemic. Physical examination findings reveal ambiguous genitalia. This presentation is suspicious for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) which can be diagnosed if there is an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level.      

Many causes of vomiting in newborns and infants can be diagnosed clinically. Viral gastroenteritis, food protein induced enterocolitis syndrome, and gastroesophageal reflux are typically diagnosed by history and physical examination alone. Imaging is necessary when there is concern that the underlying cause of vomiting is a structural abnormality. Intestinal malrotation with volvulus can be diagnosed if there is the finding of a “corkscrew” appearance of the duodenum on upper gastrointestinal contrast study. A “target sign” or “donut sign” will be present on abdominal ultrasound in patients with intussusception. While not an anatomical abnormality, the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis can be supported by the finding of pneumatosis intestinalis on abdominal radiograph.       

Laboratory studies are often necessary when evaluating a newborn or infant who presents with vomiting. When a female or uncircumcised male presents with fever (without other symptoms) or urinary symptoms, urine studies should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis as untreated urinary tract infections can lead to vomiting. Genetic causes of vomiting such as inborn errors of metabolism and congenital adrenal hyperplasia are often detected on newborn screening. However, these results should be confirmed with additional tests such as serum amino acid levels, urine organic acids, or 17-hydroxyprogesterone, depending on the patient’s symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ 17-hydroxyprogesterone level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Karyotype:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). This condition is diagnosed by the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. A karyotype would help confirm this patient’s sex but would not confirm the diagnosis of CAH. 
❌ Ammonia level:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) which can be diagnosed by the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. Elevated ammonia levels are nonspecific but can be present in patients with inborn errors of metabolism such as in urea cycle disorders. Urea cycle disorders are not associated with ambiguous genitalia. 
❌ Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). This condition is diagnosed by detection of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. An ACTH stimulation test is often used to measure the ability of the adrenal glands to respond to ACTH and produce cortisol. An ACTH stimulation test is used if results are equivocal after checking 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in patients where there is high suspicion for CAH. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is diagnosed by elevated the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. A pelvic ultrasound would help confirm this patient’s sex but would not confirm the diagnosis of CAH.

questions.text:
A 1-day old 3500-g (7.5-lb) newborn girl delivered at term to a 42-year-old primigravida is being evaluated in the nursery. The infant is having difficulty feeding and has had bilious emesis since birth. She does not have a fever, increased work of breathing, or abnormal movements. The infant's parent did not have any prenatal care. She did not drink alcohol or use other recreational substances during the pregnancy. Delivery was uncomplicated, but the infant was noted to have characteristic facial features. Temperature is 37�C (98.6�F), heart rate is 165/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is noted to have a flat facial profile with almond-shaped eyes and a single palmar crease. The mucous membranes are moist. A prominent murmur is heard on cardiac exam. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. She has poor muscle tones and poor sucking. X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Given the most like diagnosis, which of the following additional physical exam findings is most likely to be seen?  



Reproduced from Statdx
questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license.    

This newborn patient has features consistent with Down syndrome, including duodenal atresia, a flat face with almond shaped eyes, and a prominent murmur. History reveals an infant born to a mother of advanced age (42-year-old) who has not had prenatal care. Sandal toe gap with a wide space between the first and second toes is another physical that is characteristic of Down syndrome.        

Patients with Down syndrome are usually identified during prenatal screening. Risk factors include advanced maternal age. Physical examination reveals classic facial features, like upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, a flat facial profile, brachycephaly and low-set small ears. Patients may also have a short neck with excessive skin folds at the nape, a single palmar crease, Brushfield spots and a wide space between the first and second toes on the feet called a sandal toe gap. Generalized hypotonia, significant head lag, and a weak moro reflex are also commonly seen.        

Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk for congenital heart diseases, gastrointestinal malformations, hematological disorders and hearing and vision defects. Gastrointestinal anomalies include tracheoesophageal fistulas, duodenal and anal atresia, and Hirschsprung disease.        

Infants with duodenal atresia may present with difficulty feeding and bilious emesis in the first few days after birth. To confirm the diagnosis, an abdominal X-ray should be ordered. The finding of a double bubble sign, showing a distended stomach and duodenum, as seen in this patient, is consistent with duodenal atresia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Rocker bottom feet  :
Incorrect: Rocker bottom feet are commonly seen in patients with Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18), in addition to small facies with prominent occiput, small ears, and overlapping fingers. The findings in this patient and the associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Sandal toe gap is a characteristic finding in patients with Down syndrome.  
❌ Beaked nose :
Incorrect: Beaked nose (a prominent nasal bridge) is seen in patients with Crouzon syndrome in addition to craniosynostosis, strabismus and overcrowded teeth. The findings in this patient and the associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome. Sandal toe gap is a characteristic in patients with Down syndrome. 
✅ Sandal toe gap :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clenched hands :
Incorrect: Clenched hands are seen in patients with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) in addition to microcephaly, microphthalmia, and cutis aplasia. The findings in this patient and associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome. 
❌ Cleft palate  :
Incorrect: Cleft palate can be seen in patients with Digeorge syndrome (22Q11 deletion) in addition to a long face, broad nose, and small jaw (micrognathia). The findings in this patient and associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with Down syndrome is brought to the clinic by her parent who noticed that she has had abnormal gait for one week. Her parents also report new onset urinary incontinence. She has no history of trauma, fever, headache, abnormal movements, or focal neurological symptoms. She has a past medical history of bronchial asthma that is well controlled with bronchodilators, and immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 37�C (98.6�F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, ataxic gait is noted with increased muscle tone and increased deep tendon reflexes in the extremities. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 9-year-old girl with Down syndrome presents with abnormal gait and urinary incontinence, which are signs of atlantoaxial instability. Patients with down syndrome are at increased risk for atlantoaxial dislocation. The best next step in management is to obtain a cervical spine X-ray to confirm the diagnosis.   

Atlantoaxial dislocation is instability between the atlas and axis (C1-C2), which results in abnormal articulation. In patients with Down syndrome, the ligamentous laxity between the C1 atlas and C2 axis cervical vertebrae, low muscle tone, and excessive joint flexibility increases the risk of spinal cord injury during cervical spine hyperextension or hyperflexion. For this reason, they should avoid activities that increase the risk of spinal cord injury, like contact sports and trampolines. Patients with Down syndrome need anesthesia or surgery and should be cleared first by a neurosurgeon.    

Down syndrome patients with atlantoaxial instability may present with new onset neck pain, weakness, spasticity or change in tone, abnormal gait, hyperreflexia, change in bowel or bladder function, or signs or symptoms of myelopathy. To evaluate, a cervical spine X-ray should be ordered to assess the atlas and axis. Dislocation of the atlas relative to the dens of the axis confirms atlantoaxial instability.   

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: CBC can screen for iron deficiency anemia and leukemia in patients with Down syndrome given the increased risk in these patients. The patient in this vignette has signs and symptoms of ataxia and urinary incontinence consistent with atlantoaxial instability and the best next step is to obtain a cervical spine x-ray.  
❌ Sleep study:
Incorrect: Sleep studies are commonly used to determine the etiology of sleep disorders in patients with Down syndrome who have snoring, restlessness, and daytime sleepiness, since they are at increased risk. A sleep study is not warranted in this patient who has no sleep-related complaints. Instead, a cervical spine x-ray should be performed given the signs of atlantoaxial instability. 
✅ Cervical spine X-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurosurgery consult :
Incorrect: Consulting neurosurgery is appropriate for management in patients with atlantoaxial instability. However, the diagnosis should first be confirmed with a cervical spine X-ray.  
❌ 1 month follow-up visit :
Incorrect: This patient with Down syndrome has signs of atlantoaxial instability, and surgical correction may be required. Therefore, the diagnosis should be confirmed with cervical spine x-ray. Observation and follow-up are not appropriate in this case.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy presents to the office with four weeks of diarrhea. The parent reports that the stool is foul-smelling, bulky, and greasy. The Infant was born full term without complications and passed meconium at three days of life. Newborn screening results are unknown. There is no history of vomiting, choking, or increased work of breathing with feeds. History is significant for a diagnosis of pneumonia requiring hospital admission at four months of age. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight has dropped from the 55<sup>th</sup> percentile to the 7<sup>th</sup> percentile. Length has dropped from the 30<sup>th</sup> percentile to the 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. Physical examination reveals a pale thin-appearing infant without dysmorphic features or characteristic odors. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. A 2/6 flow murmur is appreciated best at the left lower sternal border. Which of the following can be used to confirm the underlying cause of growth faltering?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with growth faltering as indicated by weight-for-age crossing 2 major percentile lines. He has diarrhea, steatorrhea, a history of delayed meconium passage, and pneumonia requiring hospitalization at an early age. These findings are consistent with cystic fibrosis and a sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder of the exocrine glands that frequently leads to chronic sinopulmonary infections and pancreatic insufficiency. Newborns with CF may present with meconium ileus, prolonged neonatal jaundice, and early lung infections. Infants and children with CF may present with poor weight gain due to malabsorption, anemia, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and distal intestinal obstructive syndrome.

The diagnostic workup of growth faltering begins with a history and physical examination to narrow down the cause of growth faltering, which can be due to increased energy expenditure, inadequate caloric intake, or malabsorption. Infants with CF can develop malabsorption secondary to pancreatic insufficiency which results in steatorrhea (bulky, greasy, foul-smelling stools), vitamin deficiencies, and growth faltering. All newborns are screened for CF as part of the standard newborn screening panel starting with immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT). If a newborn screen returns with an elevated IRT level or there is clinical suspicion for CF, sweat chloride testing should be ordered. An elevated sweat chloride level is consistent with cystic fibrosis and should prompt genetic testing for CF. Two sweat chloride levels ≥ 60 mmol/L or a positive cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutation confirms the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Although a low fecal elastase indicates pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption, it does confirm CF.

Option Analysis

❌ Fecal elastase levels :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has cystic fibrosis, and fecal elastase levels are typically low in patients with cystic fibrosis. They can be used to monitor pancreatic exocrine function. However, they are not used to confirm the diagnosis. A sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
❌ Chest radiograph :
Incorrect: While a chest x-ray can identify hyperinflation, bronchiectasis, and atelectasis in patients with cystic fibrosis, it is not used to make the diagnosis. A sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
❌ Serum tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTG igA) levels :
Incorrect: A positive tTG IgA is highly suggestive of celiac disease which can cause patients to have poor weight gain, diarrhea, steatorrhea, and a rash. The findings in this patient are more consistent with cystic fibrosis given the history of delayed passage of meconium and pneumonia at an early age. A sweat chloride test is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.
✅ Sweat chloride test :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper endoscopy  :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy can be used to assess gastroesophageal reflux which can cause growth faltering. This patient most likely has cystic fibrosis, which is diagnosed by sweat chloride testing.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy living in Ohio presents to the office for a sore throat and rash for five days. The rash started on the neck and then spread to the arms and chest. There is no history of joint pain, headache, or cough. There has been no recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, there is evidence of exudative pharyngitis, circumoral pallor with a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following best describes the type of rash that would be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center

questions.solution:
Scarlet fever rash and white strawberry tongue by Estreya and Azizova. Licensed under CC BY 2.5 and CC BY-SA 3.0 respectively.         

Reproduced from Wikipedia and Wikipedia respectively.        

This patient presenting with fever, rash, sore throat, and physical exam findings of exudative pharyngitis, circumoral pallor, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy most likely has scarlet fever. The rash seen with scarlet fever is described as a sandpaper-like rash.   

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) exotoxins, most commonly in association with GAS pharyngitis. Affected patients are typically school-aged and present with fever, sore throat, headache, and often abdominal pain. Patients with scarlet fever will have generalized diffuse erythema with a fine papular “sandpaper” textured rash that typically starts in the groin or armpits and then spreads to the trunk and then the extremities. Other findings of scarlet fever include circumoral pallor, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Pastia lines, which are linear accentuation of erythema in flexor surfaces, may also be seen. A positive rapid strep test or throat culture growing GAS confirms the diagnosis of scarlet fever.       

Fever and rash are common manifestations of bacterial infections in children. History may reveal a sick contact or recent travel. Evaluation of rash morphology can often help determine the underlying cause. Maculopapular or macular rashes with annular lesions are associated with erythema multiforme and Lyme disease. Rose spots are seen with typhoid fever. Plaques can be seen with erysipelas, while diffuse papular erythema and a sandpaper-like rash are suggestive of scarlet fever. Fluid-filled lesions such as vesicles, bullae, and pustules can be caused by impetigo, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, or rickettsial pox. Petechial or purpuric rashes are seen with Rocky Mountain spotted fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Erythematous bull’s eye lesion :
Incorrect: Erythema migrans, which is seen in patients with Lyme disease, presents as an erythematous bull’s eye lesion. This patient does not live in an area endemic to Lyme disease, and he has exudative pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a skin rash; the most likely diagnosis is scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash. 
❌ Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center :
Incorrect: Lesions from erythema multiforme (EM) appear as erythematous target lesions with a dusky center. The findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash. 
✅ Sandpaper-like erythematous blanching rash :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bullous lesions :
Incorrect: Bullous lesions are often seen with infections with Staphylococcus aureus or with autoimmune disease. The history and physical exam findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever due to Streptococcus pyogenes, which causes a sandpaper-like rash.  
❌ Faint salmon-colored macules  :
Incorrect: Rose spots appear as faint salmon-colored macules. They are seen in patients with typhoid fever who typically present with vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and history of recent travel. The history and physical exam findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Earlier in the day, the infant was with her grandparents and was found playing with medication that included metformin and oxycodone. There has been no vomiting or seizure activity. Past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is unresponsive. Mucous membranes are moist. Shallow breathing is noted with equal air entry bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Bowel sounds are decreased, and the abdomen is soft and non-tender. There is no extremity edema. The infant is stabilized and admitted to the hospital. Laboratory results are shown below. Electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. Given the most likely underlying diagnosis, which of the following additional findings would be expected?  
 
 Laboratory value     Results    
 pH     7.15    
 PaO2     60 mmHg    
 PaCO2     75 mmHg    
 Serum bicarbonate      22  mEq/L    
 Serum glucose     85 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypercapnic respiratory failure. The history of exposure to narcotics, decreased respiratory rate, shallow breathing, and respiratory acidosis support the diagnosis of opioid toxicity. Pinpoint pupils are an expected finding in patients with opioid toxicity.

A partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) above 50 mmHg indicates hypercapnic respiratory failure, which is characterized by inadequate ventilation and carbon dioxide retention. Hypercapnic respiratory failure can be referred to as “pump failure" – in other words, a mechanical impairment within the respiratory system that prevents patients from effectively eliminating CO2. Pump failure can be caused by decreased central respiratory drive due to narcotic exposure, traumatic brain injury, or respiratory muscle weakness from neuromuscular disorders.

Narcotics exposure in pediatric patients can result from accidental ingestions, prescription misuse, and household exposure. Patients presenting with opioid toxicity can present with altered mental status, seizures, and respiratory depression. Physical exams typically reveal bradycardia, bradypnea, apnea, and shallow breathing. Bowel sounds are typically decreased. Miotic (pinpoint) pupils are usually seen.

Option Analysis

❌ Jitteriness  :
Incorrect: Jitteriness may be seen in newborns or young children with hypoglycemia. Given the history of possible ingestion of opioids, altered level of consciousness, respiratory depression, and normal glucose level, opioid toxicity is more likely, and pinpoint pupils would be expected on physical examination.
❌ Lower extremity edema:
Incorrect: Lower extremity edema may suggest congestive heart failure as the cause of respiratory distress. Patients with heart failure typically present with dyspnea, orthopnea, tachypnea, and abnormal heart sounds, none of which are present in this patient.
❌ Digital clubbing:
Incorrect: Digital clubbing is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). Patients with CF typically present with recurrent pneumonia and pancreatic insufficiency.
❌ Hypotonia  :
Incorrect: Hypotonia is seen in patients with neuromuscular disorders, which typically present with weakness. While neuromuscular disorders can cause respiratory failure and recurrent aspiration and pneumonia, the history and findings in this case are more suggestive of opioid toxicity.
✅ Pinpoint pupils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for a well child visit. The parents report he is unsteady while walking and trips frequently. He is unable to run and prefers to crawl up and down stairs. He knows about 20 individual words that he uses singly without stringing words together; he can only occasionally point in books at words that are said by his parents; and he can stack three blocks together. He does not help with dressing himself. Birth and past medical histories are unremarkable. Family history is pertinent for an uncle who had delayed development. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 96/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient does not want to separate from his parents and tries to get attention by pointing to his cup. Neurological exams are normal. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Genetic testing shows mutations in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following physical exam findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons . Licensed CC BY-SA 4.0 

The patient exhibits global developmental delays in language and speech, social-emotional, and motor skills with positive genetic screening for fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of global developmental delay. Patients often have characteristic physical features, including a long narrow face and large protruding ears.

Global developmental delay is present when there are delays in two or more of the major categories of development (motor, language/speech, cognitive and social/emotional).

When assessing pediatric developmental milestones, the first step is obtaining a focused history and physical exam. Understanding normal developmental milestones based on age can help physicians and caregivers recognize when a child is at risk for developmental delay and would benefit from detailed evaluation and early intervention. Reviewing birth history is important since both prematurity and low birth weight are associated with developmental delays. Interval history is useful to determine new skills learned or if there is any regression in development. Family history can reveal genetic causes of developmental delay. Genetic conditions associated with developmental delays include fragile X syndrome, Down syndrome (trisomy 21), tuberous sclerosis, neurofibromatosis, and autism spectrum disorder.

When performing the physical exam, reflexes, muscle tone, and balance should be checked. The child's behavior and social interactions should be observed. Patients with fragile X syndrome can exhibit autistic behaviors, symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, aggression, and poor eye contact. Patients with developmental delays should also be assessed for characteristic physical features.  Physical features associated with fragile X syndrome include a long, narrow face, prominent jaw, and forehead, hyperflexible fingers, and large protruding ears.

Option Analysis

❌ Organomegaly :
Incorrect: Organomegaly may indicate glycogen storage diseases, sphingolipidoses, or mucopolysaccharidoses, which are commonly associated with motor delays. However, this patient has global developmental delay with genetic testing confirming fragile X syndrome.
❌ Spastic lower extremities:
Incorrect: Spastic lower extremities are a common feature of cerebral palsy which also presents with global developmental delays, in addition to hypertonia. This patient’s presentation lacks risk factors for cerebral palsy, such as hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, central nervous system infections, or kernicterus, and genetic testing confirms fragile X syndrome.
✅ Large protruding ears:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calf hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Calf hypertrophy is typically a feature of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is characterized by progressive weakness and hypotonia. This patient’s physical exam, global developmental delay, and genetic testing are consistent with fragile X syndrome.
❌ Cleft palate:
Incorrect: Cleft palate is a common feature of DiGeorge syndrome, which is associated with hypotonia, delayed development, and congenital heart defects. This patient’s physical exam, global developmental delay, and genetic testing are consistent with fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought for a well-child evaluation after recent immigration into the country. The child began walking unsupported at 23 months of age but is still unable to climb up the stairs without help from his parents. He can draw a circle but cannot catch a ball. The patient has a vocabulary of more than 200 words and can combine them in three-word phrases. He can eat independently and knows his age and gender. The mother’s pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 32 weeks. There is no family history of developmental delays or motor disorders. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 92/63 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination no dysmorphic features are noted. Neurologic, cardiopulmonary, and abdominal exams are normal. Which of the following best describes this child’s developmental status?
questions.solution:
The child in the vignette is exhibiting isolated gross motor delay most likely secondary to prematurity (with birth at 32 weeks gestational age). Red flags that can signal motor delay in a three-year-old include difficulty using stairs and inability to catch a ball.  

When assessing development milestones in a child, it is important to understand normal development. At three-years, a child is expected to walk upstairs with alternating feet, pedal a tricycle and catch a ball. In the area of language and communication, a three-year-old should have a vocabulary of over 200 words, make three-word sentences, and have about 75% of their speech understood by strangers. Self-help skills appropriate for this age include eating independently, toilet training, and putting on their own shoes. They should be able to identify their age and gender, take turns and enjoy imaginative play.

Pediatric patients with gross motor delays should be evaluated for neuromuscular disorders. Prematurity and low birth weight are known risk factors for developmental delays. Cerebral palsy may be diagnosed in patients with a history of hypoxic ischemic insults, central nervous system infections, stroke, or kernicterus. A positive family history can suggest genetic or metabolic disorders. In patients with a history of prematurity and gross motor delays, if the physical exam also reveals low to normal tone or weakness, brain imaging should be performed to rule out other causes like cerebral palsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Gross motor delay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Global developmental delay:
Incorrect: Global developmental delay is present when two or more of the major categories show delay. This child shows appropriate language and cognitive skills but is exhibiting isolated gross motor delay.
❌ Cognitive delay:
Incorrect: Cognitive delay in a three-year-old is characterized by difficulties with tasks such as independent eating, putting on shoes or understanding comparisons. This patient does not exhibit any difficulties with these tasks. Therefore, cognitive delay is unlikely.
❌ Language delay:
Incorrect: Given the child's vocabulary of more than 200 words and ability to form three-word phrases, language development appears to be age-appropriate for this three-year-old.
❌ Social-emotional delay:
Incorrect: This patient knows his age and gender and seems to be showing appropriate social and emotional development.

questions.text: A 15-month-old toddler is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of altered mental status and convulsions. She was playing in the sandbox at the park prior to arrival when she suddenly stared off into space and then experienced stiffening of her limbs and rhythmic jerking. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and there is no significant past medical history. She does not take any medication. She has not been ill or unsupervised recently. In the ambulance, the stiffening and rhythmic jerking of the limbs stopped. However, the patient remains unconscious. Emergency medical services are unable to obtain intravenous access. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg. On exam, the patient is unresponsive with flexion of the bilateral upper extremities and extension of the bilateral lower extremities. The neck is supple, and no rashes are seen. In the emergency department, the patient starts experiencing witnessed convulsions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography of the head without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This child, who has no significant past medical history, is presenting with involuntary motor activity with impaired consciousness in the absence of an obvious trigger or signs of central nervous system infection. She is experiencing a first-time unprovoked seizure. She has had recurrent seizures without returning to baseline mental status in between the seizures and therefore is in status epilepticus, which is a medical emergency. Initial treatment includes acute stabilization, with administration of a benzodiazepine to stop seizure activity. If intravenous access cannot be obtained, the patient should be treated with intranasal administration of a benzodiazepine.
