Incorrect: Sever disease presents with heel pain and tenderness of the lateral and medial calcaneus. This patient's tenderness is along the medial tibial borders and is consistent with shin splints.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of left elbow pain. A caregiver reports the child was having a temper tantrum at the mall when the caregiver pulled the child by the left arm to go home. The patient immediately began crying and refused to use the left arm. There was no fall or direct trauma to the elbow. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no daily medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals guarding of the left arm, which is held in slight flexion and pronation. There is no evidence of obvious injury or deformity to the left elbow. Capillary refill and sensation are intact. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with classic findings of nursemaid’s elbow, or radial head subluxation. History typically involves direct longitudinal traction applied to the affected arm, and physical examination reveals the arm held in slight flexion and pronation. Diagnosis is clinical, and plain radiographs are not routinely needed. Treatment involves reduction using either extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm or supination with flexion at the elbow.       

Common musculoskeletal injuries in children include fractures, sprains, joint dislocations or subluxation, and overuse injuries. Accurate diagnosis relies heavily on a thorough history and physical examination. Categorizing the injury based on a history of direct trauma, no identifiable trauma, or repetitive stress can help narrow the differential.       

When clinically indicated, plain radiographs of the affected bone and adjacent joints can be obtained to evaluate for fracture or dislocation. However, in certain conditions (e.g., nursemaid’s elbow, little league elbow) the diagnosis is often made clinically, and imaging is not typically needed. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be considered when diagnostic uncertainty persists or when soft tissue injury is suspected. In cases concerning for non-accidental trauma, particularly in nonverbal children, those with limited communication, or those under 60 months of age, a skeletal survey should be performed.       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Radiograph of the left elbow:
Incorrect: Imaging is not routinely indicated when the presentation is consistent with radial head subluxation, and there are no signs of deformity or trauma. Radiographs may be considered if the diagnosis is unclear or if symptoms persist after reduction. 
❌ Long arm splint:
Incorrect: Immobilization is not indicated for radial head subluxation. Prompt reduction is typically curative, and children usually resume use of the arm shortly afterward. 
❌ Sling placement with orthopedic follow-up:
Incorrect: Sling placement and specialist referral are unnecessary for radial head subluxation unless symptoms persist after reduction or another diagnosis is suspected. 
❌ Direct longitudinal forearm traction:
Incorrect: Longitudinal forearm traction is the mechanism that typically results in radial head subluxation. Reduction can be achieved by extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm or supination with flexion at the elbow.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is sent to the emergency department by the pediatrician for further evaluation of failure to thrive and laboratory abnormalities. The patient was born full-term without complications. Formula feeding has been established, but weight has dropped from the 48th to the 3rd percentile. The parents report a responsive smile but note difficulty with lifting the head during tummy time. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the infant is irritable and hypotonic with a round, doll-like face. There is a protruding abdomen and mild hepatomegaly. Examination is otherwise normal. Laboratory studies obtained three hours after a feed are shown below. Which of the following additional laboratory findings would be expected?

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Blood gas         
 pH     7.3    
 PaCO2     35 mmHg    
 HCO3     17 mEq/L    
 Serum chemistries         
 Lactic acid      4 mmol/L    
 Blood glucose      30 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This infant presents with failure to thrive, hypotonia, doll-like facies, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. These findings are highly suggestive of glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), also known as von Gierke disease. Hypertriglyceridemia is commonly seen in affected infants.

In the evaluation of hypoglycemia in infants, the timing of hypoglycemia in relation to feeding is a critical diagnostic clue. Postprandial hypoglycemia raises suspicion for inborn errors of carbohydrate metabolism, such as hereditary fructose intolerance or classic galactosemia. In contrast, fasting hypoglycemia accompanied by lactic acidosis suggests a defect in gluconeogenesis, such as fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase deficiency or GSD I. Molecular genetic testing can help distinguish between these conditions.

GSD I results from mutations affecting glucose-6-phosphatase activity. Infants typically present between two and six months of age with fasting hypoglycemia (often within two to three hours of a meal) and poor weight gain. Characteristic physical findings include doll-like facies, hepatosplenomegaly, hypotonia, and xanthomas. Laboratory abnormalities may include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. Management focuses on preventing hypoglycemia through frequent feedings and supplementation with cornstarch.

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated creatine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Elevated creatine kinase levels are seen in infantile Pompe disease, a lysosomal storage disease. Affected infants typically present with cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hypotonia, and feeding difficulties. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Elevated leucine levels:
Incorrect: Elevated leucine levels are seen in patients with maple syrup urine disease. These patients can present as newborns with encephalopathy, sweet odor to the urine, and ketonuria. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Hyperammonemia:
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia suggests a urea cycle disorder, which typically presents with respiratory alkalosis and can lead to encephalopathy, seizures, and coma. This infant has metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis, consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Hyperinsulinemia:
Incorrect: Hyperinsulinemia can cause neonatal hypoglycemia, particularly in infants born to diabetic mothers or those with congenital hyperinsulinism. However, these findings of failure to thrive, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, and characteristic facies are more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
✅ Hypertriglyceridemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A newborn boy is delivered at 36 weeks' gestation via emergency cesarean section for fetal heart rate decelerations. The mother had no prenatal care and reported frequent tobacco use during pregnancy. There was no history of fever, recent illness, or substance use other than tobacco. Rupture of membranes occurred at the time of delivery. The delivery proceeded without complication, and Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, a full-thickness abdominal wall defect is noted to the right of the umbilicus with herniated bowel and no associated sac. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This newborn has findings consistent with gastroschisis, a full-thickness abdominal wall defect with herniated bowel and no associated sac. The next best step in management is the placement of a nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach.       

Gastroschisis is a congenital abdominal wall defect associated with evisceration of the bowel. Prenatal screening may reveal an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level, and ultrasound often identifies the abdominal wall defect. Risk factors include young maternal age, tobacco use, and use of illicit drugs during pregnancy. On physical examination, gastroschisis typically presents as herniation of abdominal contents through a defect to the right of the umbilicus without a covering membrane. Herniated contents commonly include the small intestine, and intestinal atresia may be present. The most frequent complication is gastrointestinal dysmotility.        
All newborns with abdominal wall defects should undergo an ABCDE assessment. If the patient is unstable, the priority is to stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation. In stable patients, a nasogastric or orogastric tube should be placed for gastric decompression. The exposed abdominal contents should be covered with warm, moist, sterile gauze or a bowel bag to reduce the risk of fluid loss, infection, and ischemia. Intravenous access should be established to initiate total parenteral nutrition soon after birth. Once stabilized, the patient should receive continuous monitoring and supplemental oxygen as needed. Definitive treatment involves surgical closure of the defect.   

Option Analysis

❌ Genetics consultation :
Incorrect: While genetic consultation may be appropriate in some neonates with congenital anomalies, gastroschisis is typically an isolated defect not associated with chromosomal abnormalities. It is not part of the initial management. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound :
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound should be performed in patients with gastroschisis; however, it does not take precedence over immediate stabilization measures.  
❌ Barium enema :
Incorrect: A barium enema is useful in the evaluation of conditions such as Hirschsprung disease, which typically presents with delayed passage of meconium and abdominal distention. It has no role in the diagnosis or management of gastroschisis.  
✅ Nasogastric tube placement :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous inotrope therapy  :
Incorrect: Inotrope therapy is reserved for patients with signs of hemodynamic instability. Although the blood pressure in this vignette may appear low, it is within the normal range for a newborn at 36 weeks’ gestation. Given the infant's stable perfusion and vital signs, inotropes are not indicated yet.

questions.text: A 4-week-old girl is evaluated during a well-check visit. The infant was born at term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and had an unremarkable neonatal course. A caregiver reports noticing an abdominal mass after the umbilical cord separated. There is no fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. Urine output and bowel movements are normal. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 129/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 75/41 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals no rash, a supple neck, and a normal cranial exam. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and nontender with a reducible umbilical mass. No drainage is noted on exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with a non-tender, reducible umbilical mass without drainage, consistent with an umbilical hernia.       

All infants with an umbilical mass should be evaluated for the presence and quality of any associated drainage. An umbilical hernia is more likely when no drainage is present. If drainage is observed, its characteristics can help identify the underlying cause. Clear urine suggests a patent urachus, while feculent or brown discharge may indicate an omphalomesenteric fistula. When such conditions are suspected, an abdominal ultrasound is typically performed for further evaluation.       

Umbilical hernias are common in newborns and result from incomplete closure of the umbilical ring fascia, allowing protrusion of intra-abdominal contents. They present as soft, non-tender, reducible midline masses that may become more prominent with crying, coughing, or straining. Asymptomatic hernias often close spontaneously by age 2. However, the development of abdominal pain or vomiting may indicate strangulation, which requires urgent surgical intervention.   

Option Analysis

❌ Gastroschisis  :
Incorrect: Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect present at birth with herniation of abdominal contents through an opening typically to the right of the umbilicus. The bowel is exposed without a protective sac, and the viscera are not reducible. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia.  
❌ Omphalomesenteric fistula. :
Incorrect: An omphalomesenteric fistula results from a persistent connection between the intestinal tract and the umbilicus. It typically presents with continuous feculent drainage, not as a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
❌ Patent urachus :
Incorrect: A patent urachus is a persistent connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. It usually presents with clear urinary discharge from the umbilicus rather than a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
❌ Umbilical granuloma  :
Incorrect: An umbilical granuloma appears as moist, red granulation tissue at the base of the umbilicus after cord separation. It may produce serosanguinous or yellow drainage but does not present as a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
✅ Umbilical hernia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is admitted for cervical lymphadenitis secondary to Staphylococcus aureus. Past medical history is significant for pneumonia due to Klebsiella pneumoniae, as well as recurrent fevers and multiple skin infections. Family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral enlarged cervical lymph nodes with associated erythema and tenderness to palpation. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms is consistent with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). A positive dihydrorhodamine test confirms the diagnosis.       

The initial evaluation of a patient with suspected primary immunodeficiency includes a detailed history, physical examination, and laboratory studies, along with an assessment for characteristic features of associated syndromes. In the absence of such features, identifying the types of microbes causing infections can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia, Klebsiella, Nocardia) should raise suspicion for CGD, which is confirmed by demonstrating decreased phagocytic oxidase activity on flow cytometry using the dihydrorhodamine test.        

Polymicrobial infections involving both aerobic and anaerobic organisms may suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which is diagnosed by flow cytometry assessing neutrophil adhesion glycoproteins. Infections with extracellular encapsulated bacteria, particularly invasive Neisseria meningitidis, may indicate complement deficiency, confirmed by reduced CH50 and AH50 activity. Recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections with encapsulated organisms should prompt evaluation for B-cell or antibody defects, typically assessed with quantitative immunoglobulin levels, flow cytometry, and genetic testing depending on the suspected condition.   

Option Analysis

❌ Total complement levels:
Incorrect: Complement deficiency typically presents with recurrent infections due to encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. This patient’s history of recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms is more consistent with chronic granulomatous disease. Dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry is the preferred diagnostic test. 
✅ Dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Platelet count:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia may be seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which presents with eczema and recurrent infections due to encapsulated organisms. This patient's history of multiple infections with catalase-positive organisms is more consistent with chronic granulomatous disease. 
❌ Quantitative immunoglobulins:
Incorrect: This test is useful in the evaluation of B-cell immunodeficiencies such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, which often presents with absent or small lymphoid tissues. The presence of palpable lymph nodes and catalase-positive infections makes this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ T-cell flow cytometry:
Incorrect: T-cell flow cytometry is used in evaluating T-cell deficiencies such as DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with recurrent viral or fungal infections, hypocalcemia-related seizures, characteristic facies, and congenital heart defects. These findings are not present in this case.

questions.text: A one-month-old infant boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. Since birth, the baby has been doing well. The parent has no concerns and reports that the infant is tolerating breast milk without issue. He has had no illnesses, including fevers, cough, or congestion. The parent also notes that the infant has been looking at faces and fixates on and follows the parent while feeding. The infant was born full term without complications. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the patient has been gaining weight appropriately. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing male infant in no acute distress. The fontanelles are soft. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Hip exam demonstrates negative Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers. Genitourinary examination shows bilaterally descended testes. The baby moves all extremities symmetrically and has normal muscle tone. Which of the following additional findings would be expected on this patient's assessment?
questions.solution:
This one-month-old infant presents for a routine well-child visit. At this age, an expected developmental milestone is voice recognition. Infants should be alert and responsive, enjoy looking at faces, and recognize familiar voices.

Well-child visits promote the health and well-being of children from birth through adolescence. In the first year of life, each visit begins with a comprehensive history and physical exam, followed by age-specific interventions and recommendations.

Key history elements include birth history (including gestation age, birth weight, and any complications), interval history (noting any changes since the last visit), developmental milestones, caregiver concerns, social determinants of health (e.g., tobacco exposure, intimate partner violence, food insecurity), and protective factors (e.g. social support). The physical exam should include general appearance, growth measurements, and a full body evaluation with attention to fontanelles, head shape, red reflex, and muscle tone.

Infants should receive age-appropriate screenings and immunizations, and caregivers should receive guidance on nutrition and oral health, as well as anticipatory guidance.

Option Analysis

❌ Babbling :
Incorrect: Babbling typically begins around six months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
✅ Familiar voice recognition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rolling over:
Incorrect: Patients should be able to roll by four to six months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
❌ Crawling:
Incorrect: Patients are generally able to crawl by nine months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
❌ Smiling at own reflection:
Incorrect: Smiling at one’s own reflection typically occurs around 6 months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn boy is evaluated in the hospital for poor feeding. The parents reports that the infant has had trouble swallowing during feeds and occasional episodes of “shortness of breath” with a high-pitched inspiratory sound. The infant was born at 36 weeks’ gestation via vaginal delivery without complications. The prenatal course was otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 150/min, blood pressure is 85/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals normal tone and reflexes with intermittent stridor. Gene sequencing confirms a diagnosis of Pierre Robin sequence. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Retained fluid in the nasal cavity
Defect in the soft or hard palate

questions.solution:
This 3-day-old newborn presents with poor feeding, stridor, and a diagnosis of Pierre Robin sequence, a rare congenital condition characterized by a combination of facial anomalies that typically present at birth, including micrognathia. Micrognathia, or an underdeveloped lower jaw, can impair feeding. Glossoptosis, the backward displacement of the tongue, can lead to airway obstruction and stridor.         

In an infant with poor feeding, the history and physical examination often reveal characteristic findings. Caregivers may report difficulty with latching or swallowing, or signs of respiratory distress such as stridor, stertor, or frequent coughing. Physical examination may show craniofacial abnormalities including cleft palate or micrognathia. In the absence of these features, frothing and bubbling at the nose and mouth may suggest esophageal atresia, while cyanosis that improves with crying, or inspiratory stridor during feeding or crying, may indicate choanal atresia or laryngomalacia, respectively. Ankyloglossia typically presents with latching difficulty and a tight lingual or upper lip frenulum.   

Option Analysis

❌ Collapse of supraglottic structures :
Incorrect: This finding is commonly associated with laryngomalacia, which may present with stridor but is not associated with Pierre Robin sequence. 
❌ Retained fluid in the nasal cavity :
Incorrect: Retained nasal fluid with respiratory distress is more suggestive of choanal atresia, which typically presents with difficulty breathing through the nose and cyanosis that improves with crying. This patient has normal oxygen saturation and no signs of nasal blockage. 
❌ Tight upper lip frenulum :
Incorrect: A tight upper lip frenulum may cause difficulty with latching, but it does not cause stridor or impaired swallowing. These features suggest a more significant structural anomaly affecting the airway and feeding coordination. 
✅ Undersized mandible and overbite :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defect in the soft or hard palate :
Incorrect: A cleft palate may be present in Pierre Robin sequence and can contribute to feeding difficulties. However, it does not typically cause stridor or signs of airway obstruction. These features suggest glossoptosis, which results from mandibular hypoplasia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by a parent for a routine check-up. The parent is concerned about progressive weight gain over the past two years. There is no significant past medical history, and no medications are taken. The child has also been experiencing increased fatigue and difficulty concentrating in school. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the father and obesity in the mother. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Body mass index is at the 97<sup>th</sup> percentile for age and sex. Examination reveals velvety, hyperpigmented plaques over the nape of the neck. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional features is most likely to be present on further history?

choices.text: Easy bruising and purple abdominal striae

questions.solution:
This patient has obesity (BMI ≥ 95th percentile for age and sex) and shows signs of acanthosis nigricans, which suggests insulin resistance and increased risk for metabolic complications. In addition, the patient is experiencing daytime fatigue and difficulty concentrating at school, which may indicate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a common comorbidity of pediatric obesity. Frequent nighttime snoring is the most likely associated feature.

A detailed history and physical examination are essential for identifying contributing factors, comorbidities, and underlying causes of weight gain. History should explore prenatal and family risk factors, dietary and activity patterns, symptoms of metabolic disorders such as diabetes, OSA, or polycystic ovary syndrome, and psychosocial influences, including adverse childhood experiences (ACEs). Physical examination may reveal obesity-related findings such as acanthosis nigricans (a marker of insulin resistance), hepatomegaly (suggestive of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)), and elevated blood pressure (indicative of hypertension).

Option Analysis

❌ Increased thirst and urination:
Incorrect: These symptoms are more characteristic of type 1 diabetes mellitus, which has an abrupt onset. In contrast, type 2 diabetes typically presents insidiously, often with signs of insulin resistance, such as acanthosis nigricans, rather than polyuria and polydipsia.
✅ Frequent nighttime snoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cold intolerance and constipation:
Incorrect: Obesity alone does not indicate hypothyroidism. Hypothyroid-related weight gain is usually accompanied by bradycardia and dry skin.
❌ History of neonatal hypotonia:
Incorrect: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) refers to a genetic disorder associated with infantile hypotonia, hyperphagia, and obesity. Developmental delays and other hallmark features are typically evident before adolescence.
❌ Easy bruising and purple abdominal striae:
Incorrect: These features suggest Cushing syndrome, which is associated with wide, purple striae, proximal muscle weakness, and facial rounding (moon facies). Striae seen in obesity are usually narrow and lighter in color.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. Body mass index (BMI) is at the 96<sup>th</sup> percentile for age and sex. There is no significant medical history, but the child spends several hours a day playing video games and consuming sugary beverages. Academic performance is strong. There are no reports of fatigue or constipation. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals increased waist circumference, with no signs of pubertal delay, dysmorphic features, or endocrine abnormalities. The caregiver expresses concern about weight gain over the past year and asks for guidance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Dietary modifications and increased physical activity

questions.solution:
This child’s BMI is above the 95th percentile, confirming a diagnosis of obesity. The first-line approach to pediatric obesity is intensive behavioral and lifestyle intervention, including dietary changes and increased physical activity.

Effective management also requires a strong therapeutic alliance. Clinicians should explore the family’s routines, values, and barriers to change, using shared decision-making to set individualized goals. Building trust and understanding the social context are essential for sustaining long-term behavior change. Early intervention is critical to prevent complications such as type 2 diabetes mellitus, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and hypertension.

Key lifestyle recommendations include reducing sugar-sweetened beverages and processed foods, increasing intake of fruits, vegetables, and fiber, promoting balanced meals, encouraging at least 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity daily, limiting screen time to under two hours per day, setting realistic, family-centered goals, and supporting healthy sleep habits.

If lifestyle changes are insufficient, adjunctive pharmacologic therapy, such as GLP-1 receptor agonists, may be considered, particularly for children with severe obesity or related comorbidities. For adolescents with severe obesity and complications that do not respond to other interventions, bariatric surgery may be an appropriate option.

Option Analysis

❌ Bariatric surgery referral:
Incorrect: Bariatric surgery is reserved for adolescents with severe obesity and significant comorbidities. It is not indicated in children without prior structured lifestyle intervention and failed attempts at weight management.
✅ Dietary modifications and increased physical activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Appetite suppressants:
Incorrect: Pharmacologic therapy (e.g. GLP-1 receptor agonists) may be considered for adolescents with severe obesity and comorbidities. They are not first-line therapy.
❌ Thyroid function testing:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism is a rare cause of obesity in children and typically presents with additional symptoms, such as fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, and poor linear growth. This patient’s presentation does not suggest thyroid dysfunction.
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin may be considered for adolescents with impaired glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, or polycystic ovary syndrome. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment without these conditions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to a cough that has persisted for the past six weeks. A caregiver reports that the cough is worse at night and when lying flat, and that the child occasionally wakes up gasping for air. Additional symptoms include fatigue, decreased appetite, and intermittent chest discomfort. There is no history of fever, recent illness, weight loss, or known exposure to sick contacts. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate is 105/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals mild jugular venous distension and diminished breath sounds in the upper chest bilaterally without wheezing or crackles. Non-tender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy is present. No clubbing or peripheral edema is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 10-year-old child presents with chronic cough, positional dyspnea, and cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, which raises concern for an anterior mediastinal mass. In children, the most probable cause is lymphoma, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Both types of lymphoma can present with painless lymphadenopathy and airway compression symptoms, including a cough that worsens when lying flat.       

When evaluating a pediatric patient with a cough, duration and pattern are key to narrowing the differential. Acute cough, lasting less than two weeks, may be due to viral infections or, if sudden in onset, foreign body aspiration. Chronic cough, persisting for more than four weeks, requires a broader approach. Structural airway anomalies often present in infancy, while older children with cough triggered by position may have airway compression from a mediastinal mass. A wet, productive cough with poor weight gain and frequent respiratory infections may suggest cystic fibrosis or primary ciliary dyskinesia. Evaluation may include chest imaging (e.g., X-ray, CT, MRI), spirometry, sweat chloride testing, genetic testing, nasal nitric oxide measurement, or bronchoscopy. Episodic coughs with identifiable triggers such as exercise or environmental exposures suggest asthma or allergic rhinitis, which can be confirmed with spirometry and allergy avoidance, respectively. In contrast, cough that resolves with sleep or distraction may indicate a habit cough.   

Option Analysis

❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Asthma commonly presents with episodic wheezing, cough that worsens at night, and exercise-induced symptoms. However, this patient has no wheezing, and the presence of jugular venous distension and lymphadenopathy is not characteristic of asthma.
✅ Lymphoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tracheomalacia:
Incorrect: Tracheomalacia typically presents in infancy with a barky cough that worsens with crying or feeding. It is uncommon in older children and does not account for the lymphadenopathy or jugular venous distension in this case. 
❌ Cystic fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis usually presents with a chronic productive cough, recurrent respiratory infections, digital clubbing, and poor weight gain. These features are absent in this case. 
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):
Incorrect: GERD-related cough often occurs at night but is typically associated with symptoms such as heartburn, sour taste, or postprandial discomfort. GERD would not explain the lymphadenopathy or jugular venous distension observed here.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a 3-week history of headaches and excessive drooling. These symptoms are associated with an unsteady gait. The headaches occur in the early morning and are often associated with vomiting, resulting in missed school days. Other than the headache, there is no history of pain, abnormal sensations, loss of consciousness, or fever. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the child is alert, cooperative, and oriented to time, place, and person. A wide-based gait is observed. Facial asymmetry is noted with deviation of the mouth to the right side and absence of the left nasolabial fold. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a diffuse, infiltrative, and minimally enhancing lesion in the pons. Which of the following physical examination findings is expected with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old boy presents with features consistent with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG), including early morning headaches and vomiting, difficulty swallowing (indicated by excessive drooling), facial weakness, and ataxia. Brain MRI confirms the diagnosis by revealing a characteristic mass in the pons. Hyperreflexia and clonus are also expected on examination.       

In children presenting with early morning headaches and vomiting, a brain tumor should be suspected, particularly in the midline or posterior fossa. The presence of ataxia suggests a posterior fossa mass. When hyperreflexia and clonus are observed along with cranial nerve palsies, the findings are more consistent with DIPG.         

DIPG is an aggressive brainstem tumor that typically affects children between 5 and 10 years of age. Common symptoms include visual changes (e.g. double vision), swallowing and speech difficulties, and, in younger children, signs such as early handedness. Physical examination often reveals multiple cranial nerve palsies and crossed findings, such as facial weakness on one side and contralateral hemiparesis. MRI characteristically shows a diffuse, expansile, infiltrative, and minimally enhancing mass in the pons. These tumors are diagnosed radiographically and are not amenable to surgical resection, resulting in a poor prognosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Torticollis  :
Incorrect: Torticollis can be seen in patients with posterior fossa masses. Although these patients may present with early morning headaches and ataxia, the presence of swallowing difficulty, hemiparesis, facial palsy, and brain MRI showing a mass in the pons is more consistent with diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
✅ Hyperreflexia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nystagmus  :
Incorrect: Nystagmus can be seen as part of Parinaud syndrome in patients with a pineal mass, which typically presents with upward gaze palsy and poorly reactive pupils. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would normally reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
❌ Short stature  :
Incorrect: Short stature, delayed linear growth, and delayed puberty are characteristic of suprasellar tumors due to pressure on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
❌ Tremors  :
Incorrect: Tremors can be seen in patients with brainstem and pineal masses. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a rapidly enlarging neck mass and increased difficulty in breathing over the past 6 hours. According to the parents, the child awoke with mild neck swelling that progressively increased throughout the day. The child has become increasingly irritable and is having difficulty swallowing. He has not consumed any food has been consumed since breakfast, and the parents report increased drooling. There is no history of trauma or recent upper respiratory illness. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Respiratory rate is 52/min. The child appears cyanotic. A mass is visible on the left lateral aspect of the neck, extending from the angle of the mandible to the clavicle. The overlying skin is taut but not erythematous. Inspiratory stridor and suprasternal and intercostal retractions are observed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the neck
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old child with a rapidly enlarging neck mass is clinically unstable with signs of airway compromise, including inspiratory stridor, retractions, drooling, and hypoxia. These findings indicate the need for urgent airway stabilization before any diagnostic testing or treatment can be safely performed. The airway should be secured via endotracheal intubation as soon as possible, ideally by the most experienced provider available.

The initial approach to a pediatric head or neck mass begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine clinical stability. Signs of instability include stridor, drooling, retractions, hypoxia, altered mental status, and poor perfusion. In such cases, immediate management should focus on securing the airway, providing oxygen, establishing intravenous access, and initiating continuous vital sign monitoring.

Imaging and diagnostic workup must be deferred until the patient is stable. In a stable patient, with normal breathing, oxygenation, perfusion, and mental status, a focused history and physical exam should be performed to guide the differential diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the neck:
Incorrect: CT imaging requires patient transport and supine positioning, which may precipitate respiratory decompensation in the setting of potential airway obstruction. Imaging can be pursued once the airway is secured and the patient is stable.
✅ Emergent endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Empiric intravenous (IV) antibiotics:
Incorrect: Although appropriate in suspected deep neck infections, antibiotics do not address the immediate threat of airway obstruction. Definitive airway management must precede antimicrobial therapy in this unstable patient.
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels:
Incorrect: Thyroid function testing is not indicated in the acute setting of respiratory distress. These studies are useful for outpatient evaluation of stable patients with suspected thyroid pathology, which typically presents with a midline neck mass.
❌ Needle aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: Invasive procedures in a child with an unstable airway may worsen the obstruction due to bleeding or edema. Aspiration may be considered after airway stabilization in patients with fluctuant masses consistent with abscesses.

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion on the left cheek. The parent reports that the area appeared slightly discolored at birth and has grown rapidly over the past month. The lesion does not seem to cause discomfort, and the infant feeds and sleeps normally. There is no history of trauma, fever, or recent illness. The infant was born full term via spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications. Immunizations are up-to-date. On examination, the infant is alert and well-appearing. A 3 cm soft, compressible, raised reddish-blue lesion is noted on the left cheek. The overlying skin is intact and warm to the touch. There is no surrounding erythema or tenderness. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Bruit on auscultation of the mass
Movement of the mass with tongue protrusion

questions.solution:
This 6-week-old infant presents with features typical of an infantile hemangioma: a soft, compressible, raised reddish-blue lesion that appeared shortly after birth and has grown rapidly during the first weeks of life. Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy. Although usually low-flow lesions, a bruit may occasionally be heard over larger or more superficial hemangiomas due to increased vascularity.

A focused history and physical examination is critical when evaluating pediatric head and neck masses, as it provides early insight into the probable cause, whether malignant, infectious, or developmental. Important historical features include age of onset, growth rate, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, or night sweats), and exposure history (e.g., animal contact, recent infections, or radiation). Physical findings such as location (midline versus lateral), consistency (soft, firm, or fluctuant), mobility, and skin changes (discoloration, warmth, or tenderness) help narrow the differential diagnosis. For example, a rapidly enlarging firm lateral mass with systemic symptoms may suggest malignancy, while a soft, fluctuant, erythematous lesion suggests infection. A midline, non-tender mass that enlarges slowly and moves with tongue protrusion is more consistent with a thyroglossal duct cyst.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Mass transillumination:
Incorrect: Transillumination is a feature of fluid-filled masses, such as cysts. Hemangiomas are vascular and solid and typically do not transilluminate.
✅ Bruit on auscultation of the mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Skin dimpling over the lesion:
Incorrect: Skin dimpling is characteristic of dermoid cysts, which are often subcutaneous with overlying skin tethering. Dermoid cysts are not vascular and do not typically grow rapidly after birth.
❌ Movement of the mass with tongue protrusion:
Incorrect: This finding is typical of a thyroglossal duct cyst, usually located in the midline neck. The described lesion is on the cheek and vascular in appearance, making a thyroglossal duct cyst unlikely.
❌ Purulent drainage from the mass:
Incorrect: Purulent drainage suggests an abscess or infected lymph node. Infantile hemangiomas are usually non-tender, non-draining, and not associated with signs of infection unless secondarily infected, which is not suggested here.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn delivered at term is being evaluated for irritability, jitteriness, and diarrhea. Maternal history is positive for seizures that are controlled with antiepileptics, and prescribed oxycodone was used after an orthopedic procedure during pregnancy. Delivery was uneventful; rupture of membrane was for 4 hours, and Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. There is no history of maternal fever or rash. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 188/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 80/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a high-pitched cry, no dysmorphic features, and no rash. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Bedside glucose is 72 mg/dL. Which of the following tests should most likely be ordered next as part of this workup?
questions.solution:
This 2-day-old newborn with a maternal history of prenatal opioid use presents with signs of withdrawal, including irritability, jitteriness, diarrhea, and a high-pitched cry. The work-up for neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) includes meconium analysis and urine toxicology to confirm the diagnosis.         

In cases of suspected prenatal teratogen exposure, it is essential to obtain a focused history and physical examination. If maternal opioid use, whether recreational or therapeutic, is identified, assess the infant for signs and symptoms of opioid withdrawal.         

Withdrawal symptoms can affect various systems, including the central nervous system (CNS), respiratory system, and gastrointestinal (GI) system. CNS symptoms include irritability, jitteriness, a high-pitched cry, sleep disturbances, hyperactive reflexes, tremors, and generalized seizures. Vasomotor disturbances include hyperthermia, sweating, frequent yawning, and nasal congestion. GI disturbances include poor feeding, excessive sucking, vomiting, and diarrhea. Testing for opioid withdrawal involves urine toxicology and meconium analysis. The treatment for most newborns with NAS is non-pharmacologic, including breastfeeding and minimizing environmental stimuli. Pharmacologic treatment is typically considered if conventional therapy fails and may include oral morphine and phenobarbital.    

Option Analysis

❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is useful for diagnosing congenital heart diseases, especially in the context of risk factors like gestational diabetes and congenital infections. However, the clinical signs of opioid withdrawal and the absence of features suggestive of a congenital heart defect make an echocardiogram unnecessary at this time.  
✅ Meconium analysis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Spine ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Spine ultrasound is typically part of the workup for infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs) to diagnose caudal regression syndrome. However, there is no maternal history of diabetes or gestational diabetes in this case, nor are there exam findings suggestive of this diagnosis. 
❌ Skeletal X-ray  :
Incorrect: Skeletal X-rays may help diagnose fetal warfarin syndrome, which is associated with nasal hypoplasia, stippled femoral epiphyses, and hypoplastic digits. However, this newborn shows no signs of these features, and the clinical presentation is more consistent with opioid withdrawal, making a skeletal X-ray unnecessary. 
❌ Valproic acid levels :
Incorrect: Measuring valproic acid levels is useful for confirming prenatal exposure to valproate, which is associated with neural tube defects like myelomeningocele, club foot, and cleft lip or palate. However, these features were not observed on physical exam, and the symptoms in this case are more consistent with opioid withdrawal, making this test less relevant.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with a 3-week history of a limp and pain while walking. A parent reports that the patient recently began playing basketball but has been lagging during running drills due to pain. The parent also notes a remote history of trauma at age six, when the child fell off a table and landed on his left hip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Weight is 90 kg (>97th percentile for age) and height is 165 cm. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the left hip without visible deformity. There is external rotation of the hip with passive flexion. The patient ambulates with a limp. Plain radiographs are obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia; Public domain.

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip

questions.solution:
Top: Displacement of the femoral head in relation to the neck on radiograph. Bottom: Radiograph after surgical fixation of the femoral head to the femoral neck. Reproduced from Wikipedia; Public domain.       

This patient, older than 10 years and with obesity, presents with a limp and hip pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation, passive flexion prompts external rotation of the hip, and radiographs show displacement of the femoral head relative to the femoral neck, consistent with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Management requires urgent orthopedic consultation for in situ fixation to prevent further slippage and complications.        

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) are distinct pediatric hip disorders that commonly present with a limp. SCFE occurs when weakness at the growth plate causes the femoral head to slip posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the neck. In contrast, LCPD results from disrupted blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis. Clinical history, physical examination, and imaging help distinguish between the two. Key differentiating features are summarized in the chart below.   



Option Analysis

✅ Orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rest and physical therapy:
Incorrect: Rest and physical therapy are not appropriate for initial management of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. Definitive treatment requires surgical stabilization to prevent further slippage and complications. Physical therapy may be considered only after fixation. 
❌ Ibuprofen and limited weight-bearing:
Incorrect: This strategy is commonly used in the management of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, not slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. SCFE requires urgent orthopedic referral and surgical intervention, not conservative management. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip:
Incorrect: While MRI can be useful in early or atypical cases of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) when radiographs are inconclusive, this patient presents with classic findings on X-ray. An MRI is unnecessary. 
❌ Petrie casting:
Incorrect: Petrie casting is used in the management of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease and is not indicated for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. This technique involves bilateral long leg casts with a connecting bar to maintain hip abduction.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department on a cold winter night for evaluation of colicky behavior. The parent reports the infant has been increasingly fussy over the past 24 hours with decreased feeding. There is no history of fever, cough, congestion, nausea, or vomiting. The infant was born full term without complications during pregnancy or delivery and has been meeting developmental milestones. The parent reports that the patient’s mother and older sibling are currently at home with a headache and nausea. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 170/min, blood pressure is 90/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the infant appears fatigued but is arousable with tactile stimulation. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Point-of-care blood glucose testing is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with colicky behavior and reduced feeding during the winter months. Several family members at home are also experiencing non-specific symptoms such as headache and nausea. Together, these findings suggest carbon monoxide poisoning.  Additional risk factors for this condition may include the use of wood-burning stoves, kerosene heaters, old furnaces, or indoor fireplaces.

Inhalation or ingestion of various household substances can cause significant morbidity and mortality in children. Increased mobility and frequent hand-to-mouth behavior during the toddler and preschool years increase the risk of unintentional or exploratory exposures. While some toxins, such as lead, typically cause vague, subacute, or chronic symptoms, exposure to caustic agents, carbon monoxide, organophosphates, or toxic alcohols can lead to acute, potentially life-threatening presentations.

Careful history and physical examination often help identify the most likely cause. Key clinical features and historical clues for common ingestions are summarized in the chart below.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Lead poisoning:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning is unlikely in a non-ambulatory infant without known exposure to lead-containing sources such as peeling paint in older homes or contaminated water from lead pipes. When symptomatic, children often present with developmental delays, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, or anemia.
✅ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Organophosphate toxicity:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning causes a cholinergic toxidrome, characterized by diarrhea, urinary frequency, pinpoint pupils, bronchospasm, bradycardia, vomiting, lacrimation, and excessive salivation. These features are not present in this infant.
❌ Button battery ingestion:
Incorrect: Ingestion of a button battery usually causes caustic injury to the esophagus and leads to symptoms such as drooling, vomiting, dysphagia, or respiratory distress. This clinical presentation does not match the current history.
❌ Ethylene glycol ingestion:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol poisoning typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. A history of exposure is common, and symptoms usually do not involve multiple household members.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after being found with an open, unmarked bottle of liquid in the living room. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 108/min, blood pressure is 105/67 mmHg, respiratory rate is 27/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the child appears fatigued. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. A venous blood gas reveals a pH of 7.42. Additional laboratory findings are obtained and detailed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 142 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.2 mEq/L
 Chloride  107 mEq/L
 Bicarbonate 28 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 18
 Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL
  Glucose 90
 Albumin 3.2 g/dL
 Serum osmolality 328 mOsm/kg

 Urinalysis
 Color Clear
 Specific gravity 1.013
 Glucose Negative
 Blood Negative
 Leukocyte esterase Negative
 Nitrites Negative
 Leukocytes 1-2/hpf
 Erythrocytes 1-2/hpf
 Dysmorphic RBCs Absent
 Ketones Large
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents following an unwitnessed ingestion of an unknown liquid. Laboratory findings show ketosis and an elevated osmolar gap of 33 mOsm/kg (calculated using the formula below) without a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings strongly suggest toxic alcohol ingestion, specifically isopropyl alcohol. Isopropyl alcohol is commonly found in hand sanitizers, rubbing alcohol, and some household cleaning products. It is metabolized to acetone, which causes ketosis without an anion-gap metabolic acidosis. It is often associated with a “fruity” breath odor.

Formulating and prioritizing a differential diagnosis in a pediatric patient with a household substance exposure depends on a careful history and physical examination. Patients often have a history of witnessed ingestion or known exposure to a specific toxin, such as organophosphates. Most present with nonspecific symptoms like nausea and vomiting accompanied by vital sign abnormalities. In non-verbal pediatric patients, important clues such as the presence of open containers, pill bottles, or similar symptoms in family members can help narrow the differential diagnosis.

Basic laboratory testing should be obtained to assess for metabolic abnormalities or anemia, as seen in cases like lead poisoning. For suspected toxic alcohol ingestion, findings on a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and serum osmolality can help distinguish between different alcohols, as outlined in the table above.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Methanol toxicity:
Incorrect: Methanol toxicity typically follows ingestion of windshield washer fluid or industrial solvents. Laboratory findings would usually show an elevated osmolar gap and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis, the latter of which is not present here.
✅ Isopropyl alcohol toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ethylene glycol toxicity:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol toxicity occurs after ingestion of antifreeze. Laboratory findings would usually show an elevated osmolar gap and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis, the latter of which is not present here.
❌ Ethanol toxicity:
Incorrect: While acute ethanol toxicity is also associated with an elevated osmolar gap without a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, the presence of large ketones in the urine is more consistent with isopropyl alcohol toxicity.
❌ Organophosphate toxicity:
Incorrect: Organophosphate toxicity presents with symptoms of a cholinergic toxidrome, including diarrhea, urinary frequency, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, emesis, lacrimation, and salivation (DUMBBELS mnemonic). This patient's physical examination shows no such findings.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of sudden-onset vomiting, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea. A parent reports that symptoms began shortly after a birthday party where the child ate potato salad and cream-filled pastries. Temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 90 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the child appears fatigued with tacky mucous membranes and capillary refill of < 2 seconds. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value Result
 White blood cell (WBC) count 8,500/µL
 Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL
 Platelet count 290,000/µL
 Sodium 138 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 12 mg/dL
 Fecal lactoferrin Negative
 Stool microscopy Gram-positive cocci in clusters
questions.solution:
This presentation is consistent with acute gastroenteritis resulting from Staphylococcus aureus infection, a toxin-mediated illness that typically presents with rapid onset vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps within hours of consuming contaminated food. This patient’s history of eating high-risk foods such as potato salad, in addition to the stool microscopy showing gram-positive cocci in clusters, supports this diagnosis. S. aureus gastroenteritis is typically self-limited and resolves within 24-48 hours. The best management strategy is oral rehydration to correct fluid losses and antiemetics to reduce vomiting, ensuring adequate hydration and symptom control.

Management of acute pediatric gastroenteritis begins with assessing dehydration to guide fluid replacement. For mild to moderate dehydration, oral rehydration therapy with an oral rehydration solution is first-line if the child can drink. An antiemetic such as ondansetron can reduce vomiting and facilitate oral intake. Severe dehydration or shock requires intravenous isotonic fluids such as normal saline and hospital admission.

Antibiotics are not indicated for S. aureus preformed toxin-related illness and are generally avoided unless an invasive bacterial infection is suspected or confirmed. In children older than 6 months, zinc supplementation can reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea, with the strongest evidence in settings where zinc deficiency is common. Probiotics are not recommended routinely because evidence for benefit is mixed, although selected preparations may offer modest symptom reduction. Routine antimicrobial therapy and stool testing are not needed in uncomplicated presentations since most infections resolve with supportive care.   

Option Analysis

❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with gastroenteritis caused by preformed enterotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus, for which azithromycin is not used to treat. It is reserved for specific invasive or febrile bacterial diarrheas such as Campylobacter jejuni or selected cases of traveler’s diarrhea based on severity and local resistance patterns.
✅ Oral rehydration and antiemetics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hospital admission for intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: This child presents without tachycardia, hypotension, or mental status changes, which indicates mild dehydration. Initial management should start with oral rehydration, using an antiemetic to facilitate intake. Intravenous fluids and admission are appropriate for severe dehydration, shock, or failure of oral therapy.
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with gastroenteritis caused by preformed enterotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus, which this antibiotic does not treat. It is considered for pathogens such as Shigella or Yersinia, depending on local susceptibility.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with a S. aureus preformed toxin-related illness, for which doxycycline is not indicated. It may be used for Vibrio cholerae to reduce stool volume and duration.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for evaluation of recurrent vomiting for one year. The episodes occur every few weeks, lasting 1-2 days, in which the patient vomits multiple times an hour. The episodes are associated with headaches and light sensitivity. There is no fever, vision changes, diarrhea, abdominal pain, or recent travel history. The patient’s appetite and growth have been normal, and there is no history of recent illness or medication use. Family history is notable for migraines in a parent. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears well, and the abdominal examination is unremarkable with no tenderness, rebound, or guarding. There is no papilledema. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown in the table below. Which of the following additional clinical factors is most likely to be present? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     13.0 g/dL    
 White blood cell count     7,200/µL    
 Serum sodium     137 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     3.9 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     22 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen     16 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     0.7 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent episodes of vomiting lasting 1-2 days, with complete resolution between episodes – a classic presentation of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS). The patient lacks signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as vision changes, altered mental status, papilledema, and focal neurological deficits. CVS is frequently associated with migraines and may be triggered by stress, infections, or sleep deprivation. Early morning vomiting is a hallmark feature of CVS and is likely to be identified on further history. Adolescents should be questioned about marijuana use, as it is strongly associated with this condition.       

A focused history is essential in narrowing the differential diagnosis for a pediatric patient presenting with vomiting. Key aspects to explore include the duration, frequency, and characteristics of the vomiting (e.g., bilious, non-bilious, or bloody) and any associated symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. It is also important to inquire about recent infections, dietary changes, medication use, and potential exposures to toxins or allergens.       

Physical examination should assess hydration status (e.g., capillary refill, skin turgor, mucous membranes) and evaluate for signs of systemic or localized pathology, such as abdominal tenderness, guarding, or neurologic deficits. Additional clues, such as weight loss, growth delay, or atopic conditions, can help refine the differential diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Blood in the vomitus:
Incorrect: Repeated retching can lead to minor esophageal tears (Mallory-Weiss tears), resulting in blood-streaked vomitus. However, hematemesis is not a typical feature of cyclic vomiting syndrome.
✅ Early morning vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vomiting associated with oral intake:
Incorrect: Cyclic vomiting syndrome is not triggered by oral intake. This condition occurs in stereotypical episodes, regardless of food consumption. Vomiting immediately after eating is more typical of eosinophilic esophagitis or gastroparesis. 
❌ Constipation:
Incorrect: While changes in bowel habits, such as constipation or diarrhea, can occur in some gastrointestinal disorders, they are not typically associated with cyclic vomiting syndrome. 
❌ Dysuria:
Incorrect: Dysuria is not associated with cyclic vomiting syndrome and would point toward a urinary tract infection or genitourinary pathology. It would be expected in a patient with fever, flank pain, or urinary frequency. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with cyclic vomiting syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to clinic due to difficulty swallowing and recurrent vomiting over the past six months. The vomiting is non-bilious and occurs after meals, especially when eating solid foods such as bread and chicken. The child has started eating very slowly and will avoid meals altogether. There is no fever, abdominal pain, or diarrhea, but the child has lost 1.5 kg (3.3 lbs.) since his last visit eight months ago. Past medical history is significant for asthma and seasonal allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. The child appears in no acute distress. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Serum IgE and food allergy testing

questions.solution:
This 10-year-old child presents with symptoms suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), including dysphagia, postprandial non-bilious vomiting, and a history of atopy (e.g., asthma and seasonal allergies). EoE is an immune-mediated condition that requires esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy for diagnosis. Characteristic esophageal findings include rings, strictures, or linear furrows, along with histologic eosinophilic infiltration.       

The diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with vomiting begins with a focused history and physical examination. Acute vomiting with bilious emesis may indicate intestinal obstruction from conditions such as superior mesenteric artery syndrome or pancreatitis. Imaging (e.g., upper GI series, CT, ultrasound) and laboratory studies (e.g., amylase, lipase) can help differentiate these conditions. The presence of diarrhea may point to infectious gastroenteritis, and stool studies can identify the pathogen. In the absence of diarrhea or bilious vomiting, infections like UTI or pharyngitis may be considered and evaluated with urine studies or rapid strep testing, respectively.        

Chronic vomiting requires evaluation for conditions such as EoE, celiac disease, or gastroparesis, often utilizing EGD with biopsy, total IgA and anti-TTG IgA levels, or motility studies. Episodic vomiting, particularly early morning vomiting, suggests cyclic vomiting syndrome or increased intracranial pressure and warrants an assessment using Rome IV criteria or neuroimaging, respectively. In contrast, vomiting related to food or fluid intake may indicate an eating disorder or uteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, which should be confirmed with a validated screening tool or renal ultrasound, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Serum IgE and food allergy testing:
Incorrect: While serum IgE and food allergy testing can identify potential triggers and guide subsequent management for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), they do not diagnose the condition. These tests should be performed only after confirmation of the condition via endoscopy. 
✅ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal (UGI) series:
Incorrect: A UGI series can identify structural abnormalities (e.g., strictures or malrotation). However, this test lacks the sensitivity to diagnose eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). EoE is primarily a histologic diagnosis, and EGD with biopsy is the preferred diagnostic tool. 
❌ Referral to a dietician:
Incorrect: Dietary management is a treatment option for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), particularly with elimination diets (i.e. empiric or targeted food elimination). However, dietary changes should follow diagnostic confirmation via EGD with biopsy. Implementing dietary changes without a confirmed diagnosis may delay appropriate treatment. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: CT imaging is not indicated in a patient with vomiting and dysphagia suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). Head imaging is more relevant in cases where neurologic symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure are present in association with vomiting.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of vomiting for two months. The vomiting is sporadic, non-bilious, and non-bloody, typically occurring after meals. The patient also reports occasional diarrhea, bloating, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Parents are concerned because of unintentional weight loss of 3 kg (6.6 lbs.). Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus, diagnosed one year ago, which has been well-controlled. Growth is at the 15th percentile for weight and the 25th percentile for height. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension but no tenderness or organomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     11.0 g/dL    
 Mean corpuscular volume     74 fL    
 Serum glucose     145 mg/dL    
 Serum sodium     139 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     4.0 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     23 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient's recurrent vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss, bloating, and history of type 1 diabetes mellitus suggest celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder in which ingestion of gluten triggers an immune response that damages the small intestine lining, leading to malabsorption. The patient’s laboratory findings further support this diagnosis, as iron deficiency anemia is commonly associated with celiac disease. The next step is to measure serum anti-TTG IgA, the preferred screening test. If positive, biopsy confirmation via esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is recommended.        

The diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with vomiting starts with a focused history and physical examination. Acute vomiting with bilious emesis may indicate intestinal obstruction from conditions like superior mesenteric artery syndrome or pancreatitis, which can be differentiated through imaging and laboratory studies. Diarrhea may suggest infectious gastroenteritis, which can be confirmed with stool studies.        

Chronic vomiting with a change in bowel habits may point to constipation or celiac disease. Celiac disease is diagnosed with total IgA and anti-TTG IgA levels and EGD with biopsy. Vomiting related to food intake may indicate eosinophilic esophagitis or gastroparesis, which are diagnosable with EGD or gastric emptying study, respectively. Episodic early morning vomiting suggests cyclic vomiting syndrome or increased intracranial pressure, which require Rome IV criteria or neuroimaging. Vomiting related to food or fluid intake may also indicate an eating disorder or uteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, diagnosable with a validated screening tool or renal ultrasound, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound is not useful for diagnosing celiac disease. It may be indicated to assess for structural abnormalities or obstruction, but these are not suggested by this patient’s presentation.
✅ Serum anti-TTG IgA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastric emptying study:
Incorrect: A gastric emptying study is used to diagnose gastroparesis, which presents with early satiety, nausea, and abdominal distension. This patient is at increased risk of gastroparesis due to underlying type 1 diabetes. However, it typically requires years of poor glycemic control to develop, which is not present here. 
❌ Stool culture and ova/parasite  :
Incorrect: The patient’s chronic symptoms and lack of fever, acute diarrhea, or travel history make an infectious etiology unlikely.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal series:
Incorrect: An upper GI series is used to assess for mechanical obstructions or motility disorders but does not provide sufficient diagnostic information for celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of low back pain. The patient is participating in gymnastics training and has had difficulty preparing for an upcoming competition due to persistent low back pain that is worse with movement and relieved with rest. The patient is otherwise healthy. He has not had any recent injury or trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the low back is noted to be hyperlordotic. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the back. The straight leg test is negative bilaterally. A radiograph of the lumbar spine is shown below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents for evaluation of low back. Imaging reveals grade 1 L4 on L5 spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis refers to anterior displacement of the vertebral body with respect to the adjacent vertebral bodies. Spondylolisthesis can be caused by degenerative changes in the spine in adult patients. It can also be congenital and seen in children. In both adolescents and children, pars defects can be caused by overuse of the low back, mainly from sports that involve repetitive back bend-like motion. This can lead to fracture of the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis) which may progress to anterior subluxation of one vertebral body with respect to an adjacent vertebral body (spondylolisthesis).  

Lumbar spondylolisthesis can present with intermittent localized low back pain. The pain is typically worsened with  flexing and extending at the affected segment of the vertebrae. There may be pain with direct palpation on physical examination. Patients can also have radicular pain if the exiting nerve roots become compressed.  

Radiography is the initial test for diagnosing spondylolisthesis. CT of the spine has the highest sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis and may be performed after spinal radiographs are completed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Compression of L4 nerve root:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from bulging intervertebral discs. The symptoms often include low back pain with associated radiation down the lower extremities. A straight leg raise is often positive with this condition. This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with lumbar radiculopathy.  
❌ Lytic bone lesions:
Incorrect: The above lumbar film does not demonstrate lytic bony lesions, which often appear as punched-out areas of bone.  
❌ Lumbar erector spinae weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness of the lumbar erector spinae can lead to low back pain.  However this would not increase the risk of spondylolisthesis seen in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Narrowing of the intraspinal canal:
Incorrect: Spinal stenosis is an uncommon condition in adolescent patients. It most commonly presents in elderly patients with pain that is worsened with walking or activity and is relieved by sitting, lying down, or bending forward at the waist.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a wellness visit. Past medical history is notable for cystic fibrosis. The patient has had several episodes of pneumonia over the past year and currently has a persistent cough with production of large quantities of viscous sputum. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for rhonchi throughout the bilateral lung fields. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with a history of cystic fibrosis and recurrent pulmonary infections was most likely prescribed N-acetylcysteine.    

N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that liquefies mucus and is often used in patients with thick secretions, such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis. This medication works by disrupting disulfide bonds within the mucosal polypeptides. N-acetylcysteine can also be administered to treat acetaminophen overdose by regenerating glutathione and is used off-label as a prophylaxis against contrast-induced nephropathy.  

N-acetylcysteine may cause an anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously and can also cause gastrointestinal side effects (e.g. nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, flatus).  

Option Analysis

❌ Dextromethorphan:
Incorrect: Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that acts by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors and additionally acts as a weak mu receptor antagonist. The medication can lead to cough suppression, which may further impair sputum clearance.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is an α-agonist that can be used as a nasal decongestant. This medication causes vasoconstriction and reduces mucosal edema. However, phenylephrine would not enhance sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds.
❌ Guaifenesin:
