Incorrect: Guaifenesin is an expectorant that increases mucosal clearance. It works by stimulating the production of hydrated respiratory secretions.  
❌ Dornase alfa:
Incorrect: Dornase alfa can assist with sputum clearance in patients with cystic fibrosis. This medication works by depolymerizing DNA within sputum and reducing its viscosity.   
✅ N-acetylcysteine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parent because of bizarre behavior, confusion, and hallucinations. A neighbor had advised the mother that several neighborhood youths had been taken to nearby hospitals after ingesting wildflowers and developing similar symptoms. The patient is mumbling, shaking, and picking at nonexistent items in the emergency room. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows flushed skin and dry oral mucosa. The pupils are dilated and nonreactive to light and accommodation. Bowel sounds are decreased. Which of the following substances can help reverse this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hallucinations, confusion, flushed skin, and dry mucous membranes. He has anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to ingestion of jimson weed flowers. Jimson weed contains large concentrations of the anticholinergic compounds atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine.  

The classic anticholinergic (technically “antimuscarinic”) syndrome is remembered as “red as a beet” (flushed skin), “hot as a hare” (hyperthermia), “dry as a bone” (dry mucous membranes, no sweating), “blind as a bat” (blurred vision, cycloplegia), and “mad as a hatter” (confusion, delirium). Patients usually have sinus tachycardia and dilated pupils. Agitated delirium or coma may be present. Muscle twitching is common, but seizures are unusual unless the patient has ingested an antihistamine or tricyclic antidepressant, which can also cause anticholinergic symptoms. Urinary retention is common, especially in older men.  

The antidote for the anticholinergic toxidrome is intravenous physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that counteracts the effects of anticholinergic drugs by preventing the degradation of acetylcholine. Intravenous physostigmine is given if the individual presents with both peripheral and central anticholinergic toxicity, such as anhidrosis from peripheral toxicity and delirium from central toxicity.  



Option Analysis

❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic agent and can be used to reverse organophosphate poisoning (cholinesterase inhibitors). This patient's history and symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. A cholinesterase inhibitor is indicated for the reversal of this patient’s symptoms.   
✅ Physostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is an opioid pain medication that exerts its effects on the brain. In contrast, this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity. Morphine would not be useful in reversing this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reverse acute opioid toxicity. This patient's history and symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. A cholinesterase inhibitor is indicated for the reversal of symptoms.   
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect: Thiamine (B1) supplementation is usually given to patients who are chronically deficient due to alcohol use disorder or malnutrition, which, if untreated, can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for evaluation of fever, cough, and weakness for the past month. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse lymph node enlargement, mild hepatomegaly, and scattered petechiae. Further evaluation confirms the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient is started on the appropriate chemotherapeutic agent that causes lysis of neoplastic cells. The patient also receives therapy with allopurinol during the treatment. Which of the following enzymes in purine metabolism is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and is receiving chemotherapy in combination with allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome. Allopurinol blocks xanthine oxidase, a crucial enzyme in purine metabolism.  

Uric acid is a natural waste product of purines, which are one of the building blocks of DNA and RNA.  During their metabolism, purines are first degraded to hypoxanthine. Afterwards, hypoxanthine is oxidized twice by xanthine oxidase to first become xanthine and then uric acid. Uric acid circulates in the bloodstream until it reaches the kidneys where it is secreted into the proximal tubules and eventually excreted via urine.  

Chronic gout medications inhibit different steps in purine metabolism to prevent the build up of uric acid. Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol, reduce uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. Additionally, febuxostat, a non-purine inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, is more selective than allopurinol. Lastly, rasburicase, a recombinant version of urate oxidase, facilitates the conversion of uric acid to a more soluble form, allantoin.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Cyclooxygenase is not involved in purine metabolism. It plays an important role in prostaglandin synthesis and is inhibited by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs such as naproxen.  
❌ Angiotensin-converting enzyme:
Incorrect: Angiotensin-converting enzyme is not involved in purine metabolism. Allopurinol acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which converts hypoxanthine to uric acid.  
❌ Phenylalanine hydroxylase:
Incorrect: Phenylalanine hydroxylase is not involved in purine metabolism. It facilitates the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine and is deficient in patients with phenylketonuria.  
✅ Xanthine oxidase:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Urate oxidase:
Incorrect: Urate oxidase facilitates the conversion of uric acid to a more soluble form, allantoin. Rasburicase is a recombinant version of urate oxidase. In contrast, allopurinol acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for evaluation of fever, cough, and weakness for the past month. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse lymph node enlargement, mild hepatomegaly, and scattered petechiae. Further evaluation confirms the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient is started on the appropriate chemotherapeutic agent that causes lysis of neoplastic cells. He also receives therapy with rasburicase. Rasbricase will most likely reduce the risk of which of the following in this patient?
questions.solution:
Recombinant urate oxidases include pegloticase and rasburicase. These medications help oxidize uric acid to allantoin, which is a more soluble and easier to excrete molecule.  

In terms of medicine-specific indications, pegloticase is used to treat chronic refractory gout. Rasburicase is used for the prevention and treatment of tumor lysis syndrome in patients with lymphoma or leukemia who are receiving anticancer therapy. Common side effects include anaphylaxis, methemoglobinemia, and hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.  



Option Analysis

❌ Chemotherapy-induced nausea:
Incorrect: Serotonin receptor antagonists, such as ondansetron, prevent serotonin-mediated stimulation of vagal fibers in the small bowel and are effective in managing chemotherapy-induced nausea. In contrast, rasburicase is used to prevent tumor lysis syndrome.   
❌ Malignancy-related anorexia:
Incorrect: Progesterone analogs and corticosteroids are effective treatment options for malignancy-related anorexia caused by elevated levels of circulating inflammatory cytokines. In contrast, rasburicase is used to prevent tumor lysis syndrome.   
✅ Tumor-lysis induced renal failure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malignancy-related hypercalcemia:
Incorrect:  Opioid-induced constipation
❌ Opioid-induced constipation:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone, an opioid antagonist, can be used to treat opioid-induced constipation. Rasburicase is not an effective option.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician’s office for evaluation of ear pain. The parent reports that the patient has been holding the right ear in discomfort for the past 24 hours. They report an associated cough and nasal congestion. The patient was born full term and has otherwise been healthy since birth. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), blood pressure is 107/55 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with a purulent effusion and impaired mobility following insufflation. There is no otorrhea present. The patient is started on high-dose amoxicillin and acetaminophen for analgesia. Forty-eight hours later, the patient returns for reassessment with persistent ear discomfort. Repeat otoscopic examination demonstrates persistent erythema, bulging, and purulent effusion of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with acute ear pain and findings suggestive of acute otitis media. Diagnosis of acute otitis media is dependent on direct otoscopy of the tympanic membrane, which in this case, revealed an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with impaired mobility. This patient has evidence of severe otitis media based on his fever >39 °C, mandating antibiotic therapy. Given the inadequate clinical response to initial treatment with high-dose amoxicillin, the best next step in management is to broaden antibiotic coverage by changing amoxicillin to amoxicillin-clavulanate.    

Once a diagnosis of acute otitis media is established, severity can then be assessed by age, and duration of illness. Patients with symptoms greater than 48 hours, moderate to severe otalgia, or a temperature >39 °C can be diagnosed with severe acute otitis media and require antibiotic therapy with high dose amoxicillin. In contrast, patients with symptoms less than 48 hours, mild otalgia, or a temperature <39 °C can be diagnosed with non-severe acute otitis media and may or may not require antibiotic therapy based on the patient's age and the presence of unilateral vs bilateral symptoms. Patients who are two years and older with non-severe AOM may be watched for 48-72 hours with analgesia alone or prescribed high-dose amoxicillin with follow-up at 48-72 hours to determine treatment response. In contrast, children aged 6 months-23 months with bilateral symptoms and non-severe AOM require antibiotics, while those with unilateral symptoms can be offered the option of treatment vs. close observation. Those with persistent or worsening symptoms at 48-72 hours should receive amoxicillin if it has not yet been tried, or they should start on broadened antibiotic therapy with either amoxicillin-clavulanate. In children with a penicillin allergy, a second or third generation cephalosporin can be considered.     

In contrast, treatment of otitis externa is more straightforward. Patients/parents should receive counseling regarding ear hygiene and should be provided with oral analgesia, topical antibiotics (e.g. polymyxin, neomycin, fluoroquinolone), with consideration of a topical corticosteroid if there is significant associated swelling.   

Option Analysis

✅ Change amoxicillin to amoxicillin-clavulanate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete the course of amoxicillin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with persistent symptoms of otitis media following an initial treatment regimen with high-dose amoxicillin. This patient should receive broadened antibiotic therapy to adequately treat the infection. 
❌ Reassess in 48 hours!:
Incorrect: This patient presents with persistent symptoms of otitis media following an initial treatment regimen with high-dose amoxicillin. This patient should receive broadened antibiotic therapy to adequately treat the infection. 
❌ Administer topical corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Topical corticosteroids are not indicated in the treatment of acute otitis media. Topical corticosteroids can be administered to patients with otitis externa. 
❌ Administer topical neomycin:
 Incorrect: Topical neomycin is not indicated for this patient with acute otitis media. Topical neomycin can be considered for patients with otitis externa only if it can be confirmed that the tympanic membrane is intact.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and increased irritability for the past two days. His parent reports that he has had foul-smelling, dark urine. The patient has not had a cough, congestion, sore throat, or ear ache. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. He was born at 35 weeks gestation. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by chronic kidney disease and hypertension in the patient's mother. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears irritable and has suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Genitourinary examination shows uncircumcised male genitalia and a normal testicular examination. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Which of the following factors places the patient at the highest risk of developing the likely underlying condition?  

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
negative
Blood
negative
Leukocyte esterase  
Large
Nitrites
Positive
Leukocytes
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes
1-2/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
none

choices.text: Family history of chronic kidney disease secondary to type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
This patient presents with irritability, fever, and suprapubic tenderness with associated foul-smelling urine. Urinalysis shows evidence of large leukocyte esterase with positive nitrites and increased leukocytes. Together, these findings are concerning for a urinary tract infection (UTI).

In the pediatric population, biologically male patients who are uncircumcised have a higher risk of urinary tract infections than do circumscribed patients. Female infants have a higher risk of UTIs than male patients. Patients with obstructive urologic abnormalities and those with vesicoureteral reflux are at increased risk of developing UTIs.

Urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common bacterial infection in children that can involve any part of the urinary tract and is usually caused by gastrointestinal flora, such as Escherichia coli. Clinical presentation often depends on the patient’s age. Young, non-verbal patients often present with fever, increased fussiness, poor feeding, or lethargy in the absence of associated infectious symptoms (e.g. cough, congestion, sore throat). Older, verbal patients may report dysuria, polyuria, hematuria, or, in the case of pyelonephritis, back or flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. Regardless of age, patients will often have foul-smelling, dark urine. Patients should be screened for risk factors and examined for signs of complicated disease such as costo-vertebral angle tenderness, dehydration, and signs of sepsis (e.g. skin mottling).  

Option Analysis

✅ Uncircumcised penis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Male sex:
Incorrect: Female sex, not male sex, is a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections.  
❌ Family history of chronic kidney disease secondary to type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: A family history of chronic kidney disease from type 2 diabetes mellitus is not a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections in pediatric patients.  
❌ Premature birth:
Incorrect: Premature birth is not a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections later in life.  
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Biological males who are less than 12 months of age are at increased risk of developing urinary tract infections than are older males.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the primary care office by her parents for a well-check visit. The parents are concerned that the child cannot stand yet. She can crawl and sit, turn her head to voices, and share interest in activities. She waves “bye-bye” and says “mama and dada” with meaning. The child was born vaginally at 40 weeks gestation and weighed 7 lb, 9 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, weight is in the 57<sup>th</sup> percentile, length is 52<sup>nd</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 48<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the child is playful and interactive. She can move both arms and legs freely against gravity and resistance, and range of motion is intact.  She is not able to stand alone or with her hands held. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the parents and recheck at 18 months

questions.solution:
This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she cannot stand at the age of 12 months.  The first step in evaluating a child with a red flag for a developmental delay is to administer an age-appropriate developmental screening tool to assess and document the child’s development. The Ages and Stages Questionnaire is a developmental screening tool commonly used by healthcare professionals to provide a standardized assessment of a child’s developmental progress.

When a developmental red flag is identified during an infant’s developmental milestone assessment, an age-appropriate developmental screening tool should be used to further qualify the deficit and provide a standardized assessment of the child’s development status.  These tools typically assess the full range of a child’s development, since many areas are interrelated. The areas assessed include gross motor, fine motor, cognitive, social-emotional, and language development. A referral for a diagnostic evaluation of the child’s development may be indicated. Visual-motor tests and auditory milestone scales can be used to further assess for deficits. Timely implementation of interventions is key to helping prevent long-term deficits and further developmental delays. Services available for early intervention include speech-language, physical, and occupational therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer the Ages & Stages Questionnaire:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Refer for a hearing evaluation:
Incorrect: A hearing deficit can lead to developmental delays, especially in the areas of receptive and expressive communication. This child’s language and response to caregivers is developing as expected, making a significant hearing deficit that needs to be evaluated less likely.  
❌ Refer to an orthopedic specialist  :
Incorrect: An orthopedic specialist may be needed when developmental delays are caused by an anatomic abnormality. Although an underlying anatomic abnormality is possible in this patient, she has a normal physical examination and otherwise has expected strength and use of her legs, making a more detailed assessment with an age-appropriate developmental screening tool the best next step.  
❌ Begin physical therapy:
Incorrect: This child with a red flag for gross motor delay may need physical therapy to help her learn to stand and walk; however, she has not yet had an adequate evaluation with a detailed age-appropriate developmental screening tool.  
❌ Reassure the parents and recheck at 18 months:
Incorrect: This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she is not yet able to stand at the age of 12 months. Failure to recognize a developmental delay and intervene in a timely manner places children at risk for long-term disability and additional delays.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for the evaluation of a sore throat, poor appetite, and malaise for the past two days. The patient’s mother reports that several of her classmates are out sick due to similar symptoms for the past two weeks. Immunizations are up to date and past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tonsillar exudative infiltrates with enlarged erythematous tonsils. Anterior cervical nodes are enlarged and tender on palpation. Rapid streptococcal antigen testing is positive. Which of the following is the best next step for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give single dose of intramuscular penicillin G
Give oral penicillin V for ten days
Give intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from pharyngitis due to group A Streptococcal infection (Streptococcus pyogenes) and the preferred oral therapy is with penicillin V for ten days. Its use in streptococcal pharyngitis is associated with a reduced risk of subsequent acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Moreover, prevention of streptococcal infections (usually with benzathine penicillin once each month for several years) in persons who have had rheumatic fever is also important to prevent the recurrence of the disease. Other indications for penicillin G and V include:  
  •  Syphilis: It is the treatment of choice for all stages of syphilis (also used for prophylaxis of recent sexual partners) 
  •  β-Hemolytic Streptococcal Toxic Shock and Necrotizing Fasciitis: Penicillin is used in combination with clindamycin 
  •  Pneumococcal pneumonia and meningitis: only for parenteral therapy of sensitive isolates of pneumococci 
  •  Pulmonary and periodontal infections by anaerobes 
  •  Actinomycosis 
  •  Clostridial gas gangrene in combination with clindamycin 


Option Analysis

❌ Give single dose of intramuscular penicillin G:
Incorrect: Single-dose intramuscular (IM) penicillin G can be administered in patients with a history of acute rheumatic fever or in patients who are non-adherent to the initial medication regimen.
✅ Give oral penicillin V for ten days:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Give intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks:
Incorrect: Intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks is the treatment regimen for tertiary syphilis, which can manifest as gummas (granulomatous disease of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, bones, or viscera) or cardiovascular involvement in sexually active adults.
❌ Supportive care only:
Incorrect: Although supportive care measures (NSAIDs or acetaminophen) may be administered to relieve fever and pain, antibiotic treatment with penicillin is the mainstay of care and prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever.
❌ Give erythromycin for 14 days:
Incorrect: Erythromycin is the treatment of choice in patients with diphtheria pharyngitis. In contrast to group A Streptococcal pharyngitis, which has an acute onset, the onset of symptoms in diphtheria is usually gradual, beginning with mild pharyngeal injection and erythema. The hallmark of diphtheria is the formation of a tightly adherent gray membrane in the nares and throat (which is absent in this patient).

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of a rash. The rash appeared on his trunk a few days ago and has gradually increased in size. The rash is slightly itchy but not painful. The family visited Vermont for camping two weeks ago and spent most of the time outdoors. Past medical and family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?


Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient who recently visited a Lyme-endemic area has developed an annular (bull’s eye) rash, most likely has early localized Lyme disease. This patient should be treated with oral amoxicillin, which is a broad-spectrum penicillin.    

The mechanism of action of broad-spectrum penicillin (e.g., amoxicillin, ampicillin) is the same as that of penicillin (i.e., it blocks transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan in the cell wall). They have a wider spectrum of antibacterial activity than penicillin G but remain susceptible to penicillinases. Their clinical uses include indications similar to penicillin G as well as infections resulting from enterococci, Listeria monocytogenes, Escherichia coli, Proteus mirabilis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. When used in combination with inhibitors of penicillinases (e.g. clavulanic acid), their antibacterial activity is often enhanced. In enterococcal and listeria infections, ampicillin is synergistic with aminoglycosides.  

This class is categorized as pregnancy category B, meaning no risks have been found for use during pregnancy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Biopsy of the rash:
Incorrect: Biopsy of a rash should be done when the lesion does not resolve with initial treatment or malignancy is suspected. This patient’s bull’s eye rash is suggestive of erythema migrans, an early Lyme disease manifestation.
❌ Observation only:
Incorrect: For patients who present with a single erythema migrans (EM) lesion, treatment with oral therapy is necessary to reduce the duration of symptoms and prevent progression to later stages of Lyme disease.
❌ Start oral fluconazole:
Incorrect: Oral fluconazole can be used in the management of tinea corporis, which usually present with annular-shaped scaly lesions with raised borders. This patient’s bull’s eye rash is suggestive of erythema migrans, an early Lyme disease manifestation
✅ Start oral amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obtain Borrelia burgdorferi serology:
Incorrect: Borrelia burgdorferi serology is usually negative in the early stages of Lyme disease and is not required before starting the treatment

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a progressive skin rash and pain. The patient’s mother first noticed the rash around the neck folds and axillae two days ago while giving him a bath. The rash has worsened since then, involving the whole body. The patient is not eating well and has been irritable for the past two days. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse erythema and desquamation that is most prominent in the neck, axilla, and gluteal folds. The perioral area has crusting and the lips are dry and cracked. The mucous membranes are normal. When gentle pressure is applied at the erythematous area, the epidermis easily comes off. The patient is admitted and started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics. Which of the following is an example of the drug most suitable for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s fever and desquamating rash is consistent with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), caused by exotoxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus.   

Intravenous treatment with an antistaphylococcal antibiotic should begin promptly. Patients are typically initially treated with penicillinase-resistant penicillin (very narrow spectrum), such as oxacillin or nafcillin. These medications were created to fight bacteria like S. aureus and S. epidermidis, which often had the beta-lactamase enzyme. These antibiotics are resistant to beta-lactamase enzymes due to a bulky R-group that blocks access of β-lactamase to β-lactam rings.   

Other examples include methicillin, cloxacillin, and dicloxacillin. These antibiotics worked well initially, until some S. aureus developed the penicillin-binding protein (PBP) site mutations and became methicillin-resistant (MR) staphylococci (MRSA).  

Option Analysis

❌ Piperacillin:
Incorrect:  Piperacillin is an antipseudomonal penicillin that has activity against several Gram-negative rods, including Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and in some cases Klebsiella species. It is not effective in the management of staphylococcal skin infections.
❌ Clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has antistaphylococcal activity but is not recommended as a primary treatment because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).
✅ Nafcillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is a penicillinase-sensitive penicillin and is effective against H. influenzae, H. pylori, E. coli, Listeria monocytogenes, Proteus mirabilis, Salmonella, Shigella, and enterococci. It is not indicated in the management of SSSS.
❌ Penicillin G:
Incorrect: Penicillin G is the first-line medication for the treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis and prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever (ARF) in these patients. Moreover, they are also effective against infections caused by other organisms like S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and spirochetes. It is, however, not effective against Staphylococcus aureus due to its penicillinase sensitivity.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a worsening cough. The patient developed rhinorrhea, congestion, and mild non-productive cough two weeks ago. This week the coughing episodes have worsened and now occur without warning and are often followed by vomiting. The patient has no chronic conditions. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry is 98% on ambient air. Physical examination shows an alert and well-appearing child with bilateral subconjunctival hemorrhages. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Lungs are clear to auscultation, and no abnormal heart sounds are heard. Which medication is the most appropriate for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a paroxysmal nonproductive cough of ≥7 days associated with rhinorrhea, posttussive emesis, and subconjunctival hemorrhage is suggestive of whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis. Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin) are the first-line medications for the treatment of whooping cough and prophylaxis of household contacts.  

They are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit protein synthesis at the level of ribosomes by binding to the 50S subunit and blocking the translocation reaction.    

Macrolides have a broad spectrum of activity and are effective against many species of Campylobacter, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma and Legionella (atypical pneumonia), Gram-positive cocci (streptococcal infections in patients allergic to penicillin). Clarithromycin is combined with amoxicillin and omeprazole to treat Helicobacter pylori which causes peptic ulcers.  

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal intolerance (e.g., anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea) and prolonged QT interval. Rarely, erythromycin can cause hypersensitivity-based acute cholestatic hepatitis and is thus contraindicated in liver disease. Erythromycin and clarithromycin also inhibit several forms of hepatic cytochrome P450 and can increase the plasma levels of many medications.    

Resistance against macrolides typically involves one of the following mechanisms: 
  •  Drug efflux by an active pump mechanism 
  •  Methylation of rRNA-binding site 
  •  Macrolide hydrolysis by esterases produced by Enterobacteriaceae 
  • Chromosomal mutations that alter a 50S ribosomal protein 


Option Analysis

❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Oseltamivir is usually used in the treatment and prevention of influenza A and B, which presents with prolonged cough, nasal congestion, and high-grade fever that resolves in 5-7 days. Symptoms would not last for two weeks.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone has been used to manage epiglottitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae, which usually presents with dysphagia, drooling, high fever, and respiratory distress, none of which are present in this patient.
✅ Azithromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to manage heart failure. This patient’s episodic cough followed by vomiting suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to manage gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcer disease. Emesis associated with GERD is postprandial rather than posttussive, and GERD does not cause rhinorrhea or congestion.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy comes to the clinic for a routine annual health check-up. His past medical history includes asthma and allergic rhinitis. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler, a corticosteroid inhaler, and oral corticosteroids. He has not traveled out of the country recently. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Oral examination reveals white lesions on the tongue and posterior pharynx. These lesions bleed after scraping them with a tongue depressor. An antifungal agent is initiated that binds to ergosterol in fungal cell walls to create micropores. Which of the following is the most likely pharmacological agent used in the treatment of this patient?


Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with oropharyngeal white plaques that bleed when scraped, suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Patients who use corticosteroid inhalers are at increased risk of acquiring an oral candidal infection. Other high-risk groups include immunocompromised patients, those with dentures, infants, and those treated with radiation/chemotherapy to the head/neck.    

Nystatin is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane to create micropores, which alters fungal cell permeability and subsequent cell death.    

Oral “swish and swallow” nystatin preparations are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Topical formulations are useful in the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis and for diaper rashes. It can also be used topically for corneal, conjunctival, and cutaneous candidiasis. Adverse effects associated with nystatin use include nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.  



Option Analysis

❌ Griseofulvin :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oral candidiasis. 
❌ Ketoconazole :
Incorrect: Ketoconazole is a topically administered azole indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. It targets the fungal cell membrane and blocks lanosterol synthesis.
✅ Nystatin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caspofungin:
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit fungal cell wall synthesis. Indications for use include esophageal candidiasis and invasive aspergillosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. 
❌ Amphotericin B :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B does target the fungal cell membrane and create micropores, but it is not the treatment of choice for patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis due to the systemic toxicity associated with its use.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother for a routine well-child exam. The patient started walking at 9 months of age, and the mother has noticed that her daughter has an uneven gait. Height and weight are in the 89th and 80th percentiles, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 95/59 mmHg and pulse is 132/min. Thigh-length discrepancy on the left and asymmetry of the gluteal skin folds are noted. There is decreased abduction and limited range of motion of the left hip. A bilateral hip radiograph shows delayed ossification and femoral head dislocation on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment at this time?

choices.text: Closed hip reduction and spica cast
Open hip reduction and abduction splint

questions.solution:
This 11-month-old infant has physical examination and radiographic findings consistent with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The most appropriate treatment based on this patient’s age is referral to a pediatric orthopedist for closed hip reduction followed by a spica cast.    

Treatment for DDH is based on patient age. For patients < 6 months of age, an abduction splint, such as a Pavlik harness, which maintains hip flexion and leg abduction, is the recommended treatment. Patients between 6 months and 2 years of age who have DDH can be treated with closed reduction of the hip joint followed by placement of a spica cast. Children > 2 years of age typically require open reduction of the hip joint followed by a spica cast.    

Following treatment, patients should have routine radiographs of the hips to ensure proper development until patients are skeletally mature. Routine radiographs are also useful to screen for late complications of DDH repair, such as osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Closed hip reduction and spica cast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Follow-up bilateral hip radiographs:
Incorrect: Follow-up radiography are helpful to ensure proper development and screen for late complications (e.g. osteonecrosis, osteoarthritis) in patients with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) who have received definitive treatment with surgery and splinting. This patient has not yet had treatment, which should include closed hip reduction and spica cast.   
❌ Open hip reduction and abduction splint:
Incorrect: Open hip reduction is generally reserved for children > 2 years of age who are diagnosed with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Given this patient's age, closed hip reduction and spica cast is recommended.
❌ Pavlik harness:
Incorrect: An abduction splint, such as the Pavlik harness, is typically used to treat infants with DDH who are < 6 months of age. Given this patient's age, closed hip reduction and spica cast is recommended.
❌ Observation:
Incorrect: Observation of a pediatric patient with historical and examination findings suspicious for hip instability is not appropriate as it would delay definitive treatment and can result in complications.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, and decreased feeding. She was born at term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and had an unremarkable neonatal course. The patient's 3-year-old sibling recently started daycare. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), heart rate is 160/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 76/49 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant with a normal head circumference and no fullness of the anterior fontanelle. There is no rash, and her neck is supple. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable, and the abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic exam is nonfocal, and she is moving all four extremities. Bloodwork shows increased CRP and prolactin levels. Blood cultures are obtained, and a lumbar puncture is being performed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Supportive care until lumbar puncture culture and blood culture results return
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head

questions.solution:
This neonate presents with fever, irritability, decreased feeding, lethargy, and hemodynamic instability with an elevated CRP and prolactin level. Acute bacterial meningitis should be suspected, and the patient should immediately be started on empiric intravenous ampicillin and cefotaxime.  

The clinical presentation of acute meningitis in infants who are 60 days old or younger can be subtle, and they can progress rapidly. Ampicillin and cefotaxime provide broad coverage against the most common pathogens responsible for meningitis in this age group, including Group B Streptococcus, Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes. Ampicillin is particularly important for its effectiveness against Listeria. Ampicillin should be combined with an expanded-spectrum cephalosporin (i.e., ceftazidime, cefepime, cefotaxime) or with gentamicin. Patients with suspected meningitis require immediate initiation of empiric antibiotics following blood culture collection and lumbar puncture; however, antibiotics should not be delayed until lumbar puncture is performed in critically ill children. Alongside antibiotic therapy, supportive care, such as fluid management and monitoring for signs of increased intracranial pressure, is necessary.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous ampicillin and cefotaxime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive care until lumbar puncture culture and blood culture results return:
Incorrect: Supportive care with intravenous fluids and observation is appropriate treatment for stable patients with confirmed aseptic viral meningitis. However, in this neonate with signs suggestive of acute bacterial meningitis with sepsis, immediate empiric antibiotics should be provided while awaiting culture results. 
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This regimen can be used to treat older children with suspected acute bacterial meningitis. Ceftriaxone is not recommended in neonates due to the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus, and in neonates, ampicillin should be used to provide coverage against Listeria. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head:
Incorrect: Imaging with CT scan of the head should be performed before lumbar puncture in patients with suspected acute meningitis who have signs of increased intracranial pressure. This patient does not have signs of increased intracranial pressure.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and cefotaxime:
Incorrect: This regimen can be used to treat older children with suspected acute bacterial meningitis. In neonates, ampicillin should be used to provide coverage for Listeria.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of a cough. The parents report that the boy was in his usual state of health until two hours prior to presentation when his mom heard him coughing in the other room. He has continued to cough since. He does not have abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He is 40<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight and 35<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 95/60, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, he is well-appearing, in no acute distress, and breathing comfortably. He has a frequent dry cough. Skin exam shows no rashes. On pulmonary exam, there is wheezing localized to the right lung. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This two-year-old boy has an acute cough that came on quickly while his mother was out of the room. He has no signs or symptoms of respiratory distress or hypoxemia and has evidence of wheezing localized to the right lung. This patient’s presentation and his age are consistent with a foreign body aspiration. Bronchoscopy is the most appropriate next step for diagnosis and treatment.

For children presenting with respiratory symptoms, Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure (ABCDE) should be assessed. If a patient is unstable, appropriate interventions should be taken, such as stabilizing airway, breathing, and circulation with possible intubation and intravenous fluids. If a patient is stable, then management depends on the diagnosis. When lower airway obstruction is present, the patient may have hypoxemia and/or respiratory distress. In these situations, oxygen and mechanical ventilation should be given as needed. Lower airway obstruction can also cause diffuse wheezing, such as during an asthma exacerbation, and albuterol is appropriate.

Foreign body aspiration most commonly occurs in children younger than two years old, and it can be life threatening. In witnessed episodes of cough and choking, the diagnosis is clear. With large objects, the obstruction may occur higher up and patients may present with stridor and respiratory distress. If the event is not witnessed and there is lower airway obstruction, signs can be more subtle, including acute onset coughing. On physical exam, patients may have localized wheezing or the unilateral absence of breath sounds. Obstruction typically occurs in the right lung since the right mainstem bronchus is wider and runs more vertically than the left mainstem bronchus. When foreign body aspiration is suspected based on clinical findings, bronchoscopy can be both diagnostic and therapeutic with the removal of the foreign body.  

Option Analysis

❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: Albuterol is the appropriate treatment for asthma. Despite wheezing heard on lung exam in this patient, his presentation is more consistent with a foreign body aspiration given the acute onset of cough and localization of wheezing to the right lung.  
❌ IM epinephrine:
Incorrect: IM epinephrine is the appropriate treatment for anaphylaxis. Patients with anaphylaxis typically present with severe respiratory symptoms and distress and hypoxemia in severe cases. Facial swelling and abdominal discomfort with nausea and vomiting may also be seen with anaphylaxis, all of which are absent in this case.  
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin would be the appropriate treatment for community-acquired pneumonia. This patient is afebrile with an acute-onset cough, making pneumonia unlikely. If this patient had pneumonia, it would be expected that he would have developed a cough over days, not hours, and crackles would be more likely on exam.  
❌ Supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: This patient is not in respiratory distress and does not have hypoxemia; therefore, he does not require supplemental oxygen.  
✅ Bronchoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A five-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for a follow-up visit. She has recently been treated for recurrent otitis media. She has a medical history of recurrent pansinusitis, recurrent pneumonias, and chronic productive cough. Her weight is in the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile and height is in the 15<sup>th</sup> percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 110/65, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, she is thin and has nasal polyps as well as bilateral middle ear serous effusions with loss of landmarks and light reflex. Cardiac exam reveals regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, but the heart is auscultated on the right side of the chest. Which of the following tests will confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a medical history of recurrent otitis media, pneumonias, and sinusitis as well as a chronic cough and physical exam findings of nasal polyps, situs inversus, and pulmonary crackles; all these symptoms are consistent with primary ciliary dyskinesia. Although there is no gold standard for diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia, a nasociliary biopsy is the best test for diagnosis.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia is an inherited disorder that affects cilia of the airways, causing impairment of mucociliary clearance and ultimately causing recurrent respiratory infections. In patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia, a nasociliary biopsy would reveal an ultrastructural ciliary defect. Genetic testing and video microscopy are other methods for diagnosing primary ciliary dyskinesia.

In addition to history and physical examination, imaging, often chest X-ray, is frequently the modality of choice for differentiating chronic cases of lower airway obstruction. Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia may have hyperinflation, bronchiectasis, and bronchial wall thickening seen on chest X-ray. Patients who have situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis can be diagnosed with Kartagener syndrome, a type of primary ciliary dyskinesia.

Patients with cystic fibrosis may have imaging findings of bronchiectasis, peribronchial thickening, air trapping, and/or mucous plugging with dilated bronchi in a predominantly upper lobe distribution. Patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia may have hyperinflated lungs with scattered cystic spaces among coarsened and reticular opacities. Patients with asthma may have hyperinflation and bronchial wall thickening. Even if chest X-ray is not diagnostic, it can often narrow down the differential in cases of lower airway obstruction. In this case, it would confirm the patient’s diagnosis of situs inversus (see below) and may show hyperinflation and bronchiectasis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Nasociliary biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: In the setting of lower airway obstruction, a bronchoscopy can diagnose (and treat) a foreign body aspiration. This patient’s symptoms are more chronic and systemic, making a foreign body aspiration unlikely.  
❌ Chest X-ray:
Incorrect: In the setting of lower airway obstruction, a chest X-ray may help diagnose cystic fibrosis, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, foreign body aspiration, or a congenital anomaly. In this case, it may confirm situs inversus, but it would not diagnose the underlying condition of primary ciliary dyskinesia.  
❌ Sweat test:
Incorrect: Sweat tests are used to diagnose cystic fibrosis. Although patients with cystic fibrosis also have otitis media, sinusitis, chronic cough, and nasal polyps, they do not have situs inversus.  
❌ Barium swallow study:
Incorrect: Barium swallow studies are typically used to diagnose various GI blockages or functional disorders. In the setting of lower airway obstruction, a barium swallow study could identify a vascular ring/sling. Anterior indentation of the esophagus on a barium swallow study is consistent with a vascular ring/sling. This patient’s symptoms are more chronic and associated with bacterial infections, making primary ciliary dyskinesia more likely.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department (ED) for fatigue and pallor worsening over the past month. The patient was born at 38 weeks of gestation and has no significant medical history. He is breastfeeding and recently started to eat more solid food. Since 4 months old, he has been taking a daily multivitamin with iron. He is at the 40th percentile for length and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 50/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94%. On examination, he is lying quietly in his parent’s lap, but alert. He appears pale and has pallor on his inner eyelids. He is tachycardic with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best over the left lower sternal border. Capillary refill is 3 seconds. He has no nasal flaring, retractions, or belly breathing. Abdomen is soft and nontender. His initial lab results are shown below. Parents have not noticed bleeding or red or black stools. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  7.2 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  21.2 % 
 Leukocyte count  11,300/mm3 
 Platelet count  280,000/mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  78 fL 
 Reticulocyte Count  1.2%
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting to the ED with worsening fatigue and pallor and has physical exam findings of tachycardia and delayed capillary refill. These findings, with the laboratory results, are consistent with severe anemia. This patient is showing early signs of hemodynamic instability (i.e. tachycardia and delayed capillary refill) and IV access needs to be obtained before further intervention. The most likely diagnosis in this infant with normocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count, and low suspicion for infection or active bleeding is transient erythroblastopenia.  

In the setting of anemia, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the provider should stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. IV access is required for volume resuscitation and possible medication administration. When a patient with anemia is unstable, be sure to look for active bleeding due to trauma, as well as signs of internal bleeding such as hematochezia, melena, or hematuria. Once the patient is stabilized, they should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring. Although obtaining IV access and placing on continuous monitor are often performed simultaneously, IV access and patient stabilization are the priorities. Occasionally, patients with severe anemia will require supplemental oxygenation, especially if oxygen saturation is <90%.  

Patients with transient erythroblastopenia are usually healthy infants (6 months and older) that present with gradual progression of symptoms. Most of the time, transient erythroblastopenia of childhood is a self-limited, benign condition, but occasionally there are severe cases such as in this vignette. Transient erythroblastopenia of childhood occurs when the bone marrow transiently fails to produce red blood cells. In addition to normocytic anemia with low reticulocyte count, there can also be neutropenia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain IV access:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: Although this patient’s respiratory rate and oxygen saturation are at the high and low end of normal, respectively, supplemental oxygen is not indicated. This patient is showing early signs of hemodynamic instability and IV access is necessary.
❌ Place on continuous monitor:
Incorrect: This patient has severe anemia and shows early signs of hemodynamic instability. This patient should ultimately be placed on a continuous monitor but not before IV access is obtained. 
❌ Start iron supplementation:
Incorrect: This patient has normocytic anemia causing symptoms of hypovolemia. Iron deficiency anemia, that would require iron supplementation is microcytic. In addition, this patient has early signs of hemodynamic instability and needs to be stabilized. If this patient had iron deficiency anemia a blood transfusion would correct symptoms faster than iron supplementation in the setting of severe iron deficiency.
❌ Check for lead poisoning:
Incorrect: This patient has early signs of hemodynamic instability and needs to be stabilized before further laboratory testing is performed. In addition, this patient has normocytic anemia and anemia secondary to lead poisoning is microcytic.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for a weight check. She was born at 39.2 weeks gestation. Parents report that she has difficulty feeding and tires quickly, so they have been bottle feeding breastmilk to her. She has no cyanosis or sweating with feeds. Newborn screen was positive for a thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) of 30 mIU/L (normal: < 20 mIU/L) and free thyroxine (T4) of 1ng/dL (normal: 0.8-2 ng/dL). This finding was confirmed, and she subsequently started on Levothyroxine 1.5 weeks ago. She is at the 30th percentile for length and 8th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 158/min, respirations are 36/min, blood pressure is 70/42 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On examination, she has jaundice of her face and upper torso and a small reducible umbilical hernia. Blood work is obtained due to persistent jaundice and is shown below. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be expected given the most likely cause of this patient's anemia?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 CBC 
 Hemoglobin  10.3 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  30.3% 
 Leukocyte count  10,900/mm3 
 Platelet count  265,000/mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  112 fL 
 Reticulocyte Count  1% 
 Serum chemistry
 Alanine transaminase (ALT)  24 U/L 
 Aspartate transaminase (AST)  30 U/L 
 Indirect bilirubin  6.8 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.4 mg/dl 
 Thyroid function tests
 Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH)  22.4 mIU/L 
 Free T4  1.6 ng/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has congenital hypothyroidism that was picked up on newborn screening and confirmed with subsequent thyroid function tests. A large anterior fontanelle is a common finding in patients with congenital hypothyroidism. This patient’s history of feeding problems and persistent jaundice and umbilical hernia on physical examination are consistent with the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism. Labs confirm hyperbilirubinemia and macrocytic anemia, both of which can be associated with congenital hypothyroidism.  

When narrowing down the differential diagnosis in patients presenting with anemia, the patient’s age is important, as some causes of anemia occur only at certain times in a child’s life, such as physiologic anemia of infancy which occurs around 8-12 weeks of life. Whether the patient has a history of prematurity should also be considered. Premature infants are at risk for anemia of prematurity around 4-8 weeks of life. History should also include diet history, medications, exposures (such as exposure to lead paint), recent infections, family history of anemia, and newborn screen results.   

Anemia in newborns and infants can present with generalized fatigue and malaise. On physical exam, patients may have tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, a flow murmur, and/or pallor. Congenital disorders associated with anemia often have associated physical abnormalities that may help narrow down the differential. For example, Diamond Blackfan anemia has associated thumb malformations (see below), craniofacial abnormalities, short stature, and heart defects. In addition to the physical examination findings noted above, patients with congenital hypothyroidism may also present with periorbital edema, macroglossia, and hypotonia.  


Triphalangeal thumb
Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Large anterior fontanelle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypertonia:
Incorrect: This patient has congenital hypothyroidism which presents with hypotonia, not hypertonia.
❌ Thumb malformation:
Incorrect: This patient has congenital hypothyroidism which does not have associated thumb malformations. Diamond blackfan anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia that has associated thumb malformations in addition to craniofacial abnormalities, short stature, kidney defects, and heart defects.
❌ Exophthalmos:
Incorrect: Exophthalmos is a physical examination finding in patients with hyperthyroidism/Graves disease. It is more common in adults than in children. This patient has hypothyroidism and associated macrocytic anemia, not hyperthyroidism.
❌ Cafe-au-lait spots:
Incorrect: Cafe au lait spots is a physical examination finding in patients with Fanconi’s anemia. Fanconi’s anemia causes pancytopenia and has physical examination findings of short stature as well as thumb, renal, and ophthalmologic abnormalities in addition to cafe au lait spots.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the pediatric office for a well-check visit. The parents have no concerns, and there were no changes to her health since the last visit. She eats a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, meat, and fish regularly. She rarely consumes sugary drinks. She has good sleeping habits. Recommended vaccinations prior to this visit are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 98/60 mmHg, weight is in the 56th percentile, and height is in the 62nd percentile. On physical examination, she is a pleasant and alert child. She makes good eye contact while talking and answers questions appropriately. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Tanner Stage 1 sexual maturity is observed. Which of the following is most appropriate to include at this visit?

choices.text: Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Gender and sexuality discussion  Mental health discussion
HPV vaccine discussion  Lead level  Mental health discussion  Influenza vaccination
Meningococcal vaccination  Lead level  Influenza vaccination  Gender and sexuality discussion
Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Meningococcal vaccination  Review of academic performance
HPV vaccine discussion  DTap vaccination  Discussion of mental health  Review of academic performance

questions.solution:
The well-check visit for a 9-year-old child should include a screening lipid panel, HPV vaccination counseling, review of academic performance, and discussion of mental health and gender and sexuality. Influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations should be offered based on the season.    

The well-child visit is an opportunity for healthcare providers to engage with patients and their caregivers about a number of components of health promotion, including routine screenings, immunizations, family wellness, child development, and safety. The details of each component will vary depending on the age of the child. Around the age of 7-8 years old, children should begin having a yearly assessment of their sexual maturity as characterized by the Tanner stage. This is also when discussions regarding early signs of puberty can begin and caregivers can be encouraged to talk with their children about body changes that can be expected. Starting at age 9-10 years old discussions regarding gender identity and sexuality can begin. Families should be encouraged to talk openly with their child about values, identity, and self-expression and to welcome questions as their child matures.  

Around age 7 and at subsequent visits, the well-child visit should include an assessment of the child’s mental health. Families should be encouraged to promote mental health and well-being by frequently checking in with their child and helping their child recognize, process, and effectively express strong emotions. Safety should be reviewed at every well-child visit, including seatbelt use, helmet use, sun protection, internet safety, bullying, and safe firearm storage.

Option Analysis

✅  Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Gender and sexuality discussion  Mental health discussion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  HPV vaccine discussion  Lead level  Mental health discussion  Influenza vaccination :
Incorrect: HPV vaccine discussion, discussion of mental health, and influenza vaccination if seasonally appropriate would be appropriate at a 9-year-old well-check. However, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. 
❌  Meningococcal vaccination  Lead level  Influenza vaccination  Gender and sexuality discussion :
Incorrect: Seasonal influenza vaccination and discussion of gender and sexuality are appropriate for a 9-year-old well-check. However, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. Also, the meningococcal vaccine is not routinely offered until the 11- or 12-year-old visit. 
❌  Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Meningococcal vaccination  Review of academic performance  :
Incorrect: A lipid panel, HPV vaccine discussion, and review of academic performance would be appropriate for a 9-year-old well-check. However, the meningococcal vaccine is not routinely offered until the 11- or 12-year-old visit. 
❌  HPV vaccine discussion  DTap vaccination  Discussion of mental health  Review of academic performance :
Incorrect: The HPV vaccine discussion, discussion of mental health, and review of academic performance would be appropriate at a 9-year-old well-check. However, the DTap vaccine is usually given last between the ages of 4 and 6 years old. A Tdap vaccine can be given to an older child who needs a catch-up vaccine, but this child is noted to be up-to-date on previously recommended vaccinations.

questions.text:
A newborn boy born at 39 weeks gestation who is 7 hours old is in the neonatal intensive care unit with persistent respiratory distress that started 1 hour after delivery. He was delivered by cesarean delivery for fetal macrosomia. Maternal history is positive for gestational diabetes with normal prenatal ultrasound. There was no history of maternal fever and GBS was negative. Amniotic fluid was clear and there were no complications at delivery. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 165 beats/minute, respiratory rate is 84/minute, and Oxygen saturation is 91% on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with 50% FiO2. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, subcostal retractions with nasal flaring, and diffuse crackles in both lung fields. No heart murmur is heard. The patient has normal pulses bilaterally. Abdominal exam is normal. Initial lab results are shown below. Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Hemoglobin
18 g/dL  
Hematocrit
48 %  
Leukocyte count  
9,800/mm3   
Platelet count  
280,000/mm3   
PH
7.30  
PCO2
52 mmHg  
PO2
80 mmHg  
Bicarbonate (HCO3)  
21 mEq/L  
Base deficit  
-3

choices.text: Bowel loops in left hemithorax on chest x-ray
Fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs on chest x-ray
Left to right shunt on echocardiogram

questions.solution:
This newborn with a maternal history of gestational diabetes who was delivered by cesarean section presents with respiratory distress beyond 6 hours of life. This is consistent with transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN), which can be confirmed by obtaining a chest x-ray that shows fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs.

TTN is caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid after birth, which leads to ineffective gas exchange and respiratory distress. Risk factors for TTN include cesarean delivery, precipitous delivery, and maternal diabetes. TTN typically presents shortly after birth with respiratory distress and persists beyond 6 hours of life. If symptoms resolve within the first 6 hours of life, then it is classified as delayed transition of the newborn. Typical physical exam findings include tachypnea, grunting, retractions, hypoxia requiring oxygen supplementation, and diffuse crackles in bilateral lung fields.

The diagnostic workup for an infant with respiratory distress should include obtaining labs such as a complete blood count (CBC) and blood gas. A CBC may help rule out anemia and infections such as neonatal sepsis and neonatal pneumonia. In this newborn, the CBC shows no evidence of anemia or leukocytosis. Blood gas is obtained to evaluate gas exchange and acid-base balance. The blood gas in this patient shows mild respiratory acidosis which is expected with transient tachypnea of the newborn.

Chest x-ray is essential to exclude other causes of respiratory distress in the newborn such as respiratory distress syndrome, meconium aspiration syndrome, and pneumothorax. Typical chest x-ray findings of TTN include the presence of pulmonary edema, with diffuse increased interstitial lung markings, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs. A lung ultrasound will demonstrate double lung points. An echocardiogram should be obtained if the newborn experiences persistent respiratory distress despite adequate treatment to rule out persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).
 
Image Courtesy of STATdx

Option Analysis

❌ Bowel loops in left hemithorax on chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Bowel loops in the left hemithorax on chest x-ray are seen in patients with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) which is commonly diagnosed on prenatal ultrasound and presents with scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds heard on chest exam. The newborn in this case had a normal prenatal ultrasound and physical exam findings are not consistent with CDH.  
❌ Compact B-lines on lung ultrasound:
Incorrect: Compact B-lines on lung ultrasound are seen with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) and preterm newborns with RDS typically present with tachypnea, grunting, retractions, and nasal flaring immediately after birth. This full-term newborn with precipitous cesarean delivery is unlikely to have respiratory distress syndrome.  
✅ Fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs on chest x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left to right shunt on echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Left to right shunt on echocardiogram is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) which is seen more commonly in premature infants and presents with a continuous machinery-like murmur and bounding peripheral pulses. This newborn does not have a heart murmur and has normal pulses which makes PDA a less likely cause of his symptoms.  
❌ Positive blood cultures:
Incorrect: Positive blood cultures are seen in infectious causes of respiratory distress such as neonatal sepsis or neonatal pneumonia. This newborn doesn't have temperature instability, no focal lung findings, and no risk factors for infections (maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, positive GBS, prolonged membrane rupture).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent for a “barking” cough and nasal congestion for the past 3 days. Today her parent noticed she was having difficulty breathing. She was diagnosed with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), 3 days ago by her pediatrician when her symptoms started. She was born at 33 weeks gestation and was briefly hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), but otherwise has no significant past medical history. Vaccines are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 107/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air with good air entry. The patient is awake and alert and has stridor at rest with moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions. Oral examination reveals erythematous changes of the posterior pharynx with moist mucous membranes. Based on these findings, the patient is given intramuscular dexamethasone. Which of the following clinical features is an indication for treatment with nebulized racemic epinephrine?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic clinical features of moderate croup including stridor at rest and moderate retractions. All patients with croup can be treated with dexamethasone; however, not all patients require treatment with nebulized racemic epinephrine. Patients like this one with moderate symptoms should be treated with nebulized racemic epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.

Patients with croup are typically between 6 months and 3 years old, and present with a low-grade fever and signs and symptoms of upper respiratory infection that can progress to a barking or seal-like cough, hoarseness, and stridor. The cough may worsen at night. Physical examination should assess for the presence of stridor (and whether it is present at rest), and the presence and severity of retractions, along with signs of respiratory distress. These features can be used to determine the severity of illness, which will then guide management.

Nebulized racemic epinephrine works by reducing airway edema and thus reducing stridor and work of breathing. Patients who receive a single dose of epinephrine should be monitored for 2-3 hours after administration to ensure that rebound edema and rebound symptoms do not occur. If rebound symptoms occur, patients should be hospitalized and given humidified oxygen along with symptomatic care (e.g. cool mist treatments) and repeat racemic epinephrine doses.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Stridor at rest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Age is not a determining factor for the administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest, and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ History of prematurity:
Incorrect: History of prematurity is not a determining factor for the administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ Preceding viral illness:
Incorrect: Preceding illness is not a determining factor for administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest, and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ Oxygen saturation:
Incorrect: Oxygen saturation is not a determining factor for administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of a cough and increased work of breathing. The parent reports the patient has had a “barking” cough for the past two days, and today the patient seemed to be struggling to breathe. He has had low-grade fevers at home and has a sibling with similar symptoms. The patient does not have any significant past medical history and vaccines are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHH, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient has stridor at rest, moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions, and an audible barking cough. Based on this infant’s presentation and findings, a diagnosis is made, and he is treated with intramuscular dexamethasone and a single dose of racemic epinephrine. On reassessment 15 minutes later, the patient is resting comfortably in bed with a normal respiratory rate and without stridor. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Monitor for three hours, if no further stridor discharge home
Admit to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU)
Discharge home with outpatient follow-up in two days
Administer additional racemic epinephrine and discharge home

questions.solution:
This 15-month-old boy presents with findings consistent with croup, including barking cough, stridor, and increased work of breathing. Patients with croup should receive dexamethasone. In patients with stridor at rest or moderate retractions, nebulized racemic epinephrine should also be given. Following the administration of racemic epinephrine, patients should be observed for three hours to see if symptoms recur. If there is no recurrence of symptoms, then patients can be discharged home.

Treatment of patients with croup depends on the severity of symptoms. Patients with mild croup can be treated with antipyretics, oral fluids, and oral dexamethasone as needed. Patients with moderate croup (stridor at rest and mild to moderate retractions but no or little distress or agitation) should receive oral or intramuscular dexamethasone and nebulized racemic epinephrine. Patients with severe croup (stridor at rest and marked retractions with agitation, lethargy, or cyanosis) should receive IV dexamethasone, nebulized racemic epinephrine, and possibly heliox therapy. All patients with croup should be provided with a cool mist. For children with ongoing severe symptoms, nebulized racemic epinephrine can be repeated every 15 to 20 minutes. Nebulized racemic epinephrine reduces airway edema. However, in some cases, rebound edema can occur, requiring further intervention. As such, patients should be monitored for at least 3 hours before being discharged. If symptoms recur, the patient should be admitted to the hospital and given humidified oxygen along with symptomatic care (e.g. cool mist treatments).
     

Option Analysis

✅ Monitor for three hours, if no further stridor discharge home:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Admit to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU):
Incorrect: This patient is clinically improving following administration of oral dexamethasone and racemic epinephrine. Admission to the PICU is not needed at this time. If he continues to be stable without rebound symptoms, he can be monitored for a total of 3 hours and discharged home.
❌ Discharge home with outpatient follow-up in two days:
Incorrect: This patient requires several hours of monitoring before being discharged home, and if he develops recurrent stridor he can get additional doses of racemic epinephrine, and hospital admission would be required.
❌ Admit to the pediatric floor:
Incorrect: This patient needs several hours of monitoring before a disposition plan can be made. If this patient continues to improve without recurrent stridor, he can be discharged home.
❌ Administer additional racemic epinephrine and discharge home:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms have resolved and there is no further stridor on reassessment. Therefore, administration of additional racemic epinephrine is not necessary. The patient should be monitored for a total of 3 hours and if there is no recurrence of stridor he can be discharged home.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of left eye swelling for five days and one day of fever. Parent reports the patient hit his eye on a door handle 5 days ago, and since that time, it has had progressively worsening swelling, and today he developed a fever. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), blood pressure is 110/67mmHg, pulse is 111/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has erythema, swelling of the left upper and lower eyelids, and tenderness around the orbit. There is no bruising around the eye and the left cheek is not flattened. Conjunctiva is normal bilaterally, but the left eye has reduced visual acuity. There is marked pain in the left eye with extraocular movements. The right eye and eyelids are within normal limits. Tympanic membranes are normal bilaterally. Which of the following complications could result if the underlying condition is not identified and treated appropriately?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with several concerning features of orbital cellulitis including orbital swelling, erythema, and tenderness about the orbit. Pain with extraocular eye movements indicates increased intraorbital pressure, differentiating this condition from preseptal periorbital cellulitis. Without recognition and acute treatment, this patient’s condition may progress, and he could develop an orbital abscess, subperiosteal abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or intracranial extension all of which could result in permanent vision loss.

Periorbital and orbital cellulitis are bacterial infections of the soft tissues within or around the orbit typically from Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and other gram-positive skin flora. The relation of the infection to the orbital septum and the presence or absence of increased intraorbital pressure can differentiate orbital from periorbital cellulitis.
